Be it further enacted, That the Judge of said City Court shall have the power to cause testimony to be taken and used de bene esse, and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction in all cases according to the General Laws of this State, and the Judge and all other officers of said City Court shall have power respectively to administer all oaths pertaining to their office as the Judge and other officers of the Superior Courts may in like cases do; and said Judge shall also have power to attest deeds and other papers and administer affidavits in all cases anywhere in the State in which. by existing laws, such papers may be attested and affidavits administered by Justices of the Peace of this State, and the Judge of said City Court shall have all the powers and authority throughout his jurisdiction
of Judges of the Superior Courts, except where by law exclusive power and authority are vested in Judges of the Superior Courts and all laws relating to and governing Judges of the Superior Court shall apply to the Judge of said City Court, so far as the same is applicable. The Judge of said Court shall have power and authority to issue attachments, distress warrants, garnishment summons, possessory warrants, dispossessory warrants, criminal warrants, and to issue all processes and writs that can or may be issued by Justices of the Peace in this State, and to try and dispose of the same. And said Judge shall have power to sit as a Court of Inquiry and a Committal Court to the same extent that Justices of the Peace may in criminal cases. Said Judge shall have the power and authority under the same rules and regulations governing Judges of the Superior Courts to issue writs of habeas corpus and dispose of the same, and the said judge of the City Court shall have the same power to punish for contempt as is vested in the Superior Court, or the Judge thereof. Powers of judge.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That, whenever, in the discretion of the Judge of said Court it is necessary, the Judge shall appoint a stenographer of said Court, and the expenses of reporting and making a transcript of the record shall be the same as is allowed stenographers in Superior Courts, and shall be paid in the same manner. In all criminal cases where the Judge deems it necessary, he shall order the record stenographically reported and the expenses thereof to be paid by the County. Stenographer.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That the mode of procedure, and all matters relating to service, pleading and practice shall be the same as now applies or may hereafter apply in the Superior Courts; the process to writs shall be annexed by the Clerk of said City Court, be tested in the name of the Judge thereof and be directed and served as provided for processes in the Superior
Courts. The rules of the Superior Courts as embraced in Sections 6260 to 6319 inclusive, of Parks Annotated Code together with such changes as shall be made therein, relating to Appeals, Attorneys, Bills of Particulars, Claims, Clerks, Consent, Continuances, Defense, Dockets, Exceptions, Executors and Administrators, Illegalities, Interrogatories, Judgments, Juries, Lost Papers, Motions, Notice, New Trials, Recognizances, Sheriffs, Witnesses, together with such other matters as may be the subject of rules of the Superior Courts shall apply to said City Court as if named with the Superior Court so far as the nature of said Court will admit. All suits shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of said Court twenty days before the first day of the term to which it is returnable, and the defendant shall be served fifteen days before said term. Procedure, etc.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the first term after the suit is filed and service had upon the defendant, as above set forth, shall be the appearance term, and where the defendant desires to file any pleadings of any character, same shall be filed on the first day of the term to which said suit is brought and filed and service had upon the defendant, and if no pleadings or defense is filed as herein provided said case shall be marked in default and a judgment absolute shall issue therein at the first term to which said suit is brought, provided, that the Judge under the same rules and regulations obtaining in the Superior Courts may allow a default opened, but in all cases where no defense is filed by defendant, or such defense where filed is disposed of by demurrer thereto, at first term where suit filed and service had, final judgment shall be entered up against the defendant. Where defendant files issuable defense such case shall be tried at the next term. Terms.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That the Judge of said Court shall have power and authority to try all civil cases brought and pending in said Court and to give
judgment therein without the intervention of a jury: provided that in all cases brought in said Court, either party in a civil or defendant in a criminal case pending in said Court may demand a trial by jury at or before the call of said case for trial. Hearings without juries.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That the Clerk of said City Court shall prepare and file in his office a complete copy of the traverse jury list of the Superior Court of the County of Jones, as provided from time to time of the Superior Courts. From said copy, traverse jurors in said City Court shall be drawn in the following manner: The Clerk of said City Court shall write upon separate tickets the names of each traverse juror, and shall number the same and place the same in a box to be prepared for that purpose from which shall be drawn all traverse jurors as now required by law in the Superior Courts. All laws with reference to the drawing, selecting, and summoning traverse and tales jurors in the Superior Courts shall apply to said City Court, except that the Judge may draw a jury in term time or vacation, when for any cause a jury was not drawn at the last term of Court. Traverse juries.

Sec. 17. All laws with reference to the qualifications, relations, empannelling, fining and challenging jurors, now of force in this State, or hereafter enacted by the General Assembly, regulating the same in the Superior Courts, shall apply to and be observed in said City Court, except when inconsistent with the provisions of this Act. Qualifications, empaneling, fining, etc.

Sec. 18. From the panel of twenty-four jurors drawn and summoned by the provision of this Act, the Judge of said City Court shall cause to be made up two juries to be known and distinguished as numbers one and two and all cases and issues to be tried by jury, civil or criminal, at that term of said City Court, shall be tried by one of these or by a jury stricken from both as hereinafter provided. In cases from any cause said
panel should be reduced below twenty-four, the Judge shall have power to fill it by causing talesmen to be summoned instanter. All laws and rules, both civil and criminal, regulating the selection of jurors in the Superior Court, shall apply to said City Court, except where they are inconsistent with the terms of this Act. One or more additional panels of jurors may be summoned for said City Court, when needed in the opinion of the Judge presiding. Panel.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all criminal cases shall be tried upon written accusation, setting forth plainly the offense charged, founded upon the affidavit of the prosecutor, except in cases where indictment is handed down from the Superior Court. No defendant shall have any right to demand an indictment by the Grand Jury of Jones County, nor shall any defendant charged with misdemeanor have a right to demand a committal trial in said Court. Said City Court of Gray shall stand and be open at all times for the hearing and trial of criminal cases, and such cases may be disposed of at any time by the Judge unless a jury is demanded by the defendant. Any defendant may withdraw, at any time, demand for jury trial and said case may then be tried by the judge. All laws and rules relating to the form and substance of said accusation, and all rules of procedure governing the trial of criminal cases upon indictment in the Superior Courts, shall apply in said City Court of Gray so far as the nature of said Court will allow. Written accusation.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of all committing Magistrates of Jones County to bind over all misdemeanor cases to the City Court of Gray for trial, where probable cause is shown to warrant binding over. Commitments to city court.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted, That the Judge of the Superior Court of Jones County shall send down
from the Superior Court to the City Court of Gray for trial and disposition all presentments and indictments for misdemeanors which may be undisposed of at the close of each term of the Superior Court, and the order transmitting said cases shall be entered on the minutes of both of said Courts, which order may be passed in term time or vacation: provided that in all transferred cases the Solicitor-General of said Superior Court shall be entitled to his accrued cost to be collected as now provided by law. Transfer of presentments and indictments.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted, That the Judge of said City Court of Gray shall have power to grant a new trial in any case, civil or criminal, in this Court, under the same rules and regulations now obtaining, or that may hereafter obtain, in the Superior Courts. The same rules and laws which now obtain in the Superior Court with reference to the application, objections, motions made after adjournment, rule nisi, supersedeas and brief of evidence shall apply in said City Court of Gray as far as the nature of said Court will allow. New trials.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted, That a writ of error shall lie from said City Court of Gray to the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court of this State upon a bill of exceptions filed under the same rules and regulations as govern the issue of writs of error and filing of bills of Exceptions from the Superior Courts to said Appellate Courts. Writs of error.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted, That all fines and forfeitures arising from cases in said City Court shall be applied to the payment of fees and costs of the Solicitor and Clerk and Sheriff of said City Court accruing in said Court except in civil cases, and including their insolvent costs therein, the same to be distributed pro rata thereon under the same rules and regulations governing the distribution of fines and forfeitures to officers of the Superior Courts, provided, however, that twenty per cent. of
all fines and forfeitures collected shall be paid into the County Treasury for county purposes. That in cases originating in Justice Courts and sent up to said City Court, the Justice and Constable shall be entitled to their cost in the particular case in the event the defendant therein is convicted and pays the fine and costs in the case. In all criminal cases allowed by the Court settled $3.00 shall be paid to the County Treasury for county purposes. Fines and forfeitures.

Sec. 25. Be it further enacted, That said City Court of Gray shall be a Court of Record and shall have a seal, and minutes, records, orders and other books and files as may be required to carry on the business of said Court, and same shall be kept in the Clerk's Office of said County. The Officer in charge of the financial affairs of said County shall furnish all books and stationery for said Court and the officers thereof. Court of record.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted, That the regular terms of said Court shall be held Quarterly on the second Mondays in February, May, August and November of each year, and juries as hereinbefore set forth shall be summoned for each term of said Court under the same rules and regulations as apply to the summoning of juries in the Superior Court. Provided, that there shall also be monthly terms held on the second Mondays in each month in the year for the disposal of civil and criminal business, except that the jurisdiction of said Court at the monthly terms in civil cases shall be limited to cases not exceeding Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) of the principal sum. Juries shall not be drawn for the monthly terms except in the sound discretion of the Judge of said Court. The Judge of said City Court of Gray may, in his sound discretion, call special terms of said Court under the same rules and provisions as now or hereafter may exist for calling extra sessions of the Superior Courts of this State. In any case coming within the jurisdiction of the monthly terms of said
Court, and which may be filed thereto, the plaintiff may take judgment by default at the first term under the same rules and provisions as set forth in Section 14 of this Act. Terms.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted, That the pay of jurors summoned and sworn in said City Court of Gray shall be the same, and shall be paid in the same manner as jurors in the Superior Court of said County of Jones. The rules obtaining in Superior Courts for obtaining non-resident witnesses shall obtain in the City Court of Gray, and such witnesses shall receive the same pay as now allowed in said Superior Court, to be paid upon the order of the Solicitor of Said Court with the approval of the Judge. Compensation of jurors.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted, That the terms of said Court shall be held at the Court House at Gray, the county site of Jones County, Georgia, and said terms shall last until the business on the dockets is disposed of, unless sooner adjourned by the Judge. The Judge of said Court may in term time set cases for trial in vacation, and said cases shall then be tried as at regular sessions of said Court. Court house.

Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That all Judgments obtained in said Court shall be a lien on all property of the defendant or defendants, in the same manner as judgments issued from the Superior Courts. Lien of judgments.

Sec. 30. Be it further enacted, That this Amending Act shall in no wise be construed as disturbing the existence of the present City Court of Gray established by Act of the General Assembly at its regular session in 1913, but that the said City Court of Gray shall continue in its operation as though this Act had not been passed by the General Assembly except in those matters where the jurisdiction of this Court has been enlarged or changed, and excepting further, where the rules of procedure as to juries and other matters have been
changed. All cases, both civil and criminal, now pending in said Court, shall stand for trial in their regular order. This Amending Act shall take effect and shall supersede the Act creating the City Court of Gray approved August 16, 1913, and an Act amendatory thereof approved August 19, 1916, immediately upon the passage thereof by the General Assembly and the approval thereof by the Governor. Amending act. Effective on approval.
Sec. 31. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: JESUP CITY COURT; FEES AND COSTS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act, of the General Assembly of Georgia, passed 1916 session, establishing the City Court of Jesup; providing for the fixing of fees of the Solicitor of Said Court, and for the paying of all fines in the county treasury; to provide for the sheriffs cost and for the purpose of fixing cost in civil cases in said City Court, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, that Section 4, in the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, creating the City Court of Jesup, on page 250, of the Acts of 1916, be and the same is hereby amended as follows: Act of 1916 amended.

By striking out all of said Section after words State in the 32nd line of said Section, and inserting in lieu thereof, the following: That said Solicitor of said City Court of Jesup shall not receive any cost or fees, but shall be placed upon a salary of One Thousand
($1,000) Dollars per annum, which shall include all remunerations for said service as Solicitor of said Court, and the fees heretofore collected and all fines and forfeitures shall be paid into the county treasury of the County of Wayne, after the cost of Clerk of said Court, and the Sheriff and Bailiff of said Court, has been paid out of said fines or forfeitures. Solicitor's Salary. Fees to county treasury.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after after the passage of this Act, that in all criminal cases, tried in the City Court of Jesup where the defendant is convicted and placed upon the chain-gang then and in that event that the Sheriff of said County or the Bailiff of said City Court, shall be paid his actual legal cost in said case, and that the County Commissioner shall examine his bills for cost in cases where the defendant is placed upon the chain-gang then that said Commissioners shall audit said bill of cost and shall require all just and legal cost paid from the county treasury. Costs when defendant is convicted.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act, that the Sheriff and Clerk cost in all civil cases where the amount involved is not more than $500.00, that his cost for service shall not be more than the sum of $2.00 for each defendant, and where the amount involved is less than $100.00 then that the sheriff cost for service shall not be more than $1.00 each for the defendant served, and the Clerk of said City Court of Jesup, shall receive the same amount as stated for the Sheriff herein, in reference to furnished copies and processes only. Sheriff and clerk.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Charter of the City Court of Hinesville, approved August 9th, 1916, and the Act amendatory, thereof approved August 14th, 1917, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the Act creating the City Court of Hinesville, approved August 9th, 1916, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved August 14th, 1917, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Acts of 1916 and 1917 amended.

item.p: I. By striking from the second line of Section eleven the word Third and inserting in lieu thereof the word Second in the original Act.

II. By striking from the fourth and fifth lines of paragraph 2 of the amendatory Act, approved August 14, 1917, the word Third and inserting in lieu thereof the word Second so that said paragraph when so amended, will read as follows: That terms of said Court shall be held on the second Monday of each month, but there shall be four Quarterly terms held on the second Monday of January, April July and October of each year, at which terms trials by juries shall be had. Terms.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to establish the City Court of Ludowici; in the City of Ludowici, Long County, Georgia; to define its jurisdiction and powers; to provide for the appointment of the first Judge and Solicitor, and the election of all succeeding Judges and Solicitors of said Court; to fix the compensation of said Judge and Solicitors; to provide for a Clerk and Sheriff thereof, and to provide for their duties and fees; to provide for pleading and practice in said Court; to provide for entertaining and granting motions for new trials therein and the carrying of cases therefrom to the Court of Appeals of Georgia, by direct bills of Exceptions, or writs of error; to provide that no party prosecuted in said Court for a criminal offense shall have the right to demand an indictment by the Grand Jury of Long County, Georgia; to provide for the transfer of all misdemeanor indictments not disposed of at the term of the Court at which they are found, from the Superior Court of Long County to the said City Court of Ludowici; to provide for jury trials in said Court, and the number constituting said juries; to provide for an amendment, and to amend the Charter of Town of Ludowici, by changing the corporate name from Town of Ludowici, to City of Ludowici, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the City Court of Ludowici is hereby established to be organized, located, and held in the City of Ludowici, in Long County, Georgia, with civil and criminal jurisdiction over the entire County of Long. Court established.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said City Court of Ludowici shall have jurisdiction
to try and dispose of all cases of whatever nature, except those cases over which exclusive jurisdiction is vested in other Courts by the Constitution of Georgia, provided further that no suit or action can be brought or maintained in said City Court of Ludowici where the principal amount claimed is less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00.) Jurisdiction.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that said City Court of Ludowici shall have jurisdiction to try and dispose of all offenses committed in the County of Long, where the offender is not subject to loss of life, or confinement in the penitentiary, and no defendant prosecuted in the City Court of Ludowici, for any misdemeanor, shall ever have the right to demand an indictment by the Grand Jury of Long County. And it shall be the duty of all committing courts of said County of Long to bind over to said City Court all persons charged with offenses committed within said County of Long, over which said City Court has jurisdiction, there to answer for said offense. They shall be bound to said City Court whether the next term of the Superior Court of Long County convenes before or after the next term of said City Court. No right to demand indictment. Commitments to city court.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a Judge of said City who shall be elected by the qualified voters of Long County, who shall hold office for the term of four years, and if there shall be a vacancy in the office of Judge the Governor shall, by appointment,, fill the same until the next General Election, when a Judge shall be elected to fill the unexpired term, which election shall be held under the same rules as govern other elections, and shall serve until the election and qualification of his successor. The first election for said Judge shall be held at the General Election in November, 1922, under the rules and regulations governing election of members of the General Assembly, and the Judge elected on said date shall go into
office on January first, 1923, and hold his office for a period of four years, and until his successor is elected and qualified. The Hon. Melville Price, of Ludowici, Georgia, shall be the Judge of said Court from the time it is organized until January first, 1923, and until his successor is elected and qualified. The qualification of said Judge shall be: that he has been a practicing attorney for five years, and a resident of Long County, or that portion of old Liberty which is now Long County, for two years, or longer. Immediately before entering upon the discharge of his duties, said Judge shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons, and that I will faithfully and impartially perform all the duties which may be required of me as Judge of the City Court of Ludowici, according to the Constitution of this State and the Constitution of the United States, so help me, God, which oath shall be filed in the executive department. The Judge of said Court shall receive a salary of Six Hundred Dollars ($600.00) per year, which shall not be increased or diminished during his continuance in office, and the same shall be paid monthly out of the funds of Long County. Said salary shall be paid upon presentation of a bill, properly verified, to the Ordinary of said County Commissioners be hereafter provided for said County, which said county authority or authorities shall immediately draw a draft or warrant on the Treasurer, or County Depository, for the amount of same. The Judge of said Court shall receive no other compensation for his services. He shall not be permitted to practice law in his own court, but may practice in any other court. Judge. Election. Term. Vacancies. Judge named. Eligibility. Oath of office. Salary. Practice of law.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a Solicitor of said City Court, who shall be elected by the qualified voters of Long County, at the same time and in the same manner as provided for the Judge of said Court, whose term of office shall be four years, and until his successor is elected
and qualified. All vacancies in the office of Solicitor shall be filled as provided for vacancies in the office of Judge of said Court. It shall be the duty of said Solicitor to prosecute all offenses cognizable before said Court, and to represent the State in all proceedings in said Court. The said Solicitor shall receive the same fees for each written accusation, and shall receive the same fees as are provided for and allowed the Solicitor-General of the Superior Courts for their services in misdemeanor cases, and all other cases over which said City Court shall have jurisdiction. In the absence or disqualification of said Solicitor, the City Court Judge shall appoint a Solicitor pro tem, who shall receive the same fees as are allowed the regularly elected Solicitor of said City Court. Said Solicitor shall, for services rendered in the Supreme Court, or Court of Appeals, be paid by the State in the same manner as Solicitors-General of Superior Courts are paid for similar services rendered in said Appellate Courts. Further, provided that the qualifications of said Solicitor of said City Court shall be that he is a practicing attorney-at-law, and that he shall be a resident of Long County. The Hon. J. Francis Smiley shall be the Solicitor of said Court from the time of its organization until January 1st, 1923, and until his successor is elected and qualified. He shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, take and subscribe an oath applicable to his office similar to that required of the Judge of said Court. Solicitor. Election. Term. Vacancies. Fees. Solicitor pro tem. Services in courts of review. Solicitor named.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Clerk of the Superior Court of Long County, and the Sheriff of said Long County, shall be by virtue of their offices, Clerk and Sheriff of the City Court of Ludowici. Before entering upon the discharge of their duties as such officers of said City Court, they each shall take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of their respective offices, and the Clerk of said Court, before entering upon the
discharge of his duties, shall enter into a good and sufficient bond in the sum of One Thousand Dollars for the faithful discharge of his duties, and the Sheriff of said Court, shall likewise enter into a good and sufficient bond in the sum of Five Thousand Dollars for the faithful discharge of his duties, which bonds shall be filed with the Ordinary of said County, and which oaths shall be entered on the minutes of said Court. Said officers, in their official connection with said Court shall be known as the Clerk and Sheriff respectively, of the City Court of Ludowici. They each shall have authority to appoint deputies as provided for clerks and sheriffs of the Superior Courts by the Code of Georgia. Ex-officio clerk and Sheriff. Deputies.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all the duties and liabilities attached to the office of said Clerk of said City Court, and to the office of said Sheriff of said City Court, respectively, and the Judge of said City Court is empowered to enforce the same authority over said Clerk and Sheriff as is exercised by the Judge of the Superior Courts over the clerks of the Superior Courts, and Sheriffs of the counties of Georgia. Duties.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Clerk and Sheriff of said City Court shall receive the same fees for all services as are allowed by law for like services in the Superior Court, except in suits and cases where the warrants claimed do not exceed One Hundred Dollars, and in said latter cases, said Clerk and Sheriff of said Court shall, for their services, receive one-half (1-2) of the fees provided by law for similar services in the Superior Court of said County of Long. Said Clerk and Sheriff shall be amenable to the same processes and penalties as they are now amenable to as officers of the Superior Court, and they shall
be entitled to the same remedies to enforce the collection of their fees and costs in said City Court as they are now entitled to in the Superior Court. Fees.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the regular terms of said City Court shall be held on the Second Mondays in each month of the year, and that the February, May, August, and November Terms of said Court shall be known as the regular Quarterly Terms of said Court, at which Quarterly Terms all jury trials shall be had. The terms of said Court shall be held in the Court House of Long County, in Ludowici, Georgia, and said terms shall continue until all business is disposed of, unless sooner adjourned. The said Judge of said Court shall hold his Court at the same place at any other time than the regular term for the transaction and disposition of any civil or criminal business which does not require a jury, and is hereby given the authority to try any Civil or Criminal case, upon the law and facts of the same, where a jury is not required, and upon any day in the year, except Sunday, and this shall be especially done to relieve the jail, consistent with the interests of the State and of the accused, and said Judge may hold adjourned terms, or special jury terms of the regular Quarterly terms of said Court, for which he may draw new juries, or require the attendance of the same jurors, if in his discretion he sees fit to do so; provided that said jurors especially drawn for a special Quarterly Term shall have at least ten days' notice of the same, and any and all civil and criminal cases may be tried at said special or adjourned term the same as any regular quarterly term of said Court. Terms. Special terms.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That the Judge of the said City Court shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus, and to hear and dispose of the same, in the same way and with the same power as the Judge of the Superior Courts. Said
Judge shall have power to cause testimony to be taken de bene esse and used, and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction, in all cases according to the general laws of the State, and the Judge and all the officers of said City Court shall have power to administer all oaths pertaining to his respective offices as Judge and other officer of the Superior Court may, in like cases, do. And said Judge shall have power to attest deeds and other papers, and administer affidavits in all cases anywhere in the State, in which by existing laws deeds and papers may be attested and affidavits administered by Justices of the Peace of said State. And the Judge of said City Court shall have all the powers and authorities, throughout his jurisdiction, of Judges of the Superior Courts, and all laws relating to and governing Judges of the Superior Court shall apply to the said City Court, so far as the same may be applicable. Powers of judge Habeas corpus. Testimony de bene esse. Oaths. Deeds and affidavits.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That suits in said City Court shall in all respects conform to the mode or procedure in the Superior Court, except as hereinafter provided; the processes in said suits shall be annexed by the Clerk of said City Court, be attested in the name of the Judge thereof, and be directed to and served by the Sheriff of the City Court of Ludowici, or his lawful deputy; and in all matters pertaining to pleading and practice, where not inconsistent with this Act, shall be applicable to said City Court. Procedure.

Sec. 12. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Judge of said City Court is hereby given authority to hear and determine any and all cases, both civil and criminal, in said Court at any time, without a jury; provided always that either party in any case shall be entitled to trial by jury where the same is demanded, which demand may be entered at any time before the trial of said case is begun. In the event a trial by jury is not demanded, to be waived. Hearings without juries.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all judgments obtained in said City Court shall be a lien on all the property of the defendant or defendants, throughout the State, in the same manner as judgments in the Superior Courts are. All exemptions from levy and sale of property under existing laws shall apply to the said City Court processes and judgments. All executions issuing from said City Court shall be attested in the name of the Judge and signed by the Clerk, and directed to the Sheriff of said City Court and his lawful deputies, and to all the Sheriffs and their deputies in the State of Georgia. Lien on property.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That all claims to personal property levied upon under judgments, executions or processes from said City Court shall be returned to and tried in said City Court, and such claims shall be tried in the same manner as claims are tried in the Superior Courts. Claims to personal property.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws upon the subject of garnishments and attachments and illegalities filed to levies, as to any and all manner whatever in the Superior Courts of this State, shall apply to said City Court as if named with the Superior Court, so far as the nature of the City Court will admit, and said City Court is hereby vested with jurisdiction and authority to try and dispose of garnishment, attachment and illegality cases either originated in or made returnable to said City Court. And said Judge of said City Court, and all Justices of the Peace and Notaries and ex-officio Justices of the Peace of said County of Long, shall have power and authority to issue attachments, garnishments and distress warrants to said City Court when said suits are within the jurisdiction of said City Court as to amount claimed. All laws relative to issuing attachments, garnishments and distress warrants, and the return of the same, applicable to the
Superior Courts of this State, shall be applicable to the said City Court so far as the nature of said latter Court will admit, and said City Court shall have power to issue scire facias to make parties to any cause in said Court, in the same manner as provided for Superior Courts, but such scire facias shall run throughout the State, and may be served by any Sheriff or Deputy Sheriff. Attachments, garnishments. etc. Scire facias.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That the general laws of this State with regard to commencement of suits, defenses, set-offs, affidavits, illegalities, arbitration of parties to suits, examination of witnesses by depositions or interrogatories, compelling attendance of witnesses, punishing for contempt, continuances, and all other matters of a judicial nature, in the Superior Courts of this State, shall be applicable to said City Court where said matters are within the jurisdiction of said latter Court. Superior court procedure.

Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said City Court shall be a Court of Record, and shall have a seal, and the minutes, records, orders and other books and files that are required by law to be kept for the Superior Courts, shall be kept in and for said City Court, and in the same manner, and all laws applicable to the duties of the Clerk and Sheriff in said Superior Court shall apply to them in said City Court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act. And all laws regulating the enforcement of judgments of the Superior Court, both civil and criminal, shall apply to said City Court where said matters are within the jurisdiction of said City Court, and executions shall issue and be levied, and sales had thereunder, under the same rules and laws governing the same in the Superior Court. Court of record.

Sec. 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of said City Court
to prepare and file in his office a complete copy of the traverse jury list of the Superior Court of Long County, as provided from time to time for such Superior Court. From said copy so made, the traverse juries in said City Court shall be drawn in the following manner: The Clerk of the said City Court shall write upon separate tickets the name of each traverse juror, and shall number the same and place the same in a box to be prepared for that purpose, from which shall be drawn twenty-four traverse jurors, in the same manner as now provided by law in the Superior Courts. All laws with reference to the drawing, and summoning, of traverse and tales jurors in the Superior Court shall apply to the City Court, and the same rules as to exemptions from jury duty now in force in the County of Long shall apply to the said City Court, except where said rules as to drawing, summoning, and excusing said jurors conflict with this Act. All laws in reference to the qualification, empaneling, fining, challenging jurors now in force in this State, or hereafter enacted, regulating the same in the Superior Courts, shall apply to said City Court, except when inconsistent with this Act. The Judge of said City Court shall have the power to draw more than twenty-four traverse jurors, if in his discretion, same is necessary or expedient, and when said summoned jurors respond and it appears that by reason of disabilities or disqualifications, said panel of twenty-four is not full, said Court shall have power to draw and summons tales jurors to fill the same. Unless a trial by jury of twelve is demanded, a jury of six shall try civil and criminal cases. If a demand for trial by a jury of twelve is demanded, in civil cases, the plaintiff and defendant shall each have six strikes, the plaintiff striking first, and then alternately, and in event of such demand in criminal cases, the defendant shall have seven strikes and the State five, the defendant striking first and then alternately with the State until the State's strikes are exhausted,
and then the defendant proceeds to exhaust his strikes. In all cases where a demand for trial by a jury of twelve is made, a panel of twenty-four qualified jurors shall be presented. In all cases where demand is not made for a trial by twelve jurors, a panel of twelve qualified jurors shall be presented. From this panel, in civil cases, the plaintiff and defendant shall each have three strikes, the plaintiff striking first and then alternately with the defendant until their strikes are exhausted and in criminal cases the State shall have two strikes and the defendant shall have four strikes, the defendant striking first, the State next, the defendant then striking twice, the State next, and the defendant last. In all cases in said Court, either party shall have the right to demand and obtain a trial by a jury of twelve. When no such demand is made, said cases shall proceed to trial by a jury of six as herein provided. Jurors serving in said Court shall receive the same compensation as jurors serving the Superior Court of Long County. Juries are to be drawn only for the regular quarterly terms, or an adjourned quarterly term, or a specially called quarterly term. Provided, however, in criminal cases, where the defendant is unable to give bond, and demands a jury trial, that the Judge of said City Court shall have the power to draw and make up a qualified panel of jurors, at any time, in the discretion of the Court, to try said case, and in such event it shall be lawful for said City Court to convene at any time, except Sundays, and to proceed to try such case and dispose of the same, and all orders, judgments and sentences passed by said Court in connection with said case shall be lawful. Traverse juries. Panel. Qualifications, empaneling, etc. Jury of six. Jury of twelve demanded. Compensation.

Sec. 19. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That the Sheriff of said Court shall have authority to appoint such Court Bailiffs as he may need, but
not to exceed two, and said Bailiffs shall receive the same compensation as Bailiffs in the Superior Court of Long County. Bailiffs.

Sec. 20. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That the defendant in criminal cases in said City Court shall be tried on a written accusation setting forth plainly the offense charged, founded upon the affidavit of the prosecutor, and signed by the prosecutor, or by said Solicitor of said Court for him, or her, and by the Solicitor of said City Court. All proceedings after accusation shall conform to rules governing cases in the Superior Courts, except there shall be no jury trial unless demanded by the accused as hereinbefore provided, and except as to the number composing a jury where trial by jury is demanded, as hereinbefore provided, in all prosecutions on all accusations in said City Court, the offense shall be charged with the same particularity as to matter of form and substance as required by the law and rules of criminal procedure to be observed as to bills of indictment in the Superior Courts. Written accusations.

Sec. 21. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That a writ of error shall be from the said City Court of Ludowici, upon a bill of exceptions, to the Court of Appeals of Georgia, under the same rules and regulations as now control and govern in the issuing of writs of error, and filing of bills of exceptions in the Superior Courts of this State. Said City Court shall have power and authority to entertain, grant, and refuse motions for new trials in said Court under the same rules applicable to the Superior Courts of this State, except where inconsistent with this Act, and all powers and rights to waive now observed in the Superior Courts of this State are hereby delegated to parties in said City Court, and the authority to give effect to the same is hereby vested in said City Court. Writs of error. New trials.

Sec. 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all suits against joint obligors, joint promissors, co-partners or joint trespassers, in which any one or more reside in the County of Long, may be brought in said Court under the same rules and regulations governing such cases in the Superior Courts as to copies, second original, returns and other matters connected with the same. Suits against co-partners.

Sec. 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the first term of said Court to which a civil case is brought shall be the appearance or return term; the second term shall be the trial or judgment term. Provided, that in all cases where no defense is filed, judgment may be entered at the second term whether said suit was made returnable to a monthly or quarterly term irrespective of whether said second term is a monthly or quarterly term. Appearance Term.

Sec. 24. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever the Judge of said City Court is from any case disqualified to preside, and when the Superior Court Judge is not present to preside, then, upon the consent of the parties, or upon their failure to agree, the cause may be tried by a Judge pro hac vice selected in the same manner as in the Superior Courts, and, upon the absence of the Judge of the said City Court, at any term thereof, and there being present no qualified Judge to preside in said Court, the Sheriff or Clerk of said City Court may adjourn it to such term as the Judge may in writing direct, or if no direction be given, the Court may be adjourned to the next regular term. Substitutes for judge.

Sec. 25. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That moneys arising from fines and forfeitures in said Court shall be paid over to the Clerk of said Court and upon order of the Judge of said Court said money shall be divided among the Solicitor, Clerk and Sheriff of said
Court as follows: One-half of all such money to be paid to the Solicitor; one-fourth to the Clerk, and one-fourth to the Sheriff. Said money shall be applied to the payment of the insolvent cost bills of the three above named officers. Should these insolvent cost bills be paid in full at any term of said Court, or from fines and forfeitures arising from said term, and there shall be a balance on hand, the said balance shall, immediately after said term of said Court, be prorated among the Justices of the Peace and Constables according to the amount of approved insolvent cost bills said officers may have. When any defendant is sentenced to work on the chaingang or such other places as the Long County authorities may direct, for a term of four months, or longer, and actually serves his sentence, the officers of said Court and the officers of the committing Court, if there was a commitment, shall be paid their lawful costs in said case by the authorities in charge of county matters, viz.: Ordinary or Commissioners of Long County, out of any funds in their hands. Fines and forfeitures.

Sec. 26. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the county authorities of Long County shall provide a suitable place in the county court house for the holding of said Court, and to provide the necessary books for keeping the docket, minutes and records of said City Court, and provide for the preservation of the papers, books, records and minutes of said Court. Court house.

Sec. 27. Be it further enacted by the aforesaid authority, That any and all cases pending in the Superior Court of Long County may, by agreement of the parties therein, be transferred to the City Court for trial and disposition, except civil and criminal cases over which said City Court has no jurisdiction. Provided, that consent of the defendant in criminal cases over which said
City Court has jurisdiction, shall not be necessary in order that such cases may be transferred to said City Court. Transfer of pending cases.

Sec. 28. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the charter of the Town of Ludowici as set forth in the Act of 1905, Pages 962 to 970, inclusive, approved August, 1905, and an amending Act thereto set forth in these Acts of 1913, pages 959 to 972, inclusive, approved August, 1913, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking therefrom wherever the same appears in said Act the word Town used immediately before the words of Ludowici, or wherever in said Act the said word Town appears, and inserting in lieu of said word Town, the word City, so that when amended the said charter, and the amendment thereto shall read, City of Ludowici, and the corporate name of said municipality is hereby changed to City of Ludowici, by which name said municipality shall be hereafter known and designated. The powers, duties and all provisions set forth in said Acts relating to said municipality shall be of force and apply to the City of Ludowici. Ludowici charter amended. Town changed to city.
Sec. 29. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act and the provisions thereof be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MACON CITY COURT; COMPENSATION OF CLERK.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend An Act to establish the City Court of Macon, in and for the County of Bibb; to define its jurisdiction and powers; to provide for the appointment
of a Judge, and the other officers thereof, and for other purposes, approved August 14, 1885, and the Acts amendatory thereof, approved August 16, 1915, and July 24, 1920, by increasing the compensation of the Clerk of said Court, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after August 31, 1921, Section 7 of the Act creating the City Court of Macon approved August 14, 1885, as amended by Section 2 of the Act approved August 16, 1915, be amended by striking said Section 7, as the same is amended by Act approved July 24, 1920, in its entirety, and substituting in lieu thereof another section to be known as Section 7, which shall read as follows, to-wit: Acts amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 7. Be it further enacted, That there shall be a Clerk of said Court, who shall be appointed by the Judge thereof; said Clerk shall, before entering on the duties of his office, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties thereof, which oath shall be entered on the book of minutes of said Court; he shall also, before entering on the duties of his office, execute a bond with good security in the sum of three thousand ($3,000.00) dollars, conditioned to account for all money which may come into his hands as Clerk, and for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office; he shall hold his office for a term of four (4) years. Said Clerk shall receive, in lieu of fees in both civil and criminal cases, a salary of thirty-six hundred ($3,600.00) dollars per annum, to be paid monthly out of the Treasury of Bibb County by the person or persons charged by law with paying out the money of said county; and the clerk of said Court shall have power, by and with the consent of the Judge thereof, to appoint a deputy-clerk whose compensation shall be twenty-one
hundred ($2,100.00) dollars per annum, to be paid as the salary of said Clerk is paid. The provisions of this section relating to the term of office of the Clerk shall not become operative until January 1, 1925, to which date the term of office of the present incumbent is hereby extended. Clerk. Bond. Term. Salary.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Metter, in the City of Metter, in the County of Candler, approved July 29, 1920, as will be found in Georgia Laws, 1920, pages 364-378, providing for a change in the time of holding said City Court of Metter, changing the monthly terms from the second Monday in each month to the third Monday in each month, and changing the quarterly terms from the second Mondays in January, April, July and October, to the third Mondays in February, May, August and November, in each year, beginning October 15th, 1921.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act establishing the City Court of Metter, approved July 29th, 1920, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the word second from the fourth line of Section eleven of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the word third, and by striking out the words January, April, July and October,
from the sixth line of Section eleven of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the words, February, May, August and November, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Act of 1920 amended.

blockquote.p: Section 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the terms of said City Court shall be monthly and quarterly, the monthly terms to be held beginning on the third Monday in each and every month of the year, and the quarterly term to be co-incident with the monthly terms in February, May, August and November. Said City Court shall be held in the Court House of Candler County in the City of Metter and, when necessary, juries shall be drawn and served at the quarterly terms, as hereinafter provided, and all of the terms of said Court shall continue until the business of the Court is disposed of, unless adjourned for good cause. The Judge of said City Court is hereby authorized to try any criminal case coming within the jurisdiction of his Court, upon the law and the facts of the cases when a jury is not required under this Act, on any day, except Sunday, and this shall be especially done to relieve the jail of prisoners, consistent with the interests of the State and the accused, and the Judge may, in his discretion, for the trial of criminal cases in which juries are required, hold adjourned quarterly terms or special jury terms of said Court, for which he may require the attendance of the regular adjourned term juries or draw new juries; provided, that juries especially drawn shall have at least ten days' notice of the same. To be read. Terms of court.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby so enacted, That the provisions of this Act shall go into effect on the 15th day of October, 1921. Effective October 15, 1921.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: NASHVILLE CITY COURT; FINES AND FORFEITURES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating the City Court of Nashville providing for the collection of fines and forfeitures, naming a custodian and providing for disbursement of said funds.
law.p: Section 1. Be it, and it is, hereby enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, that Section 36 of Act creating the City Court of Nashville, approved July 31, 1905, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking from said Act all of Section 36 and inserting in lieu thereof, the following: Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all fines and forfeitures arising from cases tried on accusation or indictment in said City Court shall be collected by the Sheriff of said Court and by him paid into the general county fund for proper disbursement. Act of 1905 amended. Collection by sheriff.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and they are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 22, 1905, establishing the City Court of Reidsville and the Acts amendatory thereof, and to repeal the Act approved August 16, 1915, providing for the trial of all civil and criminal cases of said City Court by six jurymen and for other purposes, so as to provide for the trial of all cases in said Court by twelve jurymen, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act approved August 15, 1915, providing that all civil and criminal cases in the City Court of Reidsville be tried by a jury of only six jurymen, and providing that the salary of the Judge of said City Court of Reidsville shall be only nine hundred dollars per annum, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Act of 1915 amended.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act approved August 22, 1905, establishing the City Court of Reidsville, and the Act approved August 10, 1906, amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Acts of 1905 and 1906 amended.

That thirty-six jurors shall be drawn, summoned or empaneled, and if by reason of non-attendance or disqualification of any of said regular drawn jurors, the Judge of said Court shall direct the required number to be filled by tales jurors in the same manner as is done in the Superior Court. In all civil cases each side shall have six strikes from a panel of twenty-four, and in all criminal cases the defendant shall strike seven and the State five from said panel. Each juror shall receive the same compensation for his services as is paid to
the jurors serving in the Superior Court of Tatnall County. The trial of all civil and criminal cases in said Court shall be had by a jury of twelve jurymen, except that in any criminal case any defendant may waive trial by jury and have his case both as to law and facts tried before the Judge of said Court without a jury. Thirty-six jurors. Tales jurors. Panel. Compensation. Hearings without juries.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Judge of said City Court of Reidsville shall receive a salary of twelve hundred dollars per year, payable monthly by the County Commissioners of Tatnall County out of any funds in their hands for paying the current expenses of said county. The Judge shall receive no other compensation for his services as Judge of said Court. He shall not be permitted to practice law in his own Court, but may practice law in any other Courts. Judge's salary. Practice of law.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this Act shall take effect from and after the passage thereof. Effective on approval.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SAVANNAH CITY COURT; OFFICE OF REPORTER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the several Acts relating to and creating the City Court of Savannah, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority
of the same, That from and after the 1st day of January, 1922, there shall be appointed by the Judge of the City Court of Savannah, a competent Court Reporter, who shall be required to make a stenographic report of all criminal cases and such civil cases as the parties litigant or the Judge or ex-officio Judge may desire. The said Court Reporter to hold office during the pleasure of the Judge. Appointment.

Sec. 2. The said Court Reporter so appointed shall be paid by the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Chatham County, from the County Treasury, as an expense of the said City Court, for his services in reporting and transcribing criminal cases, the sum of $125.00 per month, and the said Court Reporter for said sum so paid, shall whenever a motion for new trial is made, or whenever so directed by the Court, transcribe the criminal testimony so taken. Compensation. Duties.

Sec. 3. Fees for reporting civil cases shall be the same as prescribed for the Clerk of the Superior Courts in counties of the population of Chatham County, and such fees shall be retained by and be the property of said Court Reporter. Fees.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to change the terms of the City Court of Swainsboro from the fourth Monday in each month to the third Monday in each month, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the terms of the City Court of Swainsboro shall be held on the third Mondays in each month. The provisions of this Act shall apply alike to the monthly and the quarterly terms of said Court, but the months for holding quarterly terms of said Court shall remain as now fixed by law. Provided, the provisions of this Act shall take effect on October 1st, 1921. Monthly and quarterly terms. Effective October 1, 1921.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SYLVANIA CITY COURT; CLERK AND SHERIFF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to establish the City Court of Sylvania in and for the County of Screven, approved December 15, 1902, as amended by an Act approved August 18, 1913, found in the Georgia Laws of 1913, commencing on Page 291 and ending on Page 308, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That an Act to amend an Act to establish the City Court of Sylvania, in and for the County of Screven, approved August 18, 1913, and as found in Georgia Laws of 1913, commencing on Page 291 and ending on Page 308, be amended by striking from said Act all of Section 8, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: Act of 1913 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 8. That there shall be a Clerk of said City Court, who shall be at least twenty-one years of age and a qualified voter of the County of Screven, and who, before
entering upon the duties of his office, shall take oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of Clerk of said Court, which oath shall be entered upon the minutes of the said City Court, and who shall give bond with good security in the sum of five hundred dollars for the faithful discharge of his duties, which bond shall be made payable to the Governor and his sucessors in office, and filed in the office of the Ordinary of said county. That all duties and liabilities devolving upon the office of the Clerk of the Superior Courts of the State of Georgia shall devolve upon the office of the Clerk of City Court of Sylvania, and the Judge of said City Court is hereby empowered to enforce the same authority over said Clerk of said City Court of Sylvania as is exercised by the Judge of the Superior Courts of the State of Georgia over the Clerk; said Clerk is hereby authorized to appoint a deputy or deputies to assist him whenever the business of his office so demands; said Clerk shall hold his office for a term of two years from appointment, and shall be appointed by the grand jury of Screven County at the November term of the Screven Superior Court preceding the expiration of each term of office; the present Clerk of said City Court shall hold office until his term of office expires; should the grand jury of Screven County fail, or refuse, to make such an appointment, then the Clerk shall hold over until a succeeding grand jury of said county shall act and make such an appointment. Should any vacancy occur in the office of said Clerk the Judge of said City Court shall fill such vacancy by appointment until the grand jury next meeting shall convene and such grand jury shall have authority to appoint a Clerk to fill such a vacancy. To be read. Clerk.

law.p:
The duties heretofore devolving upon the Sheriff of said City Court shall be performed by the Sheriff of Screven County, and his lawful deputy or deputies. Provided, that should the Sheriff of said county at any
time fail to faithfully discharge the duties of such office to the satisfaction of the Judge of said City Court, said Judge of said City Court shall have the power and authority to appoint a Sheriff of said City Court of Sylvania for such time as he shall see fit, not to exceed the balance of the term of said Sheriff of said county; provided, further, that before making such appointment the said Judge of City Court of Sylvania shall confer with the members of the bar of Sylvania, and shall only appoint such person as Sheriff of said Court who is approved by not less than a majority of the members of said bar of Sylvania. Upon the appointment of any Sheriff of said City Court by the Judge thereof, such Sheriff shall have the same power and perform the same duties as devolved upon the office of Sheriff of City Court before this amendment. Sheriff.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That this Act shall not take effect until January 1, 1922. Effective January 1, 1922.
Sec. 3. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act, approved July 31, 1918, as found in Georgia Laws for 1918, commencing on Page 343 and ending on Page 345, entitled An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Thomasville, in and for the County of Thomas; to define its jurisdiction and powers, etc., approved August 18, 1905, as amended the Act approved August 6, 1912, so as to change and fix the
salary of the Judge of said Court, and for other purposes, so that from and after the passage of this Act and until otherwise provided, the salary of the Judge of said Court shall be forty-five hundred dollars per annum, instead of, as provided by said Act of July 31, 1918, three thousand dollars, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act and until otherwise provided, the above recited Act, approved July 31, 1918, be, and the same is, hereby amended so as to change the salary of the Judge of said City Court of Thomasville from three thousand dollars per annum to forty-five hundred dollars per annum. Act of 1918 amended.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 1 of said above recited Act, approved July 31, 1918, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking therefrom the word three in the thirty-sixth line thereof, and by striking the word thousand in the thirty-seventh line thereof, and by inserting in lieu of said words the words forty-five hundred, so that said section when so amended shall be and read as follows: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the above recited Act establishing the City Court of Thomasville, approved August 18, 1905, and embodied in the Georgia Laws of 1905, pages 383 to 395, inclusive, as amended by an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 6, 1912, and embodied in the Georgia Laws of 1912, pages 313 to 315, inclusive, be and the same is hereby amended as follows: By striking from said original Act all of Section 12, and from said amendatory Act all of Section 1, and by inserting in lieu thereof and to be known as Section 12,
the following, to-wit: Section 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Judge of said Court must be at least twenty-eight years of age; must have been a resident of the County of Thomas at least three years immediately preceding his election and a practicing attorney-at-law at least five years before his election. Before entering upon the discharge of his duties he shall take and subscribe the following oath: `I do solemnly swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons, and do equally right to the poor and the rich, and that I will faithfully discharge and perform my duties, which may be required of me as Judge of the City Court of Thomasville, in the County of Thomas, of this State, according to the best of my ability and understanding, agreeable to the laws and Constitution of this State and the Constitution of the United States, so help me God.' Such oath shall be immediately forwarded to the Governor and filed in the Executive Department. Said Judge may practice law in any other court except the one provided for by this Act; he shall have authority to issue criminal warrants, to dispossess tenants holding over, and intruders; to issue distress warrants and generally to do all acts which the Judges of the county Courts are generally authorized to do, unless otherwise provided by this Act. The said Judge shall receive a salary of forty-five hundred dollars per annum, which shall be paid monthly out of the Treasury of Thomas County by the person or persons charged by law with the paying out of the money of said county. The said Judge shall have the same power to enforce his orders, preserve order and punish for contempt, and enforce laws and judgments as is vested by law in the Judges of the Superior Courts of this State. To be read. Salary.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this Act increasing the salary of the Judge of said City Court of Thomasville shall be effective immediately
upon its passage and approval until repealed by law or disapproved of by the qualified voters of Thomas County as hereinafter provided. Effective on approval.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That should as many as five hundred qualified voters of Thomas County petition the Ordinary of said county for a referendum vote as to whether or not the salary herein provided for or the old salary of said Judge shall prevail, then, and in that event, said Ordinary shall call an election under the same rules, regulations and formalities as are provided for filling a vacancy in the office of Ordinary. Petition for referendum.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That should five hundred or more voters petition as provided in the preceding section and a special election be held, those in favor of the $4,500 salary shall have marked on their ballots, For present salary of Judge, and those in favor of the $3,000 salary shall have marked on their ballots For old salary of Judge. Election.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the result of said election, if held, after consolidation, shall be certified to the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Thomas County and, should a majority of those voting cast their ballots for old salary of Judge, the salary of the Judge of the City Court of Thomasville shall be $3,000 per year from the date of the special election above referred to. Otherwise, the salary will be $4,500 per annum as above provided. Result of election.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Thomas County shall let their minutes show, and publish at least one time in a newspaper circulating in Thomas County, the result of said election, if held. Publication.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That said election shall be held during the year 1921. Time of holding.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON CITY COURT; INDICTMENTS IN CRIMINAL CASES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to establish the City Court of Washington in and for the County of Wilkes, to define its jurisdiction and powers, to provide for the election of a Judge and Solicitor thereof, and the appointment of other officers, to define their powers and duties and for other purposes, approved August 9th, 1905, by repealing that portion of said Act giving defendants in criminal cases in said City Court of Washington the right to demand indictment by the grand jury, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the above recited Act establishing the City Court of Washington be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out from Section 37 of said Act all the words of said section following the word Court in the fifth line thereof, and down to the word all following the period in the seventeenth line of said section, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Act of 1905 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 37. Be it further enacted, That defendants in criminal cases in said City Court shall be tried on written accusation setting forth plainly the offense charged, founded upon the affidavit of the prosecutor,
and signed by the Solicitor of said City Court. All the proceedings after accusation shall conform to the rules governing like cases in the Superior Court, except there shall be no trial by jury unless demanded by the accused as hereinbefore provided. In all cases tried the accusation shall set forth the offense charged with the same particularity, both as to form and substance, as is now or may hereafter be requisite by the laws and rules of criminal pleading to be observed in bills of indictment in the Superior Court. If upon the trial of any case it shall appear to the Judge that the evidence makes the case against the accused a felony, he shall thereupon suspend the trial and commit or bail over the defendant to the Superior Court as in cases of preliminary examinations. To be read. No indictments by grand jury.

law.p: Sec. 2. The provisions of this bill shall be effective only when ratified in some election in the county aforesaid, by a majority of the qualified voters thereof. Election to ratify.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act abolishing Justice Courts, the office of Justice of the Peace and Notary Public, ex-officio Justice of the Peace, and the office of Constable in the City of Macon, and to establish and create in lieu thereof a Municipal Court in the City of Macon, approved August 16, 1913, and also for the purpose of amending the Acts amending the above recited Act, approved August 19, 1918, and August 18, 1919, which
amendments were for the purpose of regulating the salaries of the officers of the Municipal Court of the City of Macon, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the above recited Act, approved August 16, 1913, and the above recited Act approved August 18, 1919, be amended by striking the words, Thirty-three hundred dollars per annum where the same occurs in Section one of said last mentioned Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the words, Thirty-six hundred dollars per annum, so that the compensation of the Judge of said Municipal Court of the City of Macon shall be and is fixed at the sum of thirty-six hundred dollars per annum. Acts of 1913 and 1919 amended. Judge's salary.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section one of the Act approved August 19, 1918, amending the original Act approved August 16, 1913, be amended by striking the words, Eighteen hundred and Eighteen hundred dollars per annum wherever they occur in said section of said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the words Nineteen hundred and eighty and Nineteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum, so that the compensation of the Clerk of the Municipal Court of the City of Macon shall be and is fixed at the sum of nineteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum. Clerk's salary.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 2 of the Act approved August 19, 1918, amending the original Act approved August 16, 1913, be amended by striking the words, Fifteen hundred and Fifteen hundred dollars per annum from said Section 2 of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the words Sixteen hundred and eighty and Sixteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum, so that the compensation
of the Deputy Clerks of said Municipal Court of the City of Macon shall be and is fixed at the sum of sixteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum each. Deputy Clerks.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 3 of the Act approved August 19, 1918, amending the original Act approved August 16, 1913, be amended by striking the words Eighteen hundred and Eighteen hundred dollars per annum from said Section 3 of said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the words. Nineteen hundred and eighty and Nineteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum, so that the compensation of the Sheriff of said Municipal Court of the City of Macon shall be and is fixed at nineteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum. Sheriff.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section four of the Act approved August 19, 1918, amending the original Act approved August 16, 1913, be amended by striking the words, Fifteen hundred dollars per annum and inserting in lieu thereof the words, Sixteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum, so that the compensation of the Deputy Sheriffs of said Municipal Court of the City of Macon shall be and is fixed at the sum of sixteen hundred and eighty dollars per annum each. Deputy sheriffs.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.
