Fifth Commissioner District to be composed of the territory embraced in Norman Park, Crosland, Ty Ty and Warrior militia districts.

law.p: Sec. 3. The present members of the Board of Commissioners of said county is hereby made the members of the new Board of Commissioners herein created and are as follows: Personnel of board.

item.p: First Commissioner District, S. W. Prince.
Second Commissioner District, Dr. J. H. Green.
Third Commissioner District, H. C. King.
Fourth Commissioner District, W. C. May.
Fifth Commissioner District, Dr. J. H. Hall.

law.p: The said members of the Board of Commissioners shall hold their offices, unless removed by death, resignation or otherwise, until January 1st, 1923, at which time their successors, as hereafter provided shall begin their terms. Term.

At the general election in the year, 1922, and every two years thereafter, there shall be elected one Commissioner from each of the five commissioner districts. Said commissioners shall be residents of the districts they are elected to represent and shall be otherwise qualified to hold a county office under existing laws. They shall be elected by the qualified voters of their respective commissioner districts. Election of successors.

Sec. 4. Each Commissioner before entering upon the duties of his office shall give a good and sufficient bond to be approved by the Ordinary of said County payable to the County of Colquitt in the sum of One Thousand Dollars conditioned that he will faithfully discharge the duties of his office and will account to the county for any misappropriation participated in by him of any of the public funds passing under the control of said Board. They shall be commissioned by the Governor upon giving bond as hereinbefore prescribed and taking the usual civil oath, provided however, when a Commissioner is elected to fill a vacancy as hereinafter provided, said commissioner upon taking the oath and signing his bond shall enter at once on the discharge of his duties as Commissioner and shall be allowed thirty days in which to have his commission issued in compliance with this section. Bond.

Sec. 5. Should a vacancy occur on said Board, it shall be the duty of the Ordinary of said County to call a special election in the Commissioner District where the vacancy exists within five days after the vacancy shall become known to him and said special election shall be held from fifteen to twenty days after the call. The election
shall be advertised in the official organ of said county at least two times before the election shall be held and the Ordinary shall, if he deems necessary, have notices posted in the district where the vacancy is to be filled and at the Court House in said county, in order that the election shall be well known to the voters in the district. On the day following the special election the Chairman of the Board, or if for any reason the Chairman cannot act or there is no Chairman, then the Ordinary, shall call the surviving members together in an extra session and the Board thus assembled shall canvas the returns of the special election, declare the results and the Commissioner thus elected shall sign a bond as hereinbefore provided, take the usual civil oath and enter at once on the discharge of his duties as a member of the Board of Commissioners. Vacancies.

Sec. 6. The Board of Commissioners shall elect one of their number as Chairman and the Chairman so elected shall be the chief executive officer of said Board, and before entering on the discharge of his duties as Chairman, he shall give bond in the sum of Twenty Thousand Dollars, said bond to be approved by the other four members of the Board of Commissioners and by the Ordinary of said county and be recorded in the office of the Ordinary, conditioned that he will faithfully perform all the duties incumbent upon him as Chairman and by virtue of his office, and will faithfully account for all funds coming into his hands and passing under his control or expended by virtue of his direction. Said Chairman shall have entire charge of the road working gangs and shall be superintendent of the road work as directed by the Board. He shall be the purchasing agent of said county but all purchases made by him shall be subject to the ratification of a majority of the members of the Board and when any purchases of property other than supplies for stock, hands and convicts, should such purchase involve more than One Hundred Dollars, the said
Chairman shall bring to the attention of the Board the necessity of making said purchase and bids shall be submitted to the Board at its regular meeting or at a special meeting called by the Chairman for the purpose of considering the purchase of needed property. Purchases of less amounts than One Hundred Dollars and the purchase of supplies for stock, hands and convicts may be made by the Chairman without being ratified in advance by the Board, but all purchases of the Chairman, of whatever nature, involving the expenditure of the county funds, shall be called and passed on by the Board of Commissioners in open session. The Chairman shall be charged with seeing that all money expended by the Board is properly and lawfully expended and in accordance with the purpose to which it was intended and ordered expended by the said Board. All county warrants and orders for the payment of money out of the county funds, shall be signed by the Chairman. The Chairman shall give his entire time to the handling of the affairs of the county and to superintending the road work and other work of the county. Chairman. Bond. Authority.

Sec. 7. The Chairman shall keep and maintain an office open every day except on Sunday and legal holidays, at the Court House of said county and to this end, the Board of Commissioners may appoint a Clerk to keep the office open, which Clerk shall keep the minutes and a full record of the proceedings of the Board; keep a full financial record under the direction of the Board and to attend to all other matters that may be required by the Board in connection with said office. The Clerk shall receive a salary to be fixed by the Board not to exceed $75.00 per month. The Board shall be ultimately responsible for the conduct or misconduct of the Clerk and it shall be their duty to see that the Clerk faithfully performs the work of the office. The Clerk shall hold
office at the discretion of the Board and may be discharged at will by them for neglect of duties or incompetency. Office. Clerk.

Sec. 8. The members of the Board, other than the Chairman shall receive as compensation for their services Five Dollars per day for each day's actual service in attendance on the meetings of the Board or while looking after other business of the county under authority of the Board. The Chairman shall receive as compensation for his services the sum of One Hundred Dollars per month, payable out of the county treasury, conditioned upon his devoting his entire time to the discharge of his duties as Chairman; otherwise such salary as the remaining members of the Board shall agree to pay him. Compensation. Chairman.

Sec. 9. The Board of Commissioners shall have authority to employ a county attorney whose duties shall be to advise the Board and its Chairman on all legal matters coming before them and to represent the county in all matters pending in the courts when the county is a party. Said attorney shall be appointed for a term not to exceed four years, and at such compensation as the Board may agree upon. Whenever it is deemed necessary, the Board may appoint additional counsel to assist the county attorney. County attorney.

Sec. 10. The Board shall have authority to employ a county physician for the purpose of giving medical attention to the prisoners, convicts and paupers, and in any other matters requiring the service of a physician in the administration of which the Board of Commissioners stand charged. In the employing of the county physician, the Board may, in their discretion, more definitely fix and outline his duties, and shall name the amount of his compensation. Physician.

Sec. 11. All process, original, reissue or final, and citations and notices issued by or on behalf of said Board, shall be signed either by the Chairman of the
Board or by the Clerk under the test of the Chairman except in cases where the general law otherwise provides. Process, how signed.

Sec. 12. Said Board of Commissioners shall hold monthly sessions at the Court House in said county on the first Tuesday in each month. The Board shall have the right to hold special and adjourned sessions when, in their discretion, the business of the county may require. Special sessions are to be called by the Chairman or by a majority of the Board. Three members of the Board shall constitute a quorum at any regular and special session, but three members shall concur on any matter requiring official action, regardless of the number present at the meeting. Sessions. Quorum.
Sec. 13. The members of the Board of Commissioners shall be exempt from jury duty and military service during their term of office. Exemption from jury duty and military service.

Sec. 14. The said Board of Commissioners are given the following powers and charged with the following duties, but this enumeration is not intended to change any other powers and duties which they otherwise would have or which is given them in Section 1 of this Act. It shall be their powers and duties: To manage and make contracts relative to county property, county funds and other things due and belonging to the county; to institute and defend suits on behalf of the county; to levy such general and special taxes as may be lawfully laid for county purposes; to borrow money to be used for county purposes on credit of the county, in such cases as money may be lawfully borrowed; to supervise, control and manage the establishing and maintaining of all public roads, bridges and turnpikes, including the right to appoint all overseers, guards and all other officers necessary to carry on the work of the county; to buy all machinery, implements, livestock and other things necessary
for the work; to establish, maintain and work chaingangs; to establish, alter and change precincts and militia districts; to audit all claims against the county; to employ auditors to audit the records of the various offices of the county, have same published; to establish and maintain a county farm for the home of paupers and for raising supplies for the county chaingang and paupers and to make other provisions for paupers; to have jurisdiction over all county buildings; to promote public health as provided by law when they deem it necessary; to grant and refuse such licenses as county authorities have a right to grant or refuse and to have full and complete jurisdiction over all county matters. Powers. Contracts. Suits. Taxes. Borrowing. Roads, etc. Implements. Chaingangs. Audits. Paupers. Health. Licenses.

Sec. 15. The commutation tax of said county shall be collected by the Tax Collector of Colquitt County, in the same manner and at the same time that the regular State and County taxes are collected and shall be paid over to the Treasurer of Colquitt County or the said tax may, in the discretion of the Board of Commissioners, be collected by some other person that the Board may designate, provided that the said commutation tax shall be collected annually and the person or persons making the collection shall receive, in addition to the compensation allowed the Tax Collector for making collection of other tax, such amount as may be agreed on by the Board. Commutation tax.

Sec. 16. In the expenditure and distribution of the commutation tax, the Board of Commissioners shall expend in each militia district the amount of commutation tax paid by that district. This pro rata distribution of commutation tax shall not affect or in any way apply to the disbursement or distribution of other taxes of said county collected for road purposes, but that all the other taxes shall be expended under the direction and discretion of the Board of Commissioners as provided. The Board, in their discretion, may appoint one or more
persons in each militia district to collect the commutation tax and expend same, together with any other funds that may be given them by the Board, in making repairs to bridges, mending washouts and patching roads or other needed repairs too small to command the attention of the regular road working force. Such local Road Commissioners thus appointed shall keep a fair account of the money collected and paid them by the Board, the manner in which it was expended and file a report of same with the Board of Commissioners. Pro rata distribution. Local commissioners.
Sec. 17. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled, An Act to create a Board of County Commissioners for the County of Crisp, to prescribe the duties and powers thereof, and for other purposes. Approved August 6th, 1908, by prescribing more clearly and definitely, the duties and powers of said Board of County Commissioners with reference to taxation and the fiscal affairs of said County, to fix the compensation of the members of said Board of Commissioners, and conferring upon said Board such additional jurisdiction, power and authority, in all county matters, not conferred by the original Act, and not specially herein enumerated, as is conferred by law upon the Ordinaries of the several counties of this State, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same;

Section 1. That Section 8 of the Act referred to in the caption hereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking out the words, and such other things as are usual under the laws of this State, occurring at the end of said section, and substituting in lieu thereof the following: to levy a general tax for general purposes and a special tax for special purposes, according to law; to examine, settle and allow, according to law, all claims of whatsoever nature, that may arise against the County, to examine and audit the books and accounts of all officers having the care, custody, management, collection or disbursement of money belonging to the county, or money appropriated for its use and benefit, and bringing such officers to settlement and enforcing the same; to employ public accountants, or other competent assistance, in the examination and audit of all books and records kept, as required to be kept, by all county officers; to fix the compensation of the jailor, or sheriff of said county for feeding and dieting the prisoners; to relieve any person or corporation from double tax, if, in their judgment, the ends of justice so require; to make rules and regulations in accordance with law for the promotion of health; to allow the insolvent tax list for said county; to elect and appoint all minor officials for said county when an election is not otherwise provided for by law, and by provisions of this Act; and to exercise all of the powers, and perform all of the duties vested by law in the Ordinaries of the State, when sitting for county purposes, and not herein specifically enumerated, so that said Section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1908 amended.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said Commissioners shall have direct control of all matters now vested
in the Ordinary as relates to roads, bridges, public buildings, property, misdemeanor convicts, management of county jails and its fees, control and support of paupers, to levy a general tax for general purposes and a special tax for special purposes, according to law, to examine, settle and allow according to law, all claims of whatsoever nature that may arise against the county, to examine and audit the books and accounts of all officers having the care, custody, management, collection or disbursement of money belonging to the county, or money appropriated for its use and benefit and bringing such officers to settlement and enforcing the same, to employ public accountants or, other competent assistance in the examination and audit of all books and records kept, as required to be kept, by all county officers; to fix the compensation of the jailor or sheriff of said County for feeding and dieting the prisoners; to relieve any person, or corporation from double tax, if, in their judgment, the ends of justice so require, to make rules and regulations in accordance with law for the promotion of health, to allow the insolvent tax list of said county, to elect and appoint all minor officials for said county, not otherwise provided for by law, and by provisions of this Act, and to exercise all of the duties, vested by law in the Ordinaries of this State, when sitting for county purposes, and not herein specifically enumerated. To be read. Authority of commissioners.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 7 of said Act above referred to be amended by striking out the whole of said section and substituting in lieu thereof the following:

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Commissioners shall receive as compensation for their services, to be paid from County funds, the sum of $300.00 per annum, payable monthly, provided the Chairman of said Board of Commissioners shall receive a salary of $400.00 per annum, payable monthly,
and in addition thereto, they shall be reimbursed for any actual and necessary expense incurred by them when traveling exclusively in the interest of the County, in their capacity of Commissioners. Compensation.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the provisions of this Act with reference to the salary of said Commissioners, shall become effective on the first day of Sept., 1921. All other provisions hereof shall become effective, from and after the passage of this Act. Effective Sept. 1, 1921.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of General Assembly, approved August 19th, 1912, entitled An Act to create the office of Commissioner of Roads and Revenues in and for Dodge County, provide the methods of the election of such officer, prescribe his duties and powers, fix his salary and term of office, provide for the management of county affairs and for other purposes, so as to provide that said Commissioner shall give a bond with or in any solvent surety or guarantee company, to be approved by the Ordinary of said County, payable to the Governor of said State and his successors, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of
this Act that Section 2 of the Act above quoted be amended by inserting after the word company in the 8th line of said Section, the following: Act of 1912 amended.

Provided if said Commissioner shall give bond in a surety or guarantee company, same shall be paid for by said County, and said Commissioner shall draw his warrant upon the funds of said County for the premium on said bond. So that said Section when amended shall read as follows:

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioner as herein provided, shall be commissioned by the Governor of said State for the term of office for which he is elected and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of said office shall subscribe to the oath now required by law of county officers, and shall give bond in a solvent surety or guarantee company, to be approved by the Ordinary of said county, payable to the Governor of said State and his successors in office, in the sum of Fifty Thousand ($50,000.00) Dollars, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such Commissioner. Provided, if said Commissioner shall give bond in a surety or guarantee company, same shall be paid for by said County and said Commissioner shall draw his warrant upon the funds of said County for the premium of said bond. To be read. Bonds in surety companies.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DOUGHERTY TREASURER'S OFFICE ABOLISHED; DEPOSITORY CREATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to abolish the office of County Treasurer of Dougherty County, Georgia, and to provide in what manner all funds of said County realized from taxes and all other sources shall be received, deposited and disbursed; to provide for the appointment of a County Depository or County Desopitories, for the funds of said County; to prescribe the duties and liabilities of such Depository or Depositories; to provide for the appointment of some person to act in lieu of such Depository when necessary, and to fix his salary, duties and liabilities; to provide the duties of the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said County relative to the objects of this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, 1922, the office of County Treasurer of Dougherty County, Georgia, shall be abolished, and said office from and after that date shall cease to exist. Office abolished. January 1, 1922.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said Dougherty County, shall, by a majority vote taken among themselves, select some duly incorporated bank or banks in said county to act as depository or depositories and disbursing agent or agents of and for the public funds of said County. Any bank or banks now or hereafter in business in Albany, Georgia, when and while so selected and appointed by said Commissioners are hereby designated as depositories and disbursing agents for county funds. Said Commissioners shall select the bank as such depository and disbursing agent which makes
the highest bid for the County funds in the form of an offer to pay interest on the daily balance of the funds of the County. If no bank offers to pay interest, then said County Commissioners shall, in their discretion, select one of said banks to act under the terms of this Act. If all the banks in said county refuse to serve under this Act, then and in that event only shall said Commissioners appoint a person to act as hereinafter provided. Selection of bank.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no bank or banks which may be designated as such depository or depositories and disbursing agent or agents shall receive any compensation for acting as such. No compensation.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no such bank shall be allowed to act as such depository and disbursing agent until it shall have given a bond signed by at least two amply solvent persons or by some good surety company, or both, in the sum of at least fifty thousand dollars, payable to said commissioners and their successors in office, conditioned for the safe keeping and accounting for all funds that may come into its custody by reason of its acting as such depository and for the faithful performance of all the duties pertaining to said depository; said bond to be approved by said County Commissioners. It shall be within the power of said Commissioners to call upon said bank to increase the amount of or to strengthen said bond at any time they may deem necessary, and in default of the same being done, to revoke the appointment of such bank as depository and disbursing agent. Bond.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of any bank acting as such depository and disbursing agent: Duties.

item.p:
1. To pay without delay, when in funds of the county, all orders or warrants issued by said Commissioners or
by their authority when presented for payment. The responsibility for the legality of such orders or warrants is placed on said Commissioners; Payments.
2. To take a receipt on each order when paid and carefully file it away; Receipts.

3. To keep a well bound book in which shall be entered all receipts, stating when received, from whom, and on what account, and all amounts paid out, stating when paid, to whom and on what account; Records.

4. To keep a well bound book in which shall be entered a full description of all county orders or warrants or other forms of indebtedness, as they are presented; and to record a copy of the order of the county authorities levying county taxes;

5. To collect and receive from all officers and others all county funds. and to receive, hold and disburse according to law all funds which a county treasurer might have heretofore received, held or disbursed; County funds.

6. To render reports to and to appear before said commissioners whenever notified, and to appear before any Grand Jury, on request, to render an account of its actings and doings as such depository and disbursing agent, and to exhibit its books and vouchers as such depository and disbursing agent whenever notified; Reports.
7. To perform all other duties essential to the proper conduct of the county's affairs which it has been necessary heretofore for the county treasurer to perform. Other duties.

law.p:
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Commissioners shall have the power and authority to prescribe from time to time other reasonable duties and regulations for the government of said depositories and disbursing agents, and said depositories
and disbursing agents shall be just as much bound to observe the same as they are bound to observe those prescribed in this Act. Regulations by commissioners.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Commissioners shall appoint such depository and disbursing agent or depositories and disbursing agents who shall give bond as herein provided, on or before the day this Act shall go into effect, and the County Treasurer of said County, then in office, shall on the day this Act shall go into effect deliver to such depository, or depositories as he may be directed by said Commissioners, all county funds then in his hands, and he shall at the same time deliver to said Commissioners or to the depository or to the authority designated by them, all records, books, and papers that he may have pertaining to his office. After Jannuary 1, 1922, all parties heretofore required by law to pay over to the County Treasurer funds of said County, including the Tax Collector of said County, shall pay over such funds to the depository so selected by said Board of Commissioners, and payment to said depository shall be as legal payment as when heretofore made to County Treasurer. Delivery of books and papers.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case said Commissioners shall be unable to get a bank in said County to become such depository and disbursing agent, or in case it should come to pass that there should be no chartered bank in said County, then said Commissioners shall have the authority to appoint some person as receiving and disbursing agent who is a resident of said County, whose duties and liabilities shall be the same as now required of County Treasurers in Georgia, and said person so appointed shall give bond to the Ordinary of said County for the faithful performance of his duties, with security or securities to be approved by said Ordinary in a sum named by said Commissioners, but not less than Fifty Thousand Dollars.
The compensation of said person shall be fixed by the said Board of Commissioners, but in no event shall it exceed the sum of six hundred dollars per annum, and said salary or compensation shall be paid out of the funds of said County. All records necessary for him in the performance of his duties shall also be provided by said Commissioners out of the county funds. In the event a surety company bond is required of him, the premium on the same shall also be paid out of the county's funds by order of said Commissioners. The paying of the bond premium and the furnishing of records as set out above applies only in the event it is necessary to select some person to act as said depository and disbursing agent. If a bank is found to act as such, it shall not charge to the county its bond premium, nor its expense in procuring the necessary records and the keeping of the same. Receiving and disbursing agent.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the term of such depository and disbursing agent shall be for a period of four years from January 1, 1922, and thereafterwards shall expire at the end of each four year period, but shall extend by operation of law until a successor is appointed and qualified. For non-feasance or malfeasance in office any bank or person performing the duties under this Act may be removed by said Commissioners at any time and a successor appointed. Any person desiring to call the attention of said Commissioners to any non-feasance or mal-feasance in office of said depository and disbursing agent, shall do so in writing and shall serve a copy on said depository and disbursing agent five days before the hearing set by said Commissioners. Term. Removal for mal-feasance.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said depository and disbursing agent, or depositories and disbursing agents, shall be liable both civilly and criminally just as County Treasurers are now
liable civilly and criminally for any non-feasance, misfeasance, or mal-feasance of duty, and said Commissioners shall have the right to proceed against such depository and disbursing agent, or depositories and disbursing agents, and the security or securities on their bonds in the same manner as the Ordinary may now proceed against a County Treasurer and his securities in case of non-feasance, mis-feasance or mal-feasance in the conduct of his offices. Liability.
Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal An Act entitled an Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Douglas County, and for other purposes, approved Dec. 20th, 1900, with all the amendments thereto, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section. 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That an Act entitled An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of the County of Douglas, to define their duties and powers, fix their compensation, and for other purposes, approved Dec. 20th, 1900, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Act of 1900 repealed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this Act shall not go into effect until the Act
creating a County Commissioner for Douglas County is ratified by a vote of the people of Douglas County as provided for in House Bill No. 54. Effective on commissioner's establishment.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a County Commissioner of Roads and Revenues of Douglas County, Georgia; to provide for the election of the same; to define his powers and duties; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this act, Douglas County shall have one Commissioner of Roads and Revenues whose term of office shall be for two years, provided, however, the Commissioner to be appointed by this Act shall hold office until the convening of the grand jury for the County of Douglas, in September, 1921, they to have the authority to elect a Commissioner or call an election for one to be held on the second Wednesday in December, 1921. The Commissioner selected shall hold office until January 1st, 1923, and shall be elected thereafter at the same time representatives in the General Assembly are elected. Establishment. Term. Election.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Commissioner shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to-wit:
In directing and controlling all of the property of the county as he may deem expedient, according to law; in levying the taxes according to law; in establishing, altering and abolishing roads, bridges and ferries in conformity to law; in establishing, abolishing and changing election precincts and militia districts; in supervising the Tax Collector's and Tax Receiver's books and allowing the insolvent lists for said county; in settling all claims against the county; examining and auditing all claims or accounts of officers having the care and management, keeping, collecting or disbursement of money belonging to the county or appropriated for its use and benefit and bringing such officers to a settlement; in making such rules and regulations for the support of the poor as is consistent with law; in regulating peddling, issuing orders and to have and exercise the usual powers now granted by law to the Courts of Ordinary when sitting for county purposes and transacting business of like character; to require all tax fi. fa. that have been issued by mistake or against the wrong parties or such as are otherwise valueless to be cancelled and filed in the office of the Ordinary; to have the proper officer make up a list of all other fi. fa. for taxes uncollected when they have been allowed the Tax Collectors as insolvent, such list when so made up to be filed in the office of the Ordinary, subject to the inspection of any citizen of the county; to compel and require the County Treasurer to make quarterly returns to him, showing the amount collected and from whom, and showing the amounts paid out and to whom, also showing the amount of the different and distinct funds of said county and said county's total indebtedness, with authority in said Commissioner to compel such county officers to produce their books to him in auditing and passing on such accounts. Said Commissioner shall. in his discretion require such statements to be made under oath of such officer, and in default of such officer so handling the county funds, and
to make such showing and return to said Commissioner as above provided for, said Commissioner is hereby vested with authority to declare the office of such officer vacant and to order an election to fill such vacancy as provided by law; to require a like showing and statement from the Tax Collector of said county, in default of such showing to be dealt with in like manner as provided above for Treasurer. Jurisdiction.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioner shall have a meeting on the first Tuesday in each month, and the Ordinary of said county to be clerk and adviser to said Commissioner, and shall hold office during the term of the Commissioner. Meetings.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That P. H. Winn and R. M. Johnston are hereby appointed as an advisory board to the Commissioner who shall meet with him at his regular meeting, quarterly and shall publish a report of the financial condition of the county. Said advisory board to be elected same time as the Commissioner and for the same length of time. Advisory board.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the County Commissioner shall be engaged, at least five days in each week, looking after the roads and other county business, for which he shall receive a salary of twelve hundred ($1,200) dollars per annum with use of county truck and gasoline while on county duty. He shall employ a warden who shall not receive more than one hundred ($100.00) dollars per month; and the Ordinary in his capacity as clerk and advisor to said Commissioner shall not receive more than $250.00 per year. And the other two members of the advisory board shall not receive more than three ($3.00) dollars per day for their services. Compensation. Warden. Ordinary. Advisers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before said Commissioner shall assume office he shall give good and sufficient bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars, to be approved by the Ordinary as all other county officers' bonds are approved; and shall also take and subscribe the oath prescribed for other county officers for the faithful performance of their duties as such, before the Ordinary of said county. Bond.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, The Commissioner shall be a person qualified to keep correct accounts; and who shall make settlement with the former Commissioner and receive from them any monies they had belonging to the county or for overdrawn salaries. Accounts.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, The Commissioner shall not make any debt beyond the revenues of the county for the current year without the consent of the advisory board in this Act created. Incurring of debts.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That W. J. Dorris is hereby appointed County Commissioner to hold the office as provided for in this Act. W. J. Dorris appointed.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Ordinary of Douglas County is hereby directed to call an election not later than 60 nor less than 30 days from the passage of this Act. At said election if a majority of the voters of Douglas County vote for the passage of same, then this Act to become effective. If a majority of the voters vote against the passage of this Act, then the same is not to take effect. That in said election those desiring to vote in favor of said bill shall place upon their ballots For the Act creating one Commissioner of Roads and Revenues. Those
desiring to vote against said bill shall place upon their ballots Against the Act creating one Commissioner of Roads and Revenues. Election to ratify.
Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Effingham to be elected by the qualified voters of said county, to define the duties of said Commissioners, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, there shall be created and established a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Effingham in the State of Georgia, consisting of five persons who shall be elected by the qualified voters of said county at the general election held in the year 1924, and at each subsequent alternate general election, which election shall be held under the rules, regulations and laws governing the election of county officers in the County of Effingham and said five persons shall possess the qualifications of being resident freeholders of said county for at least five years prior to said election, shall be at least thirty years of age and eligible to election as a member of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia. Board of five created. Election. Eligibility.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the five Commissioners thus elected shall be commissioned by the Governor of said State, and shall qualify and take oath of office before the Ordinary of said County of Effingham and the term of said Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues shall be four years, as in the past. Term.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That when a vacancy shall occur in the membership of said Board, such vacancy may be filled by a majority of votes of all the remaining members of said Board of Commissioners for a suitable person to fill said vacancy for the unexpired term until the general election, at which the members of said Board of Commissioners are to be regularly elected. Vacancies.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That each of said Commissioners of Roads and Revenues shall be paid $4.00 (four dollars) per day for each day that they actually serve and are sitting for county purposes. Compensation.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the said Board of Commissioners shall hold their regular sessions on the first Tuesday in each month, in the office of the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of the County of Effingham, and they shall be authorized to call extra sessions at any other time for county purposes, when an emergency or the necessity arises. Sessions.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That not less than three of said Commissioners shall constitute a quorum of said Board, and when only three are present, it shall require a unanimous concurrence to pass an order, transact any business or take any other action in regard to any county matter, and when four of said Commissioners meet and are equally divided in their opinion on any question, the decision shall be postponed until a full Board of five members can be had, three votes being necessary to decide any question. Quorum. Orders.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the said Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues shall qualify and sign the oath of office required by law in the presence of the Ordinary of said County of Effingham, and when said oaths are thus signed and attested they shall be recorded upon the minutes of the Ordinary and the necessary certificate shall be forwarded to the Governor of said State, or the officer directed by law to receive same. Oath of office.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the said Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said county shall have original and exclusive jurisdiction over the following subject matter, to-wit: Jurisdiction.

item.p: First, in directing and controlling all of the property of said county as they may deem expedient according to law, including the Court House, the jail and the pauper and county farms. Property.
Second, in levying a general tax for general purposes and a special tax for special purposes according to law. Taxes.
Third, in establishing, working, altering or abolishing all public roads, bridges and ferries, in conformity with the law. Roads and bridges.
Fourth, in establishing and changing election precincts and militia districts. Precincts and districts.
Fifth, in examining, settling and allowing all claims against said county duly authorized by law. Claims.

Sixth, in examining and auditing the accounts of all officers, having the care, management, keeping, collecting or disbursement of money belonging to the county, or appropriated for its use and benefit, and bringing them to a settlement. Accounts.
Seventh, in making such rules and regulations for the support of the poor of the county, for the promotion of health, as are granted by law or not inconsistent therewith. Regulations.

Eighth, to exercise such powers as are indispensable to a proper exercise of their jurisdiction; each and all of the above stated powers to be exercised in strict conformity to law as now existing or hereafter enacted. Other powers.

law.p:
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the said Board of Commissioners shall have authority to employ annually a superintendent for the public roads of said county, at a reasonable salary, to be fixed by said Board and that said superintendent shall be required to give bond with good security in an amount to be designated by said Board and payable to said Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said county and their successors in office, for the faithful discharge of the duties of such superintendent, and for the proper handling of the property and funds of the county that may come into his possession as superintendent aforesaid. That said superintendent, the road overseers and guards shall be under the control and direction of said Board of Commissioners and in conformity to the rules and laws of the Prison Commission and the State law, and that said Board shall have authority to discharge or remove any of them from office as in their judgment they shall deem best for the best interest of the management of the affairs of said county. The said superintendent shall be required by said Board to keep a correct and accurate account of all the funds and moneys collected by him and from whom or what source received and to whom paid, and make such other reports as said Board of Commissioners shall require of him or deem necessary for the proper understanding of the business transacted by him and of how much money has been collected and paid out each month. All books, records,
statements of accounts, vouchers and other papers shall be kept separate from the other records in the Commissioners' office. Road super intendent.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the said Board of Commissioners shall have authority to relieve any persons or corporations from double taxes, if in their judgment, the same should be done and that they shall have no authority to correct or change any tax returns or refund any tax money that shall have been paid by any person or corporation who shall be liable for taxes due the county or State. Relief from double taxes.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the Board of Commissioners is authorized to employ a clerk, at a reasonable salary per month, to be paid by said Board of Commissioners out of the County Treasury. The clerk shall keep on file in his office a book of minutes upon which he shall enter all the proceedings of said Board of Commissioners, a road book and a book to enter all vouchers passed for payment, also any other records or papers as may be required by said Board of Commissioners. Clerk.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That said clerk shall keep on file in the Commissioners' office the old tax digests of Effingham County and the new tax digests that shall be delivered each year to the Board of County Commissioners by the Tax Receivers of said county, the clerk of said Board of Commissioners shall be paid fifty cents for each certified tax return or other extracts from the tax books of said county by persons desiring said certified tax return or other extracts from the tax books of said county. Tax records.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the clerk of said Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said county to furnish all parties, upon demand, with exemplifications
and transcripts of the papers and records of said Court of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues, and, for such service, he shall be authorized to make the same charges as the Clerk of the Superior Court does for like service, which shall be in addition to the regular salary paid him. Transcripts of records, etc.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the clerk of the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues shall be allowed the same fees for issuing warrants against road defaulters as is allowed from Courts of Justice of the Peace. These fees being allowed in addition to his regular salary. Fees.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That the present Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said county which have been elected, appointed and commissioned by the Governor under the Act of 1872, viz.: Preston J. Ziegler, William R. Fetzer, Orville A. Rahn, Christopher W. Edwards and James W. Tebeau, are qualified to serve the full term of their commissions with all the rights, benefit, power and authority given to a Board elected under this Act. Present board to serve full term.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this bill be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled Elbert Board of Commissioners, Bond Committee, approved August 14, 1919, by adding thereto a section to be known as Section 2, in lieu of the section now known as Number 2,
requiring the Bond Commissioners of Elbert County to make and publish semi-annually or by January 5th and July 5th, of each and every year, a sworn statement, fully and completely itemized of the financial condition of Elbert County, and within fifteen days after this bill becomes a law to make and publish such sworn statement from January 1st, 1921, to July 1st, 1921, the publication to be in the newspaper in Elbert County wherein are published the Sheriff's advertisements; to provide a penalty for the failure to do so; and to add thereto a section to be known as Section 3, for the repeal of all conflicting laws, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 2. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Bond Commissioners of Elbert County shall make and publish semi-annually on or by January 5th and July 5th of each and every year in the newspaper in Elbert County wherein are published the Sheriff's advertisements, a full, complete, itemized, sworn statement of the receipts and disbursments made by it for and in behalf of Elbert County. Semi-annual publication.
Sec. 3. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to provide Board of Commissioners for the County of Elbert, approved February 27th, 1875, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, by striking Section nine of the
amendatory Act of 1913, approved August 11, 1913, and inserting in lieu thereof a section to be known as Section nine requiring the Commissioners to make and publish semi-annually on or by January 5th and July 5th of each and every year, a sworn, full, complete, itemized financial statement of Elbert County and within fifteen days after this bill becomes a law to make and publish such sworn statements from January 1st, 1921, to July 1st, 1921, the publication to be in the newspaper in Elbert County wherein are published the Sheriff's advertisements; to provide a penalty for failure to do so, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, the Act of 1875 providing a Board of Commissioners for the County of Elbert, approved February 27th, 1875, and as amended by the several Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out Section nine of the amendatory Act of 1913 providing for posting quarterly at the Court House door statement of receipts and disbursements of the Commissioners, approved August 11, 1913, and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be known as Section 9: Act of 1913 amended.

Section 9. Be it further enacted, That said Commissioners shall make and publish semi-annually, on or by January fifth and July fifth of each and every year, in the newspaper in Elbert County wherein are published the Sheriff's advertisements, a full, complete, itemized, sworn statement of the recepits and disbursements of Elbert County. Within fifteen days after the approval of this Act said Commissioners shall also make and publish such financial statement of Elbert County from January first, 1921, to July first, 1921. Failure to comply with this Act or any part thereof shall immediately create a vacancy in the office of said Commissioner
which shall be filled at an election called by the Ordinary of the county, to be held within twenty days after the vacancy occurs, the successor to fill the unexpired term. Semi-annual publication. First statement for 1921.
Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Evans; to provide for the election of members thereof by the qualified voters of said county; to provide for Commissioners for said county until the first election under this law; to define all their powers and duties; and for other purposes, approved August 16, 1915, as amended by an Act approved August 16, 1920; so as to provide that the Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said county shall be paid for not more than fifty (50) days' service each during any one year.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That section fifteen of the above entitled Act, approved August 16, 1915, as amended by an Act approved August 16, 1920, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking the word Fifteen from the fifth line of said Section fifteen of said Act approved August 16, 1915, and from the fourteenth line of Section one of said amendatory Act approved August 16, 1920, and inserting in lieu thereof in each of said instances as aforesaid the word and figures Fifty (50) between the words
Than and Days in each of said instances; so that said Section fifteen of said Act approved August 16, 1915, as amended by said amendatory Act approved August 16, 1920, when so amended shall read as follows: Acts of 1915 and 1920 amended.

blockquote.p: Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That members of the Board of Commissioners herein created shall receive as their compensation four ($4.00) dollars a day for each day of actual service; provided, that no Commissioner shall be paid for more than fifty (50) days' service during any one year, and that he shall spend as much as one day in each month in each militia district looking after the roads and bridges of said district. The said Commissioners shall elect a clerk of said Board whose duty it shall be to keep a record of the actings and doings of the Board at the Court House in said county, said records to be opened to the inspection of any citizen of said county at all times if the same do not conflict with the meetings of the Board, and he shall perform such other duties as may be assigned him by said Board, and he shall keep all the books and records of his office in a neat, first-class and business-like condition at all times. He shall receive compensation for all his duties as such clerk in the amount of not exceeding fifty ($50.00) dollars per month. Said clerk shall not be a member of said Board of Commissioners. The said Commissioners shall at their first meeting elect a Chairman of said Board from their own membership, who shall act as such Chairman during the entire time of said Board. Said Commissioners before entering upon their duties as such shall take an oath before the Ordinary for the faithful performance of their duties. To be read. Payment for fifty days' service.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: FAYETTE COUNTY; INMAN SCHOOL DISTRICT ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act entitled an Act to repeal an Act entitled An Act to incorporate the Inman School District, in Fayette County; to define the boundaries of the same; to regulate the management of the school in said Inman School District; to provide revenue for said school; to provide for the election of five trustees, and to confer on them certain powers, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1901.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That an Act entitled An Act to incorporate the Inman School District, in Fayette County; to define the boundaries of the same; to regulate the management of the school in said Inman School District; to provide revenue for said school; to provide for the election of five trustees, and to confer on them certain powers, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1901 (Georgia Laws, 1901, page 242), be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Act of 1901 repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Franklin; to provide for the election of the Commissioners, who shall constitute said Board; to prescribe their term of office; prescribe their duties, fix their salaries, and for other purposes, approved August 21st, 1911.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the above entitled Act to create the office of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues in and for Franklin County, and for other purposes, approved August 21st, 1911, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Act of 1911 repealed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That this Act shall not become of force and effect until a bill known as House Bill No. 482, now pending in the General Assembly of this State, and entitled An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Franklin County, and for other purposes, shall have passed and been approved by the Governor of this State. Effective on commissioners' establishment.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for Franklin County; provide for their elections; fixing their term of office; prescribing their powers and duties; fixing the salary to be paid for such services; time of meeting; providing for the supervision of the public roads, bridges and public property of said county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after January 1st, 1922, a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Franklin, to consist of three persons, is hereby created. Said Commissioners shall be qualified voters of said county, and shall be bona fide residents of the Commissioner's District from which they are elected, which Districts are defined in Section 2 of this Act. Board of three created.

Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid. That for the purpose of this Act the said County of Franklin shall be divided into three Commissioners' Districts, to be constituted as follows, to-wit: The first Commissioner's District shall be composed of Carnesville (264th). Canon (1363rd), Stranges (812) Militia Distrits. The Second Commissioner's District shall be composed of Brvant's (206th), Gumlog (213th), Red Hill (212). Willborn (1377), Flintville (211) Militia Districts; and the Third Commissioner's District shall be composed of Manley's (370), Middle River (1420), Gunnel's (210), Dooley's (263), Ashland (1686) Militia Districts. Districts.

The Commissioners aforesaid shall have authority by a majority vote of said Board to attach any new Militia District that may be created to any one of the three Commissioners' Districts. New militia districts.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at the regular session of the Superior Court in and for Franklin County on the fourth Monday in September, 1921, next after the passage of this Act, the grand jury not later than the third day of said session shall elect by a two-thirds vote by ballot three citizens of said county, selecting one from each of the Commissioner's Districts, as set out in Section 2 of this Act, and shall annually thereafter not later than the third day of the regular session of the Superior Court in and for Franklin County at its September term, elect one Commissioner from the Commissioner's District whose Commissioner's term expires the succeeding December 31st, it being the intention of this Act that the term of one Commissioner shall expire on the 31st day of December of each year. No member while serving on such grand jury shall be eligible to election. All vacancies which shall occur by reason of the expiration of a term of office shall be filled by the grand jury by a two-thirds vote by ballot, and all other vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the Ordinary of Franklin County until the succeeding September term of the Superior Court when the grand jury shall fill the unexpired term as in cases of election. The term of office of all Commissioners shall be for three years except as provided in Section four of this Act. Elections. Eligibility. Vacancies. Term.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That within sixty days of the adjournment of the September term, 1921, of the Superior Court of said county, the Commissioners elected as provided in Section 3rd of this Act, shall meet and decide by lot among themselves who shall serve the terms one, two and three
years, which fact shall immediately be made known to the Clerk of the Superior Court, who shall enter the same upon the minutes of the Court and certify to the Governor under the seal of his office the name of the person chosen, together with the terms of each, and the Governor shall, upon receipt thereof, commission each for the term as certified. On the second day of January, 1922, said Commissioners shall meet at the Court House at the county seat in said county, and shall from among their number choose one as Chairman, elect a superintendent of roads bridges and public property, elect a clerk, and proceed to organize for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act. Said Board shall thereafter annually at its first meeting in January elect one of their number as Chairman, whose term of office shall be for one year. One, two, and three year terms. Chairman. Other officers. Term of chairman.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Commissioners shall have exclusive jurisdiction and control over the following matters, to-wit: In directing and controlling all of the property of said county as they may deem expedient according to law; in establishing or abolishing roads and bridges according to law; in establishing, abolishing or changing election precincts or Militia Districts; in supervising Tax Collector's and Tax Receiver's books; in allowing the insolvent list of said county; in settling all claims and accounts of officers having the care, management or disbursement of funds belonging to or appropriated for the use and benefit of said county, in bringing them to settlement; in providing for the poor of the county, and for the promotion of health as granted by law or not inconsistent with law; in examining the tax digest of said county for the correction of errors; in regulating or fixing license fees as may be provided by law; in establishing and maintaining the county chaingang; in working said chaingang on the public roads or public works of
said county as provided by law; in electing or appointing all minor officers and employees of said county whose election is not otherwise provided by law, such as warden and guards of convicts or chaingang, janitor of Court House and jail, superintendent of pauper farm, county physician and district overseers; in making such rules and regulations as they may deem best for the interest of the county, governing all minor officers and employees appointed by them, and fixing such reasonable compensation for them as said Board may deem best for the interest of the county; in providing for a uniform system of collecting the commutation road tax, the amount to be paid or the number of days' work on the roads of said county in lieu thereof; levying and collecting the tax for roads provided in Section 696 of the code of Georgia of 1910; in fixing the time when the commutation tax shall be paid or the work preferred; in trying all road defaulters in accordance with law; and generally to have and to exercise all the power heretofore vested in the Ordinary of said county when sitting for county purposes and to have original and exclusive jurisdiction over the subject matters mentioned and embraced in Section 4796 of the Code of Georgia of 1910, and to exercise such other powers as are granted by law or as may be indispensable to their jurisdiction over county matters and county finances. Jurisdiction and powers of board.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the clerk of grand jury shall furnish to the Clerk of the Superior Court of Franklin County a certificate showing the Commissioners elected by the grand jury within five days of the adjournment of the Court, together with the term for which they are elected, and it shall be the duty of said Clerk to enter the same upon the minutes of the Court and certify to the Governor under the seal of his office the names of the persons so chosen, and the Governor upon receipt thereof
shall commission them for the term for which they are elected, and each member of said Board shall before entering upon the discharge of his duties, shall subscribe to the oath required by law for county officers, and shall give good and solvent bond, payable to the Governor of said State and his successors in office, in the sum of one thousand dollars, to be approved by the Ordinary of said county conditioned for the faithful performance of his duty as such Commissioner. Election certificate. Bond.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the compensation of said Board shall be a salary of two hundred dollars per annum each, to be paid monthly out of the County Treasury, which shall be in full for all services whatsoever and all expenses incurred in discharge of their duties. Two of said Board shall be a quorum, and two must concur to pass any order or let any contract, pledge the county credit or grant or allow any claim or charge against the county. Compensation. Quorum.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Commissioners shall hold a regular meeting in each month on the first Wednesday thereof, and at the meeting to be held on the first Wednesday in January, 1922, at ten o'clock A. M., at the Court House at the county site of said county the present Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for said county shall turn over to them their office, all records, books and official papers therein, together with all county property, with a full inventory of the same and a full and complete statement showing the financial condition of the county. Said Board may adjourn from day to day and may hold called sessions whenever in their opinion public necessity requires it. Meetings.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Commissioners shall elect a superintendent of roads, bridges and public property to
be selected on account of his efficiency and knowledge and skill in practical road building, preference to be gives to a civil engineer when he fully measures up to the other requirements. Said superintendent shall during the term of his office devote his entire time to the superintending, supervision, building, construction and maintenance of roads and bridges and public property in and for the County of Franklin, and shall not during his term of office engage in any other trade, calling or occupation. He shall receive such salary as may be fixed by the Board of Commissioners not to exceed $2,400.00 yearly, payable monthly out of the County Treasury of said county. His term of office shall be such as may be fixed by the Board of Commissioners not to exceed $2,400.00 yearly, payable elect or appoint a successor. It shall be the duty of said superintendent to meet with said Board of commissioners every regular meeting day or any other time as said Board of Commissioners may direct, giving a detailed written report of the work accomplished each and every month and an outline of plans for the ensuing month. Said superintendent to be under the jurisdiction, authority and general direction of said Board of Commissioners of Franklin County. The superintendent shall give his receipt in writing to the clerk of the Board for all supplies and materials furnished to him by the Board, which receipt shall be kept in the office of the Board of Commissioners. Said superintendent shall give a good and solvent bond in the sum of one thousand dollars, payable to said Board and to be approved by them, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such superintendent. Superintendent of roads, etc.,

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board shall have the right to appoint a clerk to be paid monthly out of the County Treasury a salary not exceeding fifty dollars per month, who shall give a good and solvent bond in the sum of one thousand
dollars payable to said Board and to be approved by them, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as clerk, and to remove said clerk at their pleasure by a majority vote, and it shall be the duty of said clerk to attend all meetings of said Board, and to keep a full record of all its proceedings, and to keep on file and to preserve all papers relating to its business; to keep in a special book a statement of all taxes levied and for what purpose, and, also, an inventory of all county property, including road machinery, live stock, chaingang outfit, and road-working tools; to keep in a record separate from other financial affairs of the county, an accurate and itemized account of the expenditures applied to the working of the convicts and for all supplies and pay of guards furnished in behalf of the chaingang; he shall also keep a separate book in which shall be kept an account with overseers of the county for commutation tax collected and for tools furnished them; he shall also keep an itemized statement of all accounts ordered paid by the Board of Commissioners and shall show what fund is liable for the payment of said account; he shall also keep a book to be known as his record of county vouchers in which shall be kept a complete record of all warrants, or vouchers, drawn on the Treasury of said county, which record shall show by proper entries the fund from which same is payable, the persons to whom payable, the date of record, and the amount of said voucher or warrant; it shall be his duty to sign all warrants and vouchers, but he shall in no instance issue any warrant or voucher until same shall have been approved by the Board of Commissioners as provided in this Act, and he shall register each voucher on his record of vouchers, as above set out, and shall certify on the face of each and every voucher the date and fact of its record, and the Treasurer of Franklin County shall not pay any warrant, voucher or charge against said County of Franklin unless the same has been registered and certified in compliance with this
section, except such as bear date prior to January 1st, 1922. All records provided for in this section shall be kept at the Commissioners' office in the Court House in said county, and shall be open for public inspection. Clerk. Records.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Franklin County shall prepare and submit to the grand jury at the March and September term of Franklin Superior Court in each year a full and complete statement of the finances of the county, which statement shall be sworn to; said statement and report to the grand jury shall show an account of all receipts and disbursements, the source from whence received and the purpose for which expended; also submit a statement of unpaid county warrants and of indebtedness of the county for which no warrant has been executed. Said statement shall also show the number of persons who have paid the commutation tax and the amount thereof and the number of persons subject to road duty who have neither worked their time on the public road nor paid their commutation tax. Said statement or report shall be published with the general presentments of the grand jury. The purpose of this section being to show the taxpayers the financial condition of the county. Report to grand jury.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Commissioners, within twelve months after assuming the duties of their office shall have the books and accounts of the Tax Collector, Tax Receiver, Treasurer, and the Board of Commissioners, hereby created, audited by some certified public accountant of this State; and a like audit shall be had at least once every year thereafter; and said Board of Commissioners is hereby authorized and empowered to make such contracts as may be necessary in order to carry out the purposes of this section. Audits of accounts.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board shall not hire, employ, or contract with any member of said Board or with any one related to any member of said Board nearer than the third degree by marriage or consanguinity for work done or supplies to be furnished to said county in amounts exceeding $25.00, except such work to be done or supplies to be furnished shall be let at public outcry or by sealed bids to the best bidder. Certain contracts forbidden.
Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the members of said Board shall be exempt from road and jury duty during their term of office. Exemption from road and jury duty.

Sec. 14 A. Be it further enacted, That the provisions of this Act shall not become effective until submitted to a vote of the qualified voters of Franklin County, as herein provided. An election is hereby called for Friday, September 23, 1921, to be held in said county in the same manner and at the same place as general elections for said State and county officers are now held, on which date those favoring the election of County Commissioners under the provisions of this Act shall cast their ballots and have printed or written thereon, the words: For the election of Commissioners, and those opposed thereto, the words: Against the election of Commissioners. Should a majority of qualified voters, voting at said election, cast their ballots For the election of Commissioners, then and in that event, this Act shall become of full force and effect. The vote in said election shall be consolidated in the same manner as the vote in general elections and the returns thereof made to the Ordinary of said county, and said Ordinary shall declare the result thereof. Election to ratify.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to consolidate and amend an Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Glynn, approved February 21, 1873, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, approved August 12, 1914, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the Act of the General Assembly approved August 12, 1914, entitled An Act to consolidate and amend an Act to regulate public instruction in the County of Glynn approved February 21, 1873, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, and for other purposes herein mentioned, shall be amended as follows, to-wit: By striking from Section 3 of said Act the last five lines thereof beginning with the word by in the 35th line of said section and ending with the words August 1st at the end of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to-wit: At all meetings of the Board a majority vote of the quorum present shall determine the action of the Board in all matters, except that the election or removal of the County Superintendent of Schools or the changing of his salary, shall require the affirmative vote of a majority in number of the actual existing membership of the Board; and the Board is authorized in its discretion so to remove the County Superintendent of Schools. Act of 1914 amended. Majority vote of board.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act be further amended by striking from Section 6 thereof the four lines beginning with the word however in the fourth line of said section and ending with the word each in the eighth line. Second term of superintendent.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said Act be further amended by striking from Section 16 thereof after the words by a two-thirds vote in the 35th line of said section all of the remainder of said section to the end thereof, including said words by a two-thirds vote in said 35th line. Further amendment.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the amount of commutation tax for road work in the County of Hall, and to provide how the same shall be discharged by work on the roads in said county, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, nineteen hundred and twenty-two, that the commutation assessment fixed by the Ordinary or County Commissioners, as the case may be, of Hall County, shall be at the rate of one ($1.00) dollar per day for those subject to road duty who select to work out their time on the public roads of said County of Hall. Provided, further, that the commutation tax shall not exceed the sum of four ($4.00) dollars per annum, and the county authorities shall have authority to demand the payment of said sum; or labor in lieu thereof at one period, or may be divided into two periods, as said county authorities may select. Provided, further, that those who select to work
out their time on the public roads of the County of Hall shall not be required to work outside the limits of the Militia District in which is their legal residence. Tax rate. Manner of payment.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the compensation of the members of the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Harris County, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act, the three members of the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of Harris County shall each receive an annual salary of fifty dollars per year, and in addition to said annual salary of fifty dollars per year, each member of said Board shall be entitled to the sum of two and no/100 ($2.00) dollars for every day the said Commissioner is engaged in work for said Harris County; the total sum to be paid each Commissioner not to exceed the sum of two hundred, fifty and no/100 ($250.00) dollars per annum. Salary. Additional compensation. Maximum.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.
