The amount of assessment on each piece of real estate shall be a lien on said real estate from the date of the passage of the ordinance providing for the work and making the assessment. The Mayor and Council shall have power and authority to enforce collection for the amount of any assessment so made for work either upon the streets or sidewalks by execution issued by the Town Clerk against the real estate improved and assessed, for the amount assessed against the owner at the date of the ordinance making such assessments which execution may be levied by the Marshal or any policeman of said town on such real estate and after advertising and in other proceedings as in case of tax sales, the same shall be
sold at public outcry to the highest bidder. Such sale shall vest absolute title in purchaser. Said Town Marshal, or policeman acting for him, shall have authority to eject occupant and put purchaser in possession, provided the owner of said real estate shall have the right to file his affidavit denying the whole or any part of the amount for which execution is issued and stating the amount which he admits to be due, together with all costs shall be paid before the affidavit shall be returned to the Superior Court of Berrien County and there tried and the issue determined as in case of illegality, subject to penalties provided as in cases of illegality filed for delay only. The Mayor and Council shall have authority to pave and contract to pave, the whole surface of the street, without giving any railroad or street railroad company or other property holder occupant of the street the option of having the space to be paved by them, paved by themselves, or by contract at his or its instance, the object being to prevent delay and to secure uniformity. The lien for assessment on abutting property and on street railroad and other railroad companies for street or sidewalk paving, curbing, macadamizing, grading or draining, shall have rank and priority of payment next in point of dignity of liens for taxes, such liens to date from the passage of the ordinance authorizing the execution of the work in each instance. Said Mayor and Council shall have power and authority to prescribe by ordinance such other rules as they may in their discretion think necessary to grade, pave, drain, macadamize, or curb the streets, sidewalks, and alleys of said town and to collect the cost thereof by execution against the adjacent property owner and railroad companies or other occupants of the streets or alleys of said town. Street improvement assessments. Liens.

Sec. 45. Be it further enacted, That said Mayor and Council shall have full power and authority to acquire on behalf of the Town of Alapaha by gift, purchase or
otherwise, grounds suitable for such park or parks as in their judgment may be to the interest and welfare of the citizens of said town. They shall have the power and authority to improve and keep the same and to that end may appoint such officers and employees as in their judgment may be necessary and compensate them therefor. They shall have the right to draw on the ordinary expense fund of said town for said purpose or upon any other fund not otherwise appropriated according to law. Parks and playgrounds.

Sec. 46. Be it further enacted, That said Mayor and Council shall have power and authority, whenever in their judgment they see fit, to secure for said town one or more deep wells in said town for the purpose of supplying the town with plentiful supply of good wholesome water and to this end they may contract with such party or parties as they see fit. For the said purpose they may draw on the ordinary fund of the town or upon any other fund not otherwise appropriated according to law. Wells.

Sec. 47. Be it further enacted, That should the Mayor and Council determine in accordance with provisions hereinbefore made to issue bonds for the purposes hereinbefore set out, then they shall have the power and authority in addition to all other tax hereinbefore authorized, to levy and collect an additional tax not to exceed one per centum per annum, sufficient to pay off the said bonds with all interest and charges on the same within the period which said bonds have to run, and it shall be the duty of said Mayor and Council in the published notice of any election for the issuance of any bonds for any of the purposes herein provided to state the amount of annual tax it will be necessary to levy and collect to pay same. Tax to refund bonds.
Sec. 48. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to create and establish a new charter for the City of Albany; to prescribe the rights, powers, government and jurisdiction of said City; to fix the corporate limits proper of said City; to confer jurisdiction upon said City; to exercise police power over and to regulate certain matters and offenses in certain territory beyond its corporate limits proper, and to make all valid ordinances of said City, heretofore or hereafter, adopted, relative to such matters and offenses, operative in said territory; to confer power upon said City, to acquire and own property beyond its corporate limits for certain purposes, and to own and operate a municipal abattoir and control and regulate other abatoirs or slaughter-houses; to provide that no valid or existing ordinances, rule or regulation of the former corporation, nor any contract or right made or acquired under the same, shall be affected by this Act, and for other purposes, approved August 18, 1917, and for other purposes. To preserve the Act of 1921 establishing the ward system; to provide for terminating offices, appointments or employment, and to fill vacancies and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia entitled An Act to create and establish a new charter for the City of Albany; to prescribe the rights, powers, government and jurisdiction of said city; to fix the corporate limits proper of said city; to confer jurisdiction upon said city to exercise police power over, and to regulate certain matters and offenses in certain territory beyond its corporate limits proper, and to make all valid ordinances of said city heretofore or hereafter
adopted, relative to such matters and offenses, operative in said territory, to confer power upon said city to acquire and own property beyond its corporate limits for certain purposes, and to own and operate a municipal abattoir, and control and regulate other abattoirs or slaughter-houses; to provide that no valid or existing ordinances, rule or regulation of the former corporation, nor any contract or right made or acquired under the same, shall be affected by this Act, and for other purposes, approved August 18, 1917, be and the same is, hereby amended as follows, to-wit: By the adding or inserting in the 29th line of Section 1 of said Act as published, between the words legal and and the following paragraph, to-wit: Provided that no public ultility or any property used in connection therewith and necessary for the maintenance of the same, owned or controlled by the City of Albany shall ever be sold, leased or otherwise disposed of, unless the contract for such sale, lease or other disposition shall have first been assented to by two-thirds of the qualified voters of the city at an election held for that purpose, as other city elections are held, so that when said Section is so amended the same shall read as follows, to-wit: Act of 1917, sec. 1 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the County of Dougherty, hereinafter described, are hereby continued incorporated by the name and style of City of Albany, a body corporate and politic, with power to govern themselves by such ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and by-laws for municipal purposes as may be adopted and promulgated under the terms and provisions of this charter not in conflict with the Constitution or Laws of this State or of the United States, with power in and by said corporate name to contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts, and to have and to use common seal and to do all other things necessary to promote the municipal corporate
purposes of said city; and shall be able in law to purchase, hold or receive, enjoy, possess, retain, manage and dispose of, for the use and benefit of the said City of Albany, any interest in any real or personal property of whatsoever kind or description within or without the corporate limits of said city, to hold all property and effects now belonging to said city either in its name or in the name of others, for its use, for the purpose and intents for which the same were granted or dedicated; in like manner to use, manage and improve, sell and convey, rent or lease, and otherwise manage and dispose of all property hereafter acquired; and all transfers and conveyances of real or personal property heretofore made by said city are hereby confirmed, ratified and declared legal, provided that no public utility or any property used in connection therewith and necessary for the maintenance of the same, owned or controlled by the City of Albany shall ever be sold, leased or otherwise disposed of, unless the contract for such sale, lease or other disposition shall have first been assented to by two-thirds of the qualified voters of the city at an election held for that purpose, as other city elections are held. And said City of Albany shall succeed to all the rights and liabilities of the old corporation, and all existing valid ordinances, rules, by-laws and resolutions of the old corporation remain unaffected hereby and are hereby continued and confirmed. To be read. Transfer of property. Ratification of contract.

law.p:
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act be, and the same is, hereby further amended as follows, to-wit: By striking from Section 5 of said Act the words a sexton, a superintendent of the streets occurring in the 6th and 7th line of said Section as published, and between the words council and a, and striking therefrom in the 9th line thereof the figures 1918 and substituting for said figures the figures 1922, and also amended as follows, to-wit: by adding to said Section 5 the following proviso, to-wit:
Provided that the Mayor and Council may at any time by ordinance consolidate the office of Treasurer and Collector and the office of Clerk of Council so that one person may be elected to and fill both of said offices, so that when so amended said Section 5 will read as follows: Act of 1917, sec. 5 amended.

Section 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the following municipal officers of said city shall be elected by the Mayor and Council and shall hold their office for a term of two (2) years and until their successors are elected and qualified, to-wit: an attorney, a physician, a treasurer and collector, a clerk of council, a chief of the fire department. The first election hereunder for said officers shall be held on the second Monday in January, 1922, and every two years thereafter; each of the above named officers shall receive such compensation as the Mayor and Council may by ordinance prescribe, which amount shall not be increased or diminished during their term of office, and they shall, in addition to the duties herein prescribed, perform such other duties as may be provided by ordinance; provided that such municipal officers shall at all times be subject to suspension, for cause, by the Mayor in his discretion, but such suspension shall be reported within five (5) days to the Council for action on their part, under the provisions of this charter; provided further, that nothing herein contained shall operate or prevent the officers above enumerated now holding office in said city from holding same until the expiration of their respective terms and until their successors are elected and qualified. Provided that the Mayor and Council may at any time by ordinance consolidate the office of Treasurer and Collector and the office of Clerk of Council so that one person may be elected to and fill both of said offices. Provided that the amendments above provided for said Section 5 shall not take effect until the second Monday in January, 1922. And said Section 5 shall be also amended as follows, to-wit: by striking from said Section
5 all of sub-paragraph 2 which reads as follows, to-wit: Any one who has attained the age of 21 years and is a qualified voter in the City of Albany shall be eligible to any municipal office, and substituting therefor the following new sub-paragraph, to-wit: (2) Residence in the City of Albany or majority age shall not be required as a necessary qualification for a person to hold any municipal office. To be read. Municipal officers. First election. Power to consolidate offices. Eligibility.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 9 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows, to-wit: by striking from said Section 9 in the 7th line thereof the words and be employed for such time and further by striking from said Section 9 all occurring after the word police in the 16th line of said Section as published and substituting therefor the following: All members of the fire department, except the Chief, who shall be elected as hereinbefore provided by the Mayor and Council shall from and after the second Wednesday after the second Monday in September, 1921, be employed by or upon the authority of the Mayor and Council for no fixed period, and shall hold office only at the will or sufferance of the Mayor and Council, and shall under no circumstances be considered as elected within the meaning of that word, and may be discharged with or without cause and without notice, so that when so amended said Section 9 shall read as follows: Act of 1917, sec. 9 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a fire department maintained and operated by said City of Albany under such rules, regulations and ordinances as the Mayor and Council may prescribe, and such as already exist. In addition to Chief the fire department shall consist of such a number of men, who shall receive such salaries as may be provided by ordinance. The Chief shall be the executive head of the department, shall be responsible for the good order and efficiency of the same, shall make
such expenditure therefor as may be previously authorized by the Mayor and Council, and shall make such report to said Mayor and Council of the condition of the department as may be required; and said Chief shall be and he is hereby made ex-officio a police officer of the city, and empowered to make arrests as regular police. All members of the fire department, except the Chief, who shall be elected as hereinbefore provided by the Mayor and Council shall from and after the second Wednesday after the second Monday in September, 1921, be employed by or upon the authority of the Mayor and Council for no fixed period, and shall hold office only at the will or sufferance of the Mayor and Council, and shall under no circumstances be considered as elected within the meaning of that word, and may be discharged with or without cause and without notice. To be read. Fire department. Terms of members.

law.p:
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 11 of said Act be amended as follows, to-wit: by striking the words elected in the 6th line of said Section, and by striking the words first Monday in January in the 13th line of said Section, and substituting therefor the following: second Monday in January, 1922, and by striking all occurring between the word elected in the 17th line of said Section as published and the word all in the 22nd line of said Section, and substituting therefor the following, to-wit: from and after the second Wednesday in September, 1921, the other members of the police force shall not be elected within the meaning of that word, but shall be employed for terms, at the will or sufferance of the Board of Police Commissioners, and by striking all occurring between the word Dougherty in the 36th line of said Section and and in the 58th line of said Section, and substituing therefor as follows: all employment of policemen other than the Chief of Police shall be subject
to discharge by the Board with or without cause and without notice, so that said Section when so amended shall read as follows, to-wit: Act of 1917, sec. 11 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the regular police force of the City of Albany shall consist of a marshal, or chief of police, a deputy marshal, or deputy chief of police, and such other officers and members as the Mayor and Council shall prescribe; and said regular force shall be as hereinafter prescribed. Before qualifying they shall take oath to faithfully discharge the duties imposed upon them by laws and ordinances and shall give such bond as may be required of them by city ordinance. The term of office of the Chief of Police shall be two years and until his successor is elected and qualified, each term begining on the Tuesday after the second Monday in January, 1922, on which date his election shall be held; provided that the term of office of the present chief shall not expire until after the expiration of the full term for which he was elected. From and after the second Wednesday in September, 1921, the other members of the regular police force shall be elected within the meaning of that word, but shall be employed for terms at the will and sufferance of the Board of Police Commissioners. All elections shall be subject to fine, suspension or dismissal of the incumbent. Any person twenty-one (21) years of age, and who is a resident of Dougherty County, or the City of Albany shall be eligible to election on said force. The compensation of members of the regular police force shall be provided by ordinance of Mayor and Council, and shall not be decreased or diminished (except by fine) during their respective terms of office, and no extra pay, allowance or cost shall be made to them or to either of them. It shall be their duty to make arrest in the manner prescribed by law of person violating the penal laws of the State or the ordinance of the Mayor and Council. It shall be the duty of the Marshal, or chief of police, to
prosecute offenders against the penal laws of the State in the State Court of the County of Dougherty. All employment of policemen other than the Chief of Police shall be subject to discharge by the Board, with or without cause and without notice; and provided; further that the Board of Police Commissioners may, upon request of any hotel, terminal company, railroad, or street railway company, or combination of railway companies or any manufacturing company, appoint any person or persons in the employ of the applicant as a special member of the police force of the city for a term at the will of said Board, and, after taking the oath prescribed for the regular policemen, said appointee be and he is hereby clothed with as full power to make arrests under the law and the ordinances of the City of Albany for the violation of any ordinances or law committed upon the premises of his employer as the regular police of said city, and all such appointments shall be entered upon the minutes of said Board, but the appointee shall receive no compensation from the city; and provided further, that the Mayor and Council of the City of Albany shall have the power, by ordinance to confer police authority upon any officer or employee of the city, and to make such officer or employee an ex-officio member of the police force of the city, and such officer or employee shall then possess the full power and authority to make arrests for violations of the penal ordinances of the city governing matters relating to his employment as the regular police of the city; and, provided, further, that the Chief of Police, with the approval and consent of the Chairman of the Police Commissioners, shall have the power, should circumstances require it, to employ or appoint for any emergency such additional number of policemen, to be uniformed or not as he may direct, as to him shall seem needful, for a period not exceeding five (5) days; and in any emergency where a longer period is required the same shall only be extended in each case by the Board of Police Commissioners for such period, not exceeding
five (5) days, as to them may seem proper; and such temporary policemen shall be sworn as other policemen and shall receive not exceeding the same rate of pay as the regular members of the police force; and, provided, further, that the Mayor and Council of the City of Albany shall have the power to provide, by ordinance, for the election, or temporary appointment, by the Board of Police Commissioners of a force of detectives, or plain clothes men, for such term and compensation as the Mayor and Council shall prescribe. The Mayor and Council shall cause the entire regular police force of the city to be armed and so uniformed as to be readily recognized by the public as police officers, the arms and uniforms to be furnished at the expense of the city and shall remain the property of the city. To be read. Police. Term of chief. Employment of policemen. Discharge.

law.p: Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That sub-paragraph 4 of Section 24 of said Act be amended as follows, to-wit: by striking the word boards in the first line of said sub-paragraph as published and substituting therefor a board, and striking from line 3 of said sub-paragraph the word each and by striking from said sub-paragraph in the 3rd line thereof the word boards and substituting therefor the word board and striking from said sub-paragraph in line 7 thereof the words each of said boards and substituting therefor the words said board, and by striking therefrom in line 16 the word boards and substituting therefor the word board, and by striking therefrom in line 3 the word freeholders and substituting therefor the word citizens, so that when so amended said sub-paragraph 4 of said Section 24 shall read as follows: Act of 1917, sec. 24 amended.

(4) Said City shall have the power to appoint a Board of Tax Assessors of real and personal property, consisting of three (3) citizens of said city, which Board shall assess for taxation, respectively, the value of all personal and real property in the city, and perform such other duties in connection therewith as the Mayor and
Council may prescribe, and said Board when sitting, shall have the powers of a court to compel the attendance of parties and witnesses, to require the production of books and papers, and to enforce such attendance and production by attachment for contempt which may be punished by said Board, respectively as in this charter prescribed for contempt, committed before the police court, and the Mayor and Council shall provide by ordinance, not in conflict with State law, for the ascertainment of the value of taxable property by said Board in contested cases, and shall provide by ordinance, not in conflict with State law, for notice and hearing to tax-payers, the value of whose returned property has been increased or whose unreturned property has been assessed with the right in the tax-payers to contest the taxability of the property by petition in equity in the Superior Court of Dougherty County. To be read. Board of tax assessors.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 18 of said Act reading as follows, to-wit: Act of 1917, sec. 18 stricken.

Section 18. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there be and there is hereby established a Park Commission in and for the City of Albany, to be composed of four citizens and the Chairman of the standing street committee of the council who shall have the rights and privileges of the citizen members, the said citizen members of the commission shall be elected by the Mayor and Council for a term of four years and until their successors are elected. The first election hereunder shall be held on the second (2nd) Monday in January, 1918, to elect a citizen member to succeed the member heretofore elected, whose term expires in 1918, and annually thereafter, on the second Monday in each year, a citizen member shall be elected to succeed the member whose term then expires, it being the intention that nothing herein contained shall prevent the present members of said commission from serving the terms, respectively,
for which they were elected. No person shall be eligible to appointment and election of one of said citizen members unless he be a citizen of the City of Albany. Each member of said commission shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, subscribe the following oath before some officer authorized to administer the same, to-wit: I swear that I will faithfully and impartially demean myself as a member of the Park Commission of the City of Albany during my continuance in office, and I will well and truly perform all the duties of said office; and I will neither be concerned nor interested pecuniarily, directly or indirectly, in any contract or work or material furnished for or on behalf of any work, improvement or preservation of the parks or public playgrounds of the City of Albany while a member of this commission. Said oath shall be entered on the minutes of said commission. Said Park Commission shall have the exclusive management of all matters and things relating to the care, preservation, improvement, adornment, good order, and regulation generally of Tift Park, Ingram Park and the Auditorium or Chautauqua Park, and all other similar parks and public playgrounds owned or controlled by the City of Albany. Said Commission shall have the exclusive control and direction of the planting and caring for the trees, grass, flowers, and shrubbery in said parks and playgrounds; provided, that nothing herein contained shall confer power upon said Commission to have or assume any authority over the cemeteries, or the side or center parks of and in the streets of the City of Albany, but all such shall be directly under the control and authority of the Mayor and Council, except the care, planting, preservation and removal of trees and shrubbery on said center of said side parks. Said Commission shall keep a record of its proceedings and shall elect one of its members as secretary and treasurer; it shall hold a stated meeting each month at the city hall, and such other meetings as it may prescribe from time to time or as may be called by the Chairman. The Chairman shall be
elected by the Commission. Three (3) of said Commission shall constitute a quorum with power to transact all business. The Commission shall have the power to adopt such rules for its government as it may deem proper. Accurate accounts of expenditures made by said Commission shall be kept and regular quarterly reports made thereof to the Mayor and Council. The Commission shall annually file a complete report of its actings and doings of the previous year, which shall be referred to the Mayor and Council, and be spread upon the minutes of the Commission. All expenditures made by said Commission shall be within such amount as has been previously appropriated by the Mayor and Council on application for such appropriation by said Commission. Any expenditures in excess of any such appropriation shall be expressly approved by the Mayor and Council before the same is incurred. The city engineer shall act as adviser to said Commission and shall be subject to its call and direction. Said Commission shall have the power to and shall make such rules and regulations as may seem to it proper, touching matters and things within its jurisdiction, which rules and regulations shall be submitted to the Mayor and Council of the City of Albany, and, when approved by the Council of said city, shall become binding and effective. When said rules and regulations are confirmed by the Council, provisions shall be made by the Council for penalties necessary for the due observation of said rules and regulations, be and the same is, hereby stricken from said Act so as to abolish the Park Commission therein established, provided that this amendment shall not take effect until the second Monday in January, 1922. To be read. Park commission. Abolishment. Effective January 9, 1922.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 12 of said Act be and the same is hereby amended as follows: by striking the word five and the figure 5 in the 3rd line of said Section and substituting therefor the word four and the figure 4,
and inserting between the word board and but in the 8th line of said Section the clause except in case of a tie, and striking all occurring after the word board in the 19th line of said Section, and substituting the following, to-wit: Said Police Commissioners shall be elected for terms of two (2) years each by the Mayor and Council, except at the first election to be held hereunder, when all four (4) members of said Commission shall be elected, two (2) for one year and two (2) for two years respectively; thereafter the Mayor and Council shall elect two (2) Commissioners annually to take the place of those whose terms of office have expired. The first election hereunder shall be held by the Mayor and Council at their last regular meeting in January, 1922, at which time the office of the present members of the Police Commission as now constituted shall be and the same are hereby terminated. The terms of office of said Commissioners so elected hereafter shall begin on the date of the last regular meeting of said Mayor and Council in January of each year. Any vacancy occurring in the Board during the year, for any other cause than the expiration of the regular term, an election to fill said vacancy shall be immediately held by the Mayor and Council, and such incumbent shall hold until the unexpired term shall expire, and until his successor is elected and qualified. Each regular term shall begin on date of election and close as hereinbefore declared, and until a successor is elected and qualified, no person shall be eligible for election and membership of said Board for more than two consecutive terms, provided, however, that any person filling an unexpired term may be eligible for election to the two succeeding terms; so that said Section when so amended shall read as follows: Act of 1917, sec. 12 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 12. That there shall be a Board of Police Commissioners connected with the municipal government of the City of Albany, which said Board shall consist of four (4) persons, citizens of said city, and neither
of them shall be a member of the City Council, but the Mayor of the City shall be ex-officio president of the Board and shall preside at all meetings thereof. He shall in no event have a vote by reason of his membership on said Board except in case of a tie, but shall at all times, by virtue thereof, as well as by reason of his office as Mayor, have the right and power to call upon the police force or any member thereof to execute any law, ordinance, or resolution of the city government. In the absence or disability of the Mayor, from any cause, the Mayor pro tem shall preside in his place, and in the event of the absence of both the Mayor and Mayor pro tem; for any cause, a member of the Board selected by the Board shall preside, provided, such member, by reason of presiding, shall not lose any power to vote on all matters considered by the Board. Said Police Commissioners shall be elected for terms of two (2) years each by the Mayor and Council, except at the first election to be held hereunder, when all four (4) members of said Commission shall be elected, two (2) for one year and two (2) for two years respectively; thereafter, the Mayor and Council shall elect two (2) Commissioners annually to take the place of those whose terms of office have expired. The first election hereunder shall be held by the Mayor and Council at their last regular meeting in January, 1922, at which time the office of the present members of the Police Commission as now constituted shall be and the same are hereby terminated. The term of office of said Commissioners so elected hereafter shall begin on the date of the last regular meeting of said Mayor and Council in January of each year. Any vacancy occurring in the Board during the year, for any cause than the expiration of the regular term, an election to fill said vacancy shall be immediately held by the Mayor and Council, and such incumbent shall hold until the unexpired term shall expire, and until his successor is elected and qualified. Each regular term shall begin on date of election and close as hereinbefore declared, and until a
successor is elected and qualified, no person shall be eligible for election and membership of said Board for more than two consecutive terms, provided, however, that any person filling an unexpired term may be eligible for election to the two succeeding terms. And further by striking from sub-paragraph 2 of said Section 12 the word three in the 10th line of said sub-paragraph and substituting therefor the word two, so that said sub-paragraph when so amended shall read as follows: (2) That the Board of Police Commissioners thus elected and qualified shall have exclusive power, and it shall be their duty to appoint a Marshal or Chief of Police, and such other police officers or policemen as is or may be prescribed by the city ordinance. This power extends to unexpired as well as to regular terms. They shall keep a record of their proceedings, and the Clerk of the City Council shall act as the clerk thereof. They shall hold a stated meeting each month, and such other meetings as the public interest may from time to time require. Two, exclusive of the Mayor, shall constitute a quorum with power to transact all business, including questions of the election or dismissals of members of the force. He shall exercise full direction and control of the officers and members of the police force in conforming to the existing ordinances and such as may be applicable to the subject, but in no event shall said power be so construed as to deny the Mayor and ex-officio president the power to call upon the police force, or any member thereof, to execute any law, ordinance or resolution of city government. And provided, further, that the members of the entire police force, rank and file, shall be subject to suspension by the Mayor, for cause, in his discretion, but in all cases of such suspension it shall be the duty of the Mayor to report the same within five (5) days to the Board of Police Commissioners, for action thereon. Said Commissioners shall serve without compensation or emolument. That said Board shall when sitting for the trial of any member of the police force have power to
issue subpoena for witnesses to be signed by the Clerk of Council and bear test in the name of the Chairman, and to issue and enforce attachments against persons disobeying same, and shall have the power to punish for contempt to the same extent as in this Act conferred upon the Mayor and Council, and the orders, writs, warrants, attachments or other process of said Board shall be directed to and executed by the Chief of Police or any member of the police force. To be read. Police commissioners. Four members. Terms. First election. Vacancies. Sub-par. 2 amended. Powers. Quorum.

law.p: Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act shall be and the same is hereby amended as follows, to-wit: by striking the word one-half occurring in the 12th line of Section 22 of said Act, and substiutting therefor the word two-thirds and said Section 22 is further amended by inserting in line 26 thereof as published between the words companies and as the following clause, and enforced by execution, issued against said company or companies, and said Section 22 is further amended by inserting between the words denying and that in the 43 line of said Section as published, the words for any reason, so that when so amended said Section 22 of said Act shall read as follows: Act of 1917, sec. 22 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 22. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city shall have the power and authority by ordinance to pave, repave or repair the pavements of the sidewalks of the city, and to assess the cost of same against the owners of the property abutting on said sidewalks, according to frontage owned by them thereon; and said city shall have the power and authority by ordinance to grade, pave, macadamize, curb, or otherwise improve for travel or drainage, any of the streets, alleys or ways of the city or to regrade, repave, recurb, remacadamize or repair the pavement, curbing, grade or drainage of the same and to assess two-thirds of the total cost of same against the owners of the property abutting
on each side of the streets, alleys or ways so improved, according to the frontage owned by each thereon; and to require any railroad or street railroad company having, or which may hereafter have, tracks running through the streets, alleys or ways of said city, so improved, to grade, pave, macadamize, regrade, repave, or remacadamize or otherwise improve, as the Mayor and Council may by ordinance direct, the width of their tracks and two (2) feet on each side thereof, and to require said companies to repair or repave their aforesaid portions as the Mayor and Council may direct. In the event any such company or companies fail or refuse to comply with said requirement the city may have the same done and the expense thereof shall be assessed against said company or companies, and enforced by execution, issued against said company or companies, as hereinafter provided in this Section; and said city shall be and is hereby empowered to enforce the payment of the assessments provided for in this section by execution against the abutting property and against the owners of the same, which execution shall be issued and enforced by levy and sale of said property like executions for taxes under existing ordinances, or such as may hereafter be made applicable to the subject, and said property shall be sold in the same manner and shall be subject to all the incidents of purchase by the city, and redemption by the owner as provided for by the Code of Georgia, and amendments thereto; and all assessments heretofore made by said city for the purpose herein specified, but remaining unpaid, may be enforced as herein set out; provided, however, that to an execution issued under the provisions of this section, the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying for any reason that the whole or any part of the amount for which execution issued is due, and the reason why same is not due by and from defendant, and stating what amount is admitted to be due, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid before said affidavit shall be received, and said affidavit shall be received for the
balance, and said affidavit so received shall be returned to the Superior Court of Dougherty County and there tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penaltie provided for in cases of illegality for delay. The assessments provided for in this section shall constitute and be a lien, from the date of the ordinance making the assessment, upon the property against which they are assessed as well as upon all the property generally of the person owning the property at the date of the assessment, and such lien as between other liens shall take rank as city taxes. One publication of the ordinance or ordinances providing the improvement mentioned in the section in the newspaper of Dougherty County in which the sheriff's advertisements are published shall be sufficient notice to abutting property owners, or railroad or street railroad companies having tracks on the streets to be improved, of the contents and provisions of such ordinance, and of the fact that such improvements are to be made; provided, that in case of non-residents, a copy of said ordinance shall be mailed to the address of all non-residents owning land abutting to that where the improvements are to be made, if the address of such non-residents be known, but failure to send or receive such copy shall invalidate the ordinance, the assessment or levy, nor any other proceedings thereunder. To be read. Sidewalk improvements. Assessments against railway companies. Objections.

law.p: Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That nothing in this Act or the passage thereof, shall in any manner be construed as altering, changing or repealing an Act passed by the General Assembly of Georgia at its 1921 session providing for the election of members of City Council in the City of Albany from wards, or according to wards, which manner of electing councilmen is expressly preserved in this Act. Act of 1921 not repealed.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That upon the election and qualification of the three councilmen to be elected at the first election held under
the Acts of 1921, providing for the election of councilmen in the City of Albany from wards, or according to wards, upon a majority vote of the Mayor and Council, the Mayor voting, the terms of office or appointment, or election, or employment, of any or all city officials or employees of the City of Albany, (except the Mayor and Council as constituted, elected and qualified, after the said first election under the Act of 1921 providing for the election of councilmen from wards,) and also the term of office or appointment or employment of any and all board members, or members of commissions, or boards or commissions, and of those chosen under or by them, may be declared vacant and be vacated, and the new Mayor and Council as constituted, elected and qualified after the said first election under the Act of 1921, providing for the election of councilmen from wards, shall thereafter make such appointments, elections or employment to fill such unexpired terms, provided that such officials or employees as have heretofore been elected, chosen, or appointed by any Board or Commission, or Boards or Commissions, shall have their term of office or employment or appointment vacated and declared vacant by the new Board or Commission (by a majority vote, the Chairman voting) as chosen, appointed, elected and qualified by the new Mayor and Council aforesaid after election and disqualification under the Act of 1921 providing for the election of councilmen in the City of Albany from wards, which Board or Commission shall thereafter make such elections, appointment or employment to fill such vacancies for the unexpired terms, provided further that the terms of office of employment of all officials or employees shall continue at the same rate of compensation until the successors of such employees or officials are named and qualified, unless such or employment shall be legally abolished by the said Mayor and Council. The Superintendent of the City Schools and the teachers employed in the city schools shall not have their term of office or employment interfered with under
this Section until after the end of the school year in June, 1922. Nothing in this Section shall be construed as requiring the Mayor and City Council to vacate any office or appointment, or employment, unless such Mayor and Council may desire to so do by a majority vote aforesaid, nor shall any Board or Commission be required to declare any office or employment vacated unless by a majority vote of said Board or Commission aforesaid, the purpose of this Section being to give the said Mayor and Council jurisdiction over all employees and officials of the city and their employment and appointment or election, and not be required to maintain or retain any official or employee or member of a Board or Commission elected, chosen or appointed by any previous Mayor and Council unless such Mayor and Council as elected and qualified after the said first elected under the Act of 1921 for the election of councilmen according to wards shall so desire, or unless such Boards or Commissions appointed, elected or chosen by the said new Mayor and Council shall so desire as to officials or employees elected, appointed, chosen or employed by such Boards or Commissions. If this section or any portion of it is held invalid, such invalidity shall not be construed as affecting or impairing any other sections or portions of this Act. This Section shall take precedence over any and all other conflicting sections or portions of this Act, and over any and all portions or sections or parts of sections, of the Charter of the City of Albany, which charter is hereby amended by adding the wards of Sections nine and ten of this Act as Sections twenty-eight (28) and twenty-nine (29) respectively, of said charter, Acts 1917 and Section (11) eleven of this Act as Sections thirty (30) of said charter, Acts 1917. City officers, power to remove. School superintendent retained. Vote of governing body. Precedence of this section.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passage of this Act, in the interim between the passage of this Act and the first election and qualification of the three councilmen to be elected
and qualified under the Act of 1921 providing for the election of councilmen in the City of Albany, according to wards, the Mayor and Council of the City of Albany, and the Boards or Commissions or any Boards or Commissions, of said City of Albany, shall have no right to make any elections, appointments, or employment, of any official or employee for a longer period or term than the second Monday in January, 1922, or until the aforesaid three councilmen have been elected, qualified and taken their office. Interim appointments limited.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Albany, in the County of Dougherty, to provide for the division of said City of Albany into five political wards, and to provide for the election of one Councilman from each of said wards, and for the election of one Councilman at Large from said City of Albany; to provide for the time, manner and places of holding elections in said City of Albany, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the Act creating a new charter for the City of Albany, in the County of Dougherty, approved August 18, 1917, Acts 1917, Pages 454 to 496 inclusive, and all Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same are, hereby amended as hereinafter set forth. Act of 1917 amended.
The said City of Albany is hereby divided into five political wards as follows: Division into wards.

item.p: The First Ward shall embrace all that part of the City of Albany lying east of the Flint River and known as East Albany.
The Second Ward shall include all that part of the City of Albany lying west of the Flint River and south of the center of Tift street extended and east of the center of Jefferson street.
The Third Ward shall include all that part of the City of Albany lying north of the center of Tift street extended east of the center of Jefferson street and west of Flint River.
The Fourth Ward shall include all that part of the City of Albany lying north of the center of North street extended and west of the center of Jefferson street.
The Fifth Ward shall include all that part of the City of Albany lying west of the center of Jefferson street and south of the center of North street extended.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That one Councilman shall be elected-for the said City of Albany from each of the five political Wards described in Section One above, and that one Councilman shall be elected from the City of Albany at Large. Councilmen; from wards and at large.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the first election hereunder shall be held on the first Monday in December, 1921, for the election of three Councilmen, one from the First Ward, one from the Fourth Ward, and one from the city at large to be successors of the present Councilmen, whose terms of office expire on the second Monday in January, 1922. On the first Monday in December, 1922, the second election shall be held hereunder for the purpose of electing three other Councilmen who shall be elected one from the Second Ward, one from the Third Ward and one from the Fifth Ward, to be the successors of the present Councilmen, whose terms of
office expire the second Monday in January, 1923. The terms of office of said Councilmen shall be two years from the second Monday in January following their election. Thereafter three Councilmen shall be elected each year in the manner set forth above to succeed those whose terms of office expire, thus securing a rotation in office and giving each Ward the opportunity of electing a Councilman at Large every two years. Elections.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That if for any reason or cause an election is not held on the first Monday in December, as herein provided, the Mayor shall fix another date immediately on which said election shall be held and shall publish notice thereof in the official gazette of Dougherty County, Georgia, at least once, fifteen days prior to the date so fixed for said election. The same rules and regulations governing the election set for the first Monday in each December shall govern and control the election held on the date fixed by the Mayor as above provided. In the meantime, Councilmen in office shall continue to hold office until their successors are elected and qualified. Failure to hold election.

Sec. 5. Vacancies in the office of Councilmen shall be filled as provided in the new charter of the City of Albany enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia in 1917 (Acts, 1917, Pages 454 to 496), except that no person shall be eligible for election unless he be a resident of the Ward in which the vacancy occurs. Vacancies.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That no person shall be eligible to represent any Ward unless he has been a bona fide resident thereof at least three months prior to the election at which he offers himself as candidate. If any Councilman shall remove his domicile from his Ward during his term of office, this shall operate to cause a vacancy in the office of Councilman from that Ward. Eligibility.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That no voter shall be eligible to vote for a Councilman of any Ward unless he has had his domicile bona fide in said Ward at least three months immediately preceding said election, and no voter can vote for any candidate for Council except a candidate from the Ward in which said voter resides and except a candidate for the city at large. Voters' qualifications.

Sec. 8. Be it enacted, That the place of holding all municipal elections of every kind in said City of Albany shall be at the Court House or City Hall, either or both, and also at any other places or precincts designated by the Mayor and City Council as they may deem expedient. Said Mayor and Council may, if they see fit, establish a voting precinct in any Ward for any election. Any voter entitled to vote at any place or precinct shall have the right to vote his entire ticket at that place or precinct. Elections, where held.

In no event shall there be less than three voting places at any election for City Councilmen where there is opposition to each candidate in the race. Whenever there are two or more candidates for Councilmen in any Ward a separate voting place shall be established for the voters of said Ward either in said Ward or at the Court House or at the City Hall.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That all voters for Councilmen shall be registered under the same rules and regulations as now exist for registration for elections in said City of Albany except that the registrar shall keep an accurate record of said voters by Wards. Said records shall consist of a registration book in which the voters of the City of Albany shall register by Wards from which the voting lists shall be made. Registration of voters.

Sec. 10. The managers of any election contemplated by this Act shall be appointed as now provided by said charter of the City of Albany, for the appointment of
managers, but whenever a voting precinct is established for any Ward as contemplated by this Act, the managers of such election shall be residents of said Ward and qualified voters therein. The duties of said managers of elections by the charter of the City of Albany. The managers of each voting precinct shall appoint three clerks as specified in said charter of the City of Albany. Election managers.
Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to incorporate the Town of Aldora, in the County of Pike, approved August 14th, 1906, by providing for the appointment by the Judge of the Superior Court of Lamar County of three Commissioners to govern said town instead of a Mayor and the Council as now provided, to strike out the words Mayor and Council, or Council, where they appear in said Act and insert the words Commissioner or Recorder. To provide for the election by said Commissioners of a Recorder for said town, to define his powers, and also to fix the terms of office of said Commissioners and Recorder, and the amount of their salaries, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same:

Section 1. That from and after the passage of this Act that Section Two of the above decided Act be amended as follows: In said sections to strike out the words
Mayor and (3) three Councilmen in the second line be stricken and the words three Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof. That the words Mayor and Council in the third line of said section to be stricken and the words Commissioners inserted in lieu thereof. That the words Mayor and Council in the fifth line of said section be stricken and the words Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: That the Municipal Government of said town shall be vested in three Commissioners who shall be known as Commissioners of said town and under the corporate name of the Town of Aldora as aforesaid, said Commissioners shall have perpetual succession, and the right and title to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with, and to purchase and hold such real and personal property as may be needful for the good order, government and welfare of said town, and to exercise such other rights, functions, privileges and immunities as belong to municipal corporations generally under the law. Act of 1906, sec. 2 amended. To be read. Three commissioners. General powers.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the words Mayor and Council in the second line of Section Three of said recited Act be stricken and the words Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof. Act of 1906, sec. 3 amended.

That the word Mayor in the sixth line of said section be stricken and the word Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof. That the words Mayor and Council in the seventh line of said section be stricken and the words Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof. That in the twelfth line of said section after the word town there be inserted the words said Commissioners shall also elect a Recorder for said town. That in the thirteenth line of said section the words Mayor and Council be stricken and the word Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof.
That in line fifteen of said section strike out the words Mayor and Council and the word Commissioners be inserted in lieu thereof.

That in the sixteenth line of said section before the word Clerk insert the word Recorder, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Be it enacted, That the corporate powers of said town shall be exercised by said Commissioners, or by officers and agents under their authority, except when otherwise provided. They shall also elect a Clerk and Treasurer and a Marshal, each of whom when elected shall enter into a bond with sufficient sureties, approved by the Commissioners, in such penal sum as the Commissioners may prescribe, payable to the corporation and conditioned to faithfully discharge their duties as prescribed by the charter and ordinances of said town, and to collect and pay over all the taxes, fines, forfeitures and other incomes of said town, and to account for all moneys and property that may come into their hands belonging to said town and said officers shall continue in office during the pleasure of the Commissioners, and perform the duties as prescribed by the said body or as may be provided therein. Said Commissioners shall by ordinance prescribe the duties of said Recorder, Clerk and Treasurer and Marshal, as well as any other officers or agents appointed by them. To be read. City officers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said Commissioners shall be appointed by the Judge of the Superior Court of the County of Lamar as soon as practicable after the passage of this Act. One shall be appointed for three years, one for two years and one for one year from January 1st, 1922, who shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. All appointments thereafter shall be for the term of three years except appointment to fill vacancies which shall be for the unexpired term. Commissioners' appointments and terms.

Said Commissioners as well as the other officers of said town, shall each, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully discharge the duties of his office to the best of his skill and knowledge, without fear, favor or affection, and to the best interest of said town, which oath shall be made before any person authorized by law to administer oaths and be filed with the Clerk and Treasurer of said town. That so much of Section Four of said Act as related to the election of the Mayor and Councilmen for said town be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Oath of office.
Said Commissioners shall elect one of their number Chairman, who shall preside over their meetings. Chairman.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That Sections 695, 696, 697, 698, 699, 700, 701, 702, 703, 704, 705, 706, 707, 708, 709, 710, 717, 718, 719, 720, 721, and 722 of Volume 1 the Code of Georgia of 1895, be, and the same are, hereby incorporated in this Act and made a part hereof, and the provision thereof and the powers conferred thereby are hereby bestowed upon said Town of Aldora, and the Commissioners and Recorder of said town instead of the Mayor, Mayor and Council or Council of said town. Code sections incorporated.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said Commissioners shall elect a Recorder for said town who shall have jurisdiction to try all offenders against the ordinances of said town and hold his Court as often as may be necessary for that purpose. He shall have authority to impose fines not exceeding one hundred dollars or imprison offenders in the town prison or common jail of Lamar County or labor on the streets of said town not exceeding ninety days, to punish witnesses for non-attendance or disobeying the processes of said Court. Said Recorder is hereby authorized to issue warrants for the arrest of all persons charged upon affidavit made before him with having committed within the limits of said town
offenses against penal law of this State, to take examination of such persons and the same to discharge or commit to prison or let to bail according to law, to answer such charge before the Court having jurisdiction in the same manner as Justices of the Peace of this State has or may have by law, which warrants shall be addressed to the Marshal, Deputy Marshal of said town and to the Sheriffs, Deputy Sheriffs or Constables of said State to execute the same. Recorder.
In the absence or disqualification of the Recorder, the Chairman of the Commissioners of said town may preside in his stead and exercise all the powers of said Recorder. Substitute.

Sec. 6. That Section Seven of said Act be amended by striking out the words Mayor and Council in the first line of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the word Commissioners, also strike out the words Mayor and Council in the third line of Section Eight of said Act and insert in lieu thereof the word Commissioner. Also strike out the words Mayor and Council in Section Nine of said Act and insert the word Commissioner in lieu thereof. Further amendments.

Also strike out the words Mayor or any member of said Council in the second and third lines of Section Ten of said Act and insert the words any one of said Commissioners. Also strike out the word Mayor's in the last line of said Section Ten and insert the word Recorder's.
Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That Sections 11 and 12 and 13 of the above recited Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Act of 1906, secs. 11, 12, 13 stricken.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the words Mayor and Council in the third line of Section 14 of said Act be stricken and the word Commissioner inserted in lieu thereof. Sec. 14 amended.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AMERICUS, CITY OF; ARBITRATION OF TAX VALUES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 10, 1920, entitled An Act to amend an Act approved November 11, 1889, and to amend, revise and consolidate the several Acts granting corporate authority to the City of Americus; to confer additional power upon the Mayor and City Council of Americus; to extend the corporate limits of said city and for other purposes, so as to provide for the arbitration of tax values by owners of property where the value is fixed by a Board of Assessors of Tax Returns, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act that:

Section 1. That an Act approved August 10, 1920, entitled an Act approved November 11, 1889, entitled an Act to revise and consolidate the several Acts granting corporate authority to the City of Americus, etc., be amended by striking the three last unnumbered sections following sub-Section 3 and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to-wit: Act of1920 amended.

That any tax payer dissatisfied with the action of said Board of Assessors of Tax Returns may within ten days
after receiving written notice from said Board notify the Clerk and Treasurer of the City of Americus in writtime furnish the Clerk and Treasurer the name of his property as fixed by the Board of Tax Assessors and that he desires to arbitrate the same and at the same time furnish the Cler kand Treasurer the name of his arbitrator; upon the filing of such written notice with the Clerk and Treasurer he will immediately notify the Board of Assessors and such Assessors will name an arbitrator to represent the city and should such two arbitrators fail to agree upon a value, they will then name the third man and the three of them will have the right to subpoena witnesses for the purpose of procuring such information as may be necessary to arrive at the true value of such property, which hearing will be had and the decision made by such arbitrators within twenty days from the date of the selection of the third arbitrator. Notification of objection. Arbitrators.

That the decision of such arbitrators when made up shall be filed with the City Clerk and Treasurer and attached to the return of the tax payer and shall then become final as to the value of such property for that year. Decision filed.

That the posting or mailing of any notice provided for herein in a correctly addressed stamped envelope or card shall be full compliance with the foregoing requirements relative to the giving of notice.
Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Athens and other Acts amendatory thereof, approved August 24th, 1872, so as to provide for an additional Ward in said city to be known as Ward Number Five, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 1 of the Act above referred to, and the various Acts amendatory thereof, be amended as follows: By striking from the seventh line thereof the word eight and inserting in lieu thereof the word ten, so that said portion of said section, as amended, shall read: And the municipal government of the City of Athens shall consist of a Mayor and ten Aldermen. Act of 1872 amended. Ten aldermen.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 2 of the Act referred to in the caption, to-wit, an Act entitled An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Athens, and the various Acts amendatory thereof, approved August 24th, 1872, be, and the same is, hereby amended so as to provide for a Fifth Ward in the City of Athens, which shall consist of that portion of the City of Athens lying within the boundaries hereinafter named. Five wards.
Sec. 3. That said Ward Number Five shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying in the following boundaries, to-wit: Description of ward five.

Beginning at the center of the intersection of Chase street and Hancoc kavenue in said city, and running thence in a northerly direction along the center of said Chase street to Oneta street; thence in a northeasterly
direction, along the center of Oneta street to the center of Barber street; thence along the center of Barber street in a northwesterly direction to the new city limits; thence along the new city limits in a southerly direction to the center of Broad street; thence along the center of Broad street, in a direction east by south, to the center of Hancock avenue; thence along the center of Hancock avenue, in a northerly direction to the beginning point.
Sec. 4. Said Section 2 of said Act is further amended so that the description of Ward Number 3 shall be as follows: Description of ward three.

Ward Number 3 shall consist of that portion of the City of Athens beginning at the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, and extending in a westerly direction along the center of Hancock avenue to the center of its intersection with Broad street; thence along the center of Broad street in a westerly direction to the new city limits; thence in a southerly direction along said new city limits to the center of South Lumpkin street; thence along the center of South Lumpkin street in a northerly direction to the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, the beginning point.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 2 of said Act be further amended so that the description of Ward Number Four shall read as follows: Description of ward four.

Ward Number Four shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street and extending thence in a northerly direction, along the center of North Lumpkin street to the city limits; thence in a southwesterly direction along said city limits to the center of Barber street; thence in a southerly direction, along the center
of Barber street, to the center of Oneta street; thence along the center of Oneta street in a southwesterly direction to the center of Chase street; thence in a southerly direction, along the center of Chase street, to the center of Hancock avenue; thence in a northeasterly direction, along the center of Hancock avenue, to the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, the same being the beginning point.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Section 2 of said Act be amended by striking from the second line of said section the word four and inserting in lieu thereof the word five. Further amendment.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Section 2 of said Act be further amended by adding after the words city limits in the sixteenth line thereof, and before the word each the following: Description of ward five

Ward Number Five shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying in the following boundaries: Beginning at the center of the intersection of Chase street and Hancock avenue in said city, and running thence in a northerly direction, along the center of said Chase street to Oneta street; thence in a northeasterly direction, along the center of Oneta street, to Barber street, thence along the center of Barber street in a northwesterly direction, to the new city limits; thence with the new city limits, in a southerly direction, to the center of Broad street; thence along the center of Broad street, in a direction cast by south, to the center of Hancock avenue; thence along the center of Hancock avenue in a northeasterly direction to the beginning point.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Section 2 of said Act be further amended as follows: By adding, after the word to in the seventh line thereof, and before the word city in the
eighth line the word old, and by adding, after the word limits in the eighth line of said section the following: New territorial limits

blockquote.p: From thence in a westerly direction, along the old city limits, to its intersection with the Central of Georgia Railroad; thence along the center of said railroad, in a southwesterly direction, to its intersection with new city limits.

law.p: Sec. 9. So that said Section Two of said Act, as amended, shall read: Act of 1872, sec. 2 read.

blockquote.p:
Section 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said City of Athens shall be divided into five Wards, as follows: Ward Number One shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying east of a line through the center of Thomas street indefinitely extended north, and running south until Thomas street runs into the street leading to the new cemetery; thence in a straight line through the center of the last mentioned street extended to the old city limits; from thence in a westerly direction, along the old city limits to its intersection with the Central of Georgia Railroad; thence along the center of said railroad in a southwesterly direction to its intersection with new city limits. Ward Number Two shall consist of all that portion of the city lying west of said last mentioned line and east of a line through Lumpkin street as it runs in said city indefinitely extended. Ward Number Three shall consist of that portion of the City of Athens beginning at the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, and extending in a westerly direction along the center of Hancock avenue to the center of its intersection with Broad street; thence along the center of Broad street in a westerly direction to the new city limits; thence in a southerly direction, along said new city limits to the center of South Lumpkin street; thence along
the center of South Lumpkin street, in a northerly direction, to the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, the beginning corner. Ward Number Four shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, and extending thence in a northerly direction, along the center of North Lumpkin street to the city limits; thence in a southwesterly direction, along said city limits, to the center of Barber street, thence in a southerly direction, along the center of Barber street, to the center of Oneta street; thence along the center of Oneta street in a southwesterly direction, to the center of Chase street; thence in a southerly direction, along the center of Chase street, to the center of Hancock avenue; thence in a northeasterly direction, along the center of Hancock avenue to the center of the intersection of Hancock avenue and Lumpkin street, the same being the beginning point. Ward Number Five shall consist of all that portion of the City of Athens lying in the following boundaries: Beginning at the center of the intersection of Chase street and Hancock avenue in said city and running thence in a northerly direction along the center of said Chase street to Oneta street, thence in a northeasterly direction along the center of Oneta street to Barber street, thence along the center of Barber street in a northwesterly direction to the new city limits, thence with the new city limits in a southerly direction, to Broad street, thence along the center of Broad street in a direction east by south, to Hancock avenue, thence along the center of Hancock avenue in a northerly direction to the beginning point.

law.p: Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That said Ward Number Five shall be entitled to two Aldermen, who shall be members of the City Council of the City of Athens. Aldermen from ward five.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at the general election to be held for the election of Aldermen in the City of Athens for the years 1922 and 1923 two Aldermen shall be elected to represent said Fifth Ward, one for one year, beginning January 1st, 1922, and one for two years, beginning January 1st, 1922. Election.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That of the candidates running for such representation as Alderman from said Fifth Ward, as aforesaid, in said general election the candidate receiving the highest number of votes shall be entitled to represent said Fifth Ward as Alderman for said two-year term, and the candidate receiving the next highest number of votes shall be entitled to represent said Fifth Ward for said one-year term. Terms.
Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all other respects said election shall be held under existing laws and the returns thereof made as now provided by law. Returns.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That until January 1st, 1922, the Aldermen now representing the Third Ward in the City of Athens shall continue to represent that portion of the Fifth Ward hereby created which is taken from said Third Ward; and the Alderman now representing the Fourth Ward in said City of Athens shall continue to represent that portion of the Fifth Ward which is hereby created which is taken from the Fourth Ward in said City of Athens. Interim representation.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is enacted by authority of the same, That an Act establishing a new charter for the City of Atlanta, approved February 28th, 1874, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows:

Section 1. That females having been qualified by the Federal Constitution to vote, are hereby made eligible for election to and service on the Board of Education of the city. Females on board of education.

Sec. 1-A. Zoning Regulations. The Mayor and General Council may, in the interest of the public health, safety, order, convenience, comfort, prosperity or general welfare, adopt by ordinance a plan or plans for the districting or zoning of the city for the purpose of regulating the location of trades, industries, apartment houses, dwellings or other uses of property, or for the purpose of regulating the height of buildings or other structures, or the area or dimensions of the lots or of the yards used in connection with buildings or other structures, or for the purpose of regulating the alignment of buildings or other structures near street frontages. The zoning regulations may be based upon any one or more of the purposes above described. The city may be divided into such number of zones or districts and such districts may be of such shape and area as the Mayor and General Council shall deem best suited to accomplish the purposes of the zoning regulations. In the determination
and establishment of districts and regulations, classifications may be based on the nature or character of the trade, industry, profession or other activity conducted or to be conducted upon the premises, the number of persons, families, or other group units to reside in or use buildings, the public, quasi-public or private nature of the use of premises or upon any other basis or bases revelant to the promotion of the public health, safety, order, morals, convenience, prosperity or welfare. Zoning regulations.

Sec. 1-B. Residence Sections. For the reasons above stated, said Mayor and General Council shall have the further right and power in any districts proposed to be set aside primarily for residence purposes to further classify the use thereof and the class or classes of residents to be housed therein, and to provide therein such other and similar regulations and restrictions as shall secure the peace and good order of the city and the residents thereof. No such ordinance or amendment thereto authorized by either of the above sections shall be adopted except by three-fourths vote of the General Council. Residence sections.

Sec. 1-C. Preparation of Plan. Notice and hearing. Ordinance. No ordinance adopting zoning regulations as above authorized shall be passed by the Mayor and General Council until after a comprehensive plan for the zoning of the city has been prepared and submitted to the Mayor and General Council by the City Planning Commission. Whenever the City Planning Commission shall certify to the Mayor and General Council a plan for the zoning of the city, the Mayor and General Council shall hold a public hearing thereon and shall give thirty days' notice of the time and place thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city; and during said thirty days, a copy of such plan and proposed ordinances shall be on file for public examination in the
office of the City Planning Commission or any such other office as may be designated by the Mayor and General Council. No ordinance, measure or regulation which violates, differs or departs from the plan or report submitted by the City Planning Commission shall take effect unless passed by a three-fourths vote of the Mayor and General Council. Plan for zoning. Hearing. Ordinance.
