At the heads or tops of each of said ballots shall be printed the words Official Ballot for Commission Manager Government, and there shall be endorsed underneath said language the signature of the Mayor, and for this purpose he may use a stamp with a fac-simile of his signature impressed thereon.
No ticket, vote or ballot shall be used, voted or counted in said election, unless the same is procured by the voter from the managers and complies with the above requirements in substantial form.
There shall be prepared and furnished to the managers a sufficient number of tickets or ballots, as provided above, in order to supply all of the voters qualified to vote in said election.
If any voter should spoil a ballot he shall be entitled to receive a new ballot provided he returns to the manager or managers the unused or spoiled ballot.

Before depositing any ballot or ticket in the box or permitting any ticket or ballot to be deposited in the box the manager or managers must see that the ticket or ballot attempted to be voted by the voter bears the same designation and the same number as the stub which bears the name of the particular voter.

No printer, publisher or other person engaged by the Mayor to provide tickets or ballots for said election shall deliver or furnish a ballot or ballots, or any likeness of the same, to any person other than said managers or on their written order, and no person engaged by such printer or publisher or other person to aid or assist in the printing or preparation of said ballots shall retain, or deliver, or furnish a ticket or ballot or any likeness of the same, to any person other than said managers or on their written order, nor shall any person, who, having in any manner procured an official ballot or likeness thereof, furnish, deliver or give the same to any one other than one of said managers. Provided, however, that the Mayor shall publish the form of the ballot with instructions as to how to mark the same in a newspaper or newspapers of general circulation in said city, in each issue of such newspaper or newspapers, for ten days prior to said election.

Any person who knowingly and wilfully violates any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in Section 1065 of the Penal Code of 1910. Penalty for violation.

Sec. 44. If the majority of those voting in said special election to be held on the 27th day of September, 1921, shall vote for Commission Manager Government, then on the second Saturday of December, 1921, there shall be held an election for the election of the five Commissioners of the City of Columbus to constitute the Commission created by this Act. Such election shall be held by managers and clerks appointed by the Mayor and Aldermen and they shall hold the said election under the same laws and regulations as now govern elections for Mayor and Aldermen of said City of Columbus. The managers shall report the result of said election to the Mayor and Aldermen as the results of the city elections are reported and the Mayor and Aldermen shall thereafter at their first meeting thereafter held, whether regular or called, declare the five persons who shall receive the highest number of votes cast at such election as Commissioners. It shall be determined by lot among themselves which of the five candidates elected shall respectively hold office for the respective terms of one, two, three, four and five years, beginning on the first Monday in January, 1922, and until their successors are chosen and qualified. Election of commission.

Sec. 45. On the second Saturday of December of each year thereafter a general, or regular, election shall be held to elect a Commissioner for a full term of five years to succeed the one whose term is about to expire and at such regular election, there shall also be elected Commissioners to fill unexpired terms temporarily filled by the Commission or the Governor more than thirty (30) days prior to such election. The term of each Commissioner elected at such regular election shall begin on the first Monday in January following the election. Such
elections shall be held under the laws, rules and regulations now governing regular elections held for the election of the Mayor and Aldermen of the said City of Columbus; provided, however, the Commissioners shall, at their option, designate and appoint any three persons they see fit to serve as registrars of the City of Columbus in lieu of the City Clerk (who likewise shall serve in lieu of the former Clerk of Council), the City Treasurer, and the City Marshal. Successors.

Sec. 46. All special elections, and all special initiative, referendum and recall elections of the City of Columbus shall be held under the laws, rules and regulations now governing special elections of said city, except as otherwise provided by this Act, and all initiative, referendum and recall elections held at the same time as a general election for Commissioners shall be held under the laws, rules and regulations now governing regular elections held for the election of the Mayor and Aldermen of said city, except as otherwise provided by this Act. Special elections.

Sec. 47. The Acts of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia providing that political parties or organizations shall nominate their candidates for all offices of the City of Columbus which are now, or which may hereafter be elected by the people of the City of Columbus, by primary elections, shall remain of full force and effect, and all provisions thereof shall govern primary elections held by such political parties or organizations for the nomination of candidates for the offices of Commissioners created by this Act. Primaries.

Sec. 48 (A) Any proposed ordinances, including ordinances for the repeal or amendment of an ordinance then in effect, may be submitted to the City Commission by petition signed by at least five per cent. of the total number of registered voters in the municipality as shown by the official registration list filed for the general election of Commissioner last held. All petitions circulated
with respect to any proposed ordinance shall be uniform in character, shall contain the proposed ordinance in full, and shall have printed or written thereon the name and addresses of at least five qualified voters who shall be officially regarded as filing the petition and shall constitute a committee of the petitioners for the purpose hereinafter named. Each signer of a petition shall sign his name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place on the petition opposite his name the date of his signature and his place of residence by street and number. The signatures of any such petition need not all be appended to one paper, but to each such paper there shall be attached an affidavit by the circulator thereof, stating the number of signers to such part of the petition and that each signature appended to the paper is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be and that it was made in the presence of the affiant on the date indicated. Initiative. Petitions.

(B) All papers comprising a petition shall be assembled and filed with the City Clerk as one instrument within sixty (60) days from the date of the first signature thereon, and when so filed, the Clerk shall submit the same to the City Commission at its next regular meeting and provision shall be made for public hearings upon the proposed ordinance. How filed.

(C) The City Commission shall at once proceed to consider such petition and shall take final action thereon within thirty (30) days from the date of submission. If the City Commission rejects the proposed ordinance, or passes it in a different form from that set forth in the petition, or fails to act finally upon it within the time stated, then, if within five days thereafter the committee of the petitioners file with the City Clerk written demand so to do, the City Clerk shall at once upon the expiration of said five days cause three printed or typewritten copies of such petition, without the signatures, to be made. He shall cause said three copies of such petition
to be placed on file in his office, and provide facilities for their signing the same, and shall immediately cause notice to be published in some newspaper of general circulation in the city of the placing of such copies of such petition shall remain on file in the office of the City Clerk for a period of twenty days, during which time any of them may be signed by a qualified voter of the city in person, but not by agent or attorney. Each signer of any such copy shall sign his name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place thereafter his residence by street and number. If during said time qualified voters equal or exceeding twenty-five per cent. of the qualified voters in the municipality as shown by the official registration list filed for the general election of Commissioner last held shall sign such copies of said petition, the Clerk shall forthwith certify such fact to the Commission. Action of commission.

(D) If an election is to be held not more than three months nor less than thirty days after the aforesaid certification by the Clerk, such proposed ordinance shall be submitted to a vote of the qualified voters at such election. If no election is to be held within the time aforesaid, the Commission shall provide for submitting the proposed ordinance to the qualified voters at a special election to be held not later than sixty days nor earlier than thirty days after the publication of such notice, if the petition for such ordinances and the petition for such election so demand, and if the signers of the said copies of said petition amount in the aggregate to at least thirty per cent. of the registered voters of the city, otherwise the same shall be submitted at the next general or special city election. At least ten days before any such election the City Clerk shall cause such proposed ordinance to be published. Referendum.

(E) The ballots used when voting upon any such proposed ordinance shall state the title of the ordinance to be voted on and below it the two propositions, For the
Ordinance and Against the Ordinance. Those voting for the ordinance shall draw a mark through the words, Against the Ordinance, and those voting against the ordinance shall draw a mark through the words, For the Ordinance. If a majority of the qualified voters voting on any such proposed ordinance shall vote in favor thereof, it shall thereupon become an ordinance of the city. Ballots.

(F) Before any ordinance so proposed shall be submitted to the City Commission, it shall first be approved as to its form and legal validity by the City Attorney, whose duty it shall be to draft such proposed ordinance in the proper legal language, and to render such other service to persons desiring to propose such ordinances as shall be necessary to make the same proper for consideration by the City Commission. Attorney's approval.

(G) No ordinance adopted by an electoral vote, as hereinbefore provided, can be repealed or amended except by an electoral vote. But an ordinance to repeal or amend any such ordinance may, by resolution of the City Commission be submitted to an electoral vote at any general election, or at any special municipal election called for some other purpose, provided notice of the intention so to do be published by the City Commission not more than sixty days nor less than thirty days prior to such election. If an amendment is proposed, such notice shall contain the proposed amendment in full. Such submission shall be in the same manner, and the vote shall have the same effect as in cases of ordinances submitted to an election by popular petition. Amending and repeal.

Sec. 49 (A). No ordinance passed by the City Commission, unless it be an emergency measure, or the annual appropriation ordinance, shall go into effect until thirty days after its final passage. If, at any time within said thirty days, an unsigned petition requesting that such ordinance be repealed or amended as stated in
the petition, be filed with the City Clerk, and said petition after the filing of the same and within said thirty days, is therein the office of said City Clerk signed by qualified voters amounting to or exceeding twenty-five per cent. of qualified voters as shown by the official registration list filed for the general election of Commissioner last held, the City Clerk shall, thereupon, certify said fact to the Commission and the ordinance shall not become operative until the steps indicated herein have been taken. Such petition shall have stated therein the names and addresses of at least five qualified voters as a committee to represent the petitioners. Referendum petitions need not contain the text of the ordinance or ordinances the repeal of which is sought; but shall contain the proposed amendment, if an amendment is demanded, and shall be subject in all other respects to the requirements for petitions submitting proposed ordinances to the City Commission. Ballots used in referendum elections shall conform in all respects to those provided for in Paragraph (E), Section 48, of this Act. Ordinances, when effective. Petition for repeal.

(B) At the next meeting of the Commission after said certification by the Clerk, the City Commission shall proceed to reconsider the ordinance. If within thirty days after the date of such certification by the Clerk, the ordinance be not repealed or amended as requested, the City Commission shall provide for submitting the proposed repeal or amendment to a vote of the qualified voters, provided a majority of the committee named in the petition to represent the petitioners shall, by writing filed with the City Clerk within twenty days after the expiration of said thirty days, so require. In so doing the City Commission shall be governed by the provisions of Paragraph (D), Section 48, of this Act respecting the time of submission and the manner of voting on ordinances proposed to the City Commission by petition, excepting that the City Commission may call, and fix the time for a special election for such purposes if in its judgment
the public interests will be prejudiced by delay. If, when submitted to a vote of the qualified voters, such repeal or amendment be approved by a majority of those voting thereon, it shall thereupon go into effect as an ordinance of the city; but if any such amendment is clearly separable from the remainder of the ordinance and does not materially affect the other provisions of such ordinance, all sections of the ordinance except that sought to be amended and those dependent thereon shall take effect as though no referendum of any portion of the ordinance had been contemplated; or if any such amendment or repeal of the ordinance is not approved by a majority of those voting therein, then the ordinance passed by the Commission shall at once take effect. Reconsideration. Referendum.

(C) Ordinances submitted to the City Commission by initiative petition and passed by the City Commission without change or passed in an amended form and not required to be submitted to a vote of the qualified voters by the committee of the petitioners, shall be subject to the referendum in the same manner as other ordinances. If the provisions of two or more ordinances adopted or approved at the same election conflict, the ordinance receiving the highest affirmative vote shall prevail. Ordinances subject to referendum.

(D) Ordinances passed as emergency measures shall be subject to referendum in like manner as other ordinances except that they shall go into effect at the time indicated in such ordinances. If, when submitted to a vote of the qualified voters, an emergency measure be not approved by a majority of those voting thereon it shall be considered repealed as regards any further action thereunder, but such measure repealed shall be deemed sufficient authority for payment in accordance with the ordinance of any expense incurred previous to the referendum vote thereon. Emergency measures.

(E) In case a petition be filed requiring that a measure passed by the City Commission providing for an expenditure
of money, a bond issue, or a public improvement be submitted to a vote of the qualified voters, all steps preliminary to such actual expenditures, actual is sue of bonds, or actual execution of a contract for such improvement, may be taken prior to the election. Appropriations, etc.
Sec. 50 (A). Any or all members of the City Commission may be removed from office by the qualified voters by the following procedure: Recall.

A petition for the recall of the Commissioner, or Commissioners, designated, signed by at least five per cent. of the qualified voters of the city, as shown by the official registration list filed for the general election of Commissioner last held, and containing a statement in not more than two hundred words of the grounds of the recall shall be filed with the City Clerk, who shall forthwith notify the Commissioner or Commissioners sought to be removed, and he or they within five days after such notice, may file with such Clerk a defensive statement in not exceeding two hundred words. The City Clerk shall at once upon the expiration of said five days cause three printed or typewritten copies of such petition without the signatures, to be made, and to each of them shall attach a printed or typewritten copy of such defensive statement, if one is furnished him within the time provided. He shall cause the copies of such petition to be placed on file in his office, and provide facilities for their signing the same. The City Clerk shall immediately cause notice to be published in some newspaper of general circulation in the city of the placing of such copies of such petition. Such copies of such petition shall remain on file in the office of the City Clerk for a period of thirty days, during which time any of them may be signed by a qualified voter of the city in person, but not by agent or attorney. Each signer of any such copy shall sign his name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place thereafter his residence by street and number. Petition.

(B) At the expiration of said period of thirty days the City Clerk shall assemble the three copies in his office as one instrument and shall examine the same and ascertain and certify thereon whether the signatures thereto amount to at least twenty-five per cent. of the registered voters as shown by the official registration list filed for the general election of the Commissioners last held. If such signatures do amount to such per cent., he shall at once serve notice of that fact upon the Commissioner or Commissioners designated in the petition, and also deliver to the Commission a copy of the original petition with his certificate as to the percentage of qualified voters who signed the same and a certificate as to the date of his last mentioned notice to the Commissioner or Commissioners designated in the petition. How filed.

(C) If the Commissioner or Commissioners, or any of them, designated in the petition, file with the City Clerk within five days after the last mentioned notice from the City Clerk, his or their written resignation, the Clerk shall at once notify the Commission of that fact, and such resignation shall be irrevocable and the Commission shall proceed to fill the vacancy. In the absence of any such resignation, the Commission shall forthwith order and fix a day for holding a recall election for the removal of those not resigning. In the event that recall petitions require at one and the same time a recall election for more than two of the Commissioners, then such recall election shall be ordered by the City Clerk and he shall fix a day for holding such election and shall have and exercise all power and authority relative to holding and conducting such election as would otherwise be possessed by the Commission. Any such recall election shall be held not less than thirty nor more than sixty days after the expiration of the period of five days last mentioned and at the same time as any other general or special election held within such period; but if no such election
be held within such period the Commission, or, in event of its disqualification, the City Clerk shall call a special election to be held within the period aforesaid. Resignation. Recall election.
(D) The ballots at such election shall conform to the following requirements, with respect to each person whose removal is sought the question shall be submitted: Ballots.

(E) In any such election, if a majority of the votes cast on the question of removal of any Commissioner is affirmative, the person whose removal is sought shall thereupon be deemed removed from office upon the announcement of the official return of that election, and the vacancy caused by such recall shall be filled by the remainder of the City Commission. If, however, an election is held for the recall of more than one Commissioner, candidates to succeed them for their unexpired term shall be voted upon at the same election. Result, when effective.

(F) Candidates shall not be voted for to succeed any particular Commissioner; but if only one Commissioner is removed at such election, the candidate at such election receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared elected to fill the vacancy, and if more than one Commissioner is removed at such election, such candidates equal in number to the number of Commissioners removed shall be declared elected to fill the vacancies; and among the successful candidates the respective terms of office shall be determined by lot by the City Attorney. Successors.

(G) No proceedings for the recall of all of the members of the City Commission at the same election shall be defeated in whole or in part by the resignation of any or all of them, but upon the resignation of any of them the City Commission, except as herein otherwise provided, shall have power to fill the vacancy until a successor is elected, and the proceedings for the recall and the election of successors shall continue and have the same effect as though there had been no resignation. Recall of all commissioners.

(H) No petition to recall any Commissioner shall be filed within six months after he takes office. No person removed by recall shall be eligible to be elected or appointed upon or for a period of two years after the date of such recall. The City Clerk shall preserve in his office all papers comprising or connected with a petition for a recall for a period of one year after same were filed. The method of removal herein provided for is cumulative of such other methods as will, are, or may be, provided by law. Petition, when filed. Re-election.

(I) No person shall falsely impersonate another or purposely write his name or residence falsely in the signing of any petition for initiative, referendum, or recall, or forge any name thereto or sign any such paper with knowledge that he is not a qualified voter of the city, qualified at the time of such signing to vote, nothing to the contrary thereafter intervening, at the next
and ensuing general election for Commissioner. No person shall sign, or knowingly permit to be signed, any petition for initiative referendum or recall at any place other than at the place hereinbefore designated for the signing of such petitions; nor shall any person employ or pay another, or accept employment or payment, for circulating any initiative, referendum or recall petition upon the basis of the number of signatures procured thereto. Any person violating any provisions of this paragraph of this Act shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction be punished as provided by Section 1065 of the Criminal Code of the State of Georgia. Personation, etc. Penalty.

Sec. 51. If the majority of those voting in said special election to be held on the 27th day of September, 1921, shall vote for Commission Manager Government, then the general election for Mayor and Aldermen in December, 1921, shall not be held, but the present Mayor and Aldermen of said City of Columbus shall continue in office, performing all of their respective and joint duties until the first Monday of January, 1922, and until the Commissioners elected under Section 44 of this Act shall have qualified; provided, however, that from and after the passage of this Act said Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall have no authority to pass any tax ordinances. Present governing body.

Sec. 52. If any section or part of a section of this Act shall for any reason be adjudged by any Court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, the same shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect of any other section or part of a section of this Act, but shall be confined in its operations to the section or part of a section directly involved in the controversy in which judgment shall have been rendered. Constitutional law.

Sec. 53. For the purpose of nominating and electing officers and all purposes connected therewith and for the purpose of exercising the powers of the city, as provided
herein, this Act shall take effect from the time of its approval by the electors of the city. For the purpose of establishing departments and officers and distributing the functions thereof and for all other purposes the Act shall take effect on the second day of January, 1922. Effective on ratification.
Sec. 54. Throughout this Act, language expressing the masculine gender shall be construed to include the feminine. Males and females.
Sec. 55. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Columbus in Muscogee County so as to create a Commission for the City of Columbus to be known as Parks and Playgrounds Commission, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That power and authority be, and the same is, hereby conferred upon the City of Columbus, a municipal corporation of Muscogee County, to create a Board of Commissioners to be known as the Parks and Playground Commission, to whom said city may delegate the management, operation and control of its parks, that is, such parks as it now has or may hereafter have and establish by ordinance, and said City of Columbus, by and through its Mayor and Board of Aldermen, shall have the right to fix the number of persons composing said Commission known as Parks and Playgrounds Commission, the qualifications necessary to become members
thereof, the time and manner of the election of said Commission, and invest said Commission with such power and authority respecting the management, operation, control and regulation of its parks that it now has or may hereafter establish in said city as said city may by ordinance or resolution consider proper and appropriate, and said city is further empowered to fix the number of persons composing said Commission and to provide that one or more of said Commissioners shall be a woman, and may further provide that the Mayor and Chairman of the Parks and Commons Commission of Council shall be ex-officio members of said Commission. Establishment.
Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CONYERS, CITY OF; QUALIFICATIONS OF VOTERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 24, 1881, and the Acts amendatory thereto approved August 21, 1891; to prescribe the qualifications for voters in the City of Conyers, Georgia, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Sec. 4 of the Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 24, 1881, incorporating the City of Conyers be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking the word male from Section 4 of the third line in said section, so that the same shall read when so amended as follows: And it is further enacted, That all persons voting at the elections provided for in this Act shall have the following qualifications, viz.: They must be citizens of the United States, twenty-one
years of age, who shall have resided in said city six months next preceding the election at which they offer, and they must register their names, as voters, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by said Mayor and Aldermen. Act of 1881 amended. To be read. Females eligible.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passage of this Sec. 2 of the Acts of the General Assembly approved Aug. 21, 1891, enlarging and defining the powers and duties of the Mayor and Aldermen and other officers of said city, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking the word him from line four of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the word them, and by striking the words shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on indictment and conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in Sec. 4310 of the Code of Georgia, and inserting in lieu thereof the words shall be guilty of disorderly conduct and, upon conviction therefor, shall be punished as prescribed in Sec. 123 of the charter of Conyers, Georgia, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That no person shall be permitted to vote at any of the elections of said city who has not paid all taxes, to-wit, State, county or said city, that has been required of them; and any person who shall vote at any of said elections without the payment of said taxes, or more than once at said election, or without being qualified to vote thereat, shall be guilty of disorderly conduct, and, upon conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in Sec. 123 of the charter of Conyers, Georgia. Act of 1891 amended. To be read. Illegal voting.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CORDELE WATER, LIGHT AND BOND COMMISSION.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the City of Cordele, by providing for and creating a Water, Light and Bond Commission for said city, said Commission to be clothed with full and exclusive power and authority as to the construction, operation and management and control of the waterworks system of said city, the sewerage system of said city, and the lighting system of said city, including bonds belonging to, or arising from, said departments, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act establishing a new charter for the City of Cordele, approved August 21st, 1911, and found on Pages 990 to 1042 inclusive, of the Acts of the General Assembly, 1911, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same are, hereby amended as follows: From and after the passage of this Act there shall be for the City of Cordele a Commission to be known and designated as the Water, Light and Bond Commission for the City of Cordele, which said Commission shall consist of three persons, residents of said city, and who shall be otherwise qualified to vote for members of the Board of Aldermen and Mayor of said city, and who shall hold office for a term of six years, except as hereinafter provided. Act of 1911 amended. Establishment. Three members.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That Jerry Slade, Fred Harder and B. M. Williams shall be and are authorized and constituted as Commissioners under this act, clothed with all of the powers and charged with all the duties hereinafter enumerated, their respective terms of office shall be as follows: The term of one of said Commissioners shall expire on the first day of January, 1923; the term of one shall expire on the first day of January, 1924,
and the term of one shall expire on the first day of January, 1925, the respective terms of each member to be determined by lot by the members of the Commission at the time of their organization under this Act. The successors to said persons, as Commissioners, shall be elected by the Mayor and City Council of Cordele at the time for the annual election of officers of said city, and in the same manner, except that one Commissioner shall be elected every year and each Commissioner, so elected, shall hold his office three years and until his successor shall be elected and qualified, the terms of said Commissioners beginning on the first day of January after election. Personnel. Terms.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all vacancies in said Commission by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, shall be filled by election by the Mayor and City Council of Cordele at the first regular meeting of that body after said vacancy occurs, provided such vacancy occurs more than five days prior to the meeting of Council; should any such vacancy occur within five days prior to the regular meeting of Council, then and in that event, action may be deferred by said Mayor and Council until the following meeting, in their discretion, as the exigencies of the occasion may demand. Vacancies.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That a member of said Commission shall be subject to impeachment and removal from office, in like manner and for like cause, as the Mayor and Aldermen of said city may be impeached and removed. Removal.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That before entering upon the discharge of their duties, said Commissioners shall take and subscribe a similar oath for the faithful discharge of their duties to the oath required of the Mayor and Aldermen of said city, which said oath shall be recorded on the minutes of the Mayor and City Council of Cordele by the Clerk of that body. Oath of office.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That immediately upon their organization, the members of the Commission shall elect a Chairman from one of their number who shall serve for the next year ensuing, as such Chairman, provided the Chairman first elected shall serve until the first day of January, 1923, all vacancies shall be filled in like manner, for the remainder of the unexpired term. Chairman.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by apthority aforesaid, That the Commissioners shall receive no compensation for their services, nor shall the Chairman thereof recive any compensation, and such Chairman in addiiton to performing the duties of a Commissioner, shall preside at all meetings of the Commission, be entitled to a vote upon all questions coming before the body, and perform any and all other services, and discharge such duties as may, from time be delegated to him by the Commission, and that are permissible under the provisions of this Act. All actual personal expenses incurred by members of said Board of Commissioners, while in the performance of their official duties, shall be paid from any funds that said Commission may have in hand, or that may come into their hands, and not otherwise appropriated. No compensation. Duties of chairman.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the regular meeting of said Commission shall be held at the Council Chamber in the City of Cordele at such time as may be designated by the Commission, but the time of meeting may be changed at any time, in the pleasure of the Commission. The Chairman may call special meetings, at any time, when the business of the Commission may require it, giving notice to all the members thereof in advance of any such meeting. Meetings.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Clerk and Treasurer of the City of Cordele shall be ex-officio Clerk and Treasurer of the Board of Commissioners, and it shall be his duty to attend all
meetings of said Board, to keep an accurate minute thereof, and to properly and fully record the same in a book to be furnished him and to be kept for that purpose; he shall also be required to receive and disburse all money handled or controlled by said Board of Commissioners, under proper orders therefrom; he shall keep an accurate account of all receipts and disbursements and submit the same to said Board of Commissioners whenever required so to do; he shall issue all processes necessary for the collection of all monies comnig under the jurisdiction of said Board, and shall perform any and all other duties in connection therewith, not herein specifically enumerated, as may be required of him by said Board of Commissioners. The oath and bond taken and given by him as Clerk and Treasurer of the City of Cordele shall be held and deemed to extend to, and cover his acts and doings as Clerk and Treasurer of this Board. No additional compensation shall be paid said Clerk by the Board of Commissioners, but his salary as Clerk and Treasurer of the City of Cordele shall be held and deemed to embrace and cover his compensation as ex-officio Clerk of this Board. Ex-officio clerk and treasurer.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the City Attorney of the City of Cordele shall, by virtue of his office, be attorney for the Water, Light and Bond Commission. His duties shall be to advise said Commission upon all matters touching the conduct of said Board when requested so to do, and to represent said Commission in all matters where the services of an attorney are needed. He shall receive for such service no compensation other than that as City Attorney for the City of Cordele. Attorney.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Water, Light and Bond Commission shall be vested with full and exclusive power and control over the waterworks and water and sewer system of the City of Cordele, all of the rights, powers and duties in
regard thereto, heretofore residing in the Mayor and City Council of Cordele, shall be, and is, hereby delegated to said Water, Light and Bond Commission, including full and exclusive power and authority to manage, control and operate the waterworks and water system for said city, to contract for and pay for all material and supplies used in connection with same, to employ and discharge all employees necessary in the maintenance and operation of same, to fix and pay their compensation and salaries, to contract for, and supervise all necessary repairs and additons thereto, and generally to have full and complete control and authority over the same and to do and perform any and all other such acts and things not specifically enumerated, as may be necessary or expedient in the management, control, maintenance and operation of the waterworks and sewerage system of said city. Powers. Water-works, etc.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Water, Light and Bond Commission shall be vested with full and complete power and control over the lighting system of said city, all of the powers and duties heretofore delegated to the Mayor and City Council of Cordele, shall be, and are, hereby vested in said Commission, such powers to include the right to build, construct, operate and maintain a municipal power and lighting plant to be operated by said municipality in connection with the waterworks of said city, the power to employ all labor and all assistance of every kind and character that may be necessary, to sign and perform all such contracts in connection therewith as may be necessary, as well as the power to discharge all persons employed by them, in the conduct of said business. Said Commission is also expressly authorized, on behalf of the City of Cordele, and in its name, to enter into and execute from time to time, as may be necessary, or expedient, contracts with public utility corporations, for lighting said city and the public buildings
thereof, having the same powers in that regard as have heretofore been exercised by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Cordele, the purpose of this act being to confer upon said Board exclusive power and jurisdiction over the lighting system of said city, and over any system that may hereafter be installed therein. Electric lights.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Water, Light and Bond Commission shall have full, complete and exclusive control and management over all monies arising from the operation of the waterworks, from the operation of any municipal light and power plant that may hereafter be installed, and from the sale of any and all bonds that may hereafter be issued and sold by the City of Cordele for any purpose whatever. Said Board shall be vested with full and exclusive power and authority in expending all sums of money that may arise from the sale of water, sewer or light bonds, and shall have full and complete control over the handling and investment of the sinking fund of said city, provided such funds are invested in accordance with the general laws of this State. Funds.

Sec. 14. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Water, Light and Bond Commission shall annually at the time required by law for reports from heads of departments, cause to be transmitted to the Mayor and City Council of Cordele a full and complete report of their acting and doings, showing all monies that have come into their hands and the purposes for which the same have been expended. Said Board shall, at the same time, submit to Council an estimate, or budget, showing what amount of money, if any, will be needed from the general treasury to care for their departments during the coming fiscal year, and in the event said Board should have on hand any sum or sums which should belong to the general treasury of said city, said amount, or amounts, should be turned over and settled for at such time. Reports. Budget.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved December 18, 1894, granting corporate authority to the City of Crawfordville, Taliaferro County, and Acts amendatory thereof, so as to define the corporate limits of said city, to provide compensation for its Marshal and Night Watchman, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, Section 6 of the Act approved December 18, 1894, granting corporate authority to the City of Crawfordville, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from said section the words one-half of a mile and substituting therefore the words one mile, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Act of 1894 amended.

blockquote.p: Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the corporate limits of said city shall extend one mile in every direction from the present County Court House in Crawfordville, Georgia. Territorial limits.

law.p:
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the extension of the corporate limits of said city, as provided in the preceding section hereof, shall not in any way operate to change the provisions of the charter of said city with reference to eligibility to office, or his qualification as elector, of any person who may become a resident of said city as a result of extending the corporate limits as aforesaid
nor shall such person be required to pay to said city any property tax or street tax during the present municipal fiscal year. Provisions not changed.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the salaries of the Marshal and Night Watchman of said city shall be fixed by its Mayor and Council in such sum, including all compensation, cost, fees and perquisites of any kind, as said Mayor and Council may see fit, so that the entire compensation of each, the said Marshal and Night Watchman, shall not exceed sixty dollars per month. Marshal and night watchman; salaries.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith, be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act of the General Assembly of this State incorporating the Town of Cumming, approved August 12, 1910, so as to provide for the election of Mayor and Council when for any reason such election is not held at the date named in said Act. To fix the date when term of office of such Mayor and Council shall commence. To provide fees for the officers of said town, and for the removal of the Marshal or Policemen from office for failure to perform any of the duties devolving upon them. To define the age at which persons shall become subject to work upon the streets, alleys, lanes or cemeteries in said town, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Section 4, of the above named Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding
at the end thereof the following: Provided, that if for any reason no election should be held on the date named, then such election may be held at any time thereafter upon the call of any five freeholder residents in said town, after giving notice of the time and place of holding the same for five days by posting notices at the Court House door, and at five other public places in said town. And the persons so elected shall hold their offices from the time of their qualifications until their successors are elected and qualified. So that said Section 4 shall read as follows: Act of 1910, sec. 4 amended.

blockquote.p: Section 4. Be it further enacted, That said Mayor and Council shall be chosen by the elector residents within said corporate limits, who are qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly, who shall have been bona fide residents of said town for three months immediately prior to the election at which said elector may offer to vote. Said Mayor and Councilmen shall be chosen annually on the third Monday in December, and shall hold their office for one year and until their successors are elected and qualified. Any person qualified to vote for Mayor and Councilmen shall be qualified to hold either of said offices. Provided, that if for any reason no election should be held on the date named then such election may be held at any time thereafter upon the call of any five freeholder residents in said town after giving notice of the time and place of holding the same for five days by posting notices at the Court House door and at five other public places in said town. And the persons so elected shall hold their offices from the time of their qualification until their successors are elected and qualified. To be read. Special elections.

law.p:
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 9 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended, by adding at the end thereof the following: And said Mayor shall have authority upon the recommendation
of a majority of the councilmen to remove any marshal or policeman of said town from office for any act of malfeasance in office, or for neglect or failure to discharge the dtuies of their offices. So that said Section 9 shall read as follows: Act of 1910, sec. 9 amended.

Section 9. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor of said town shall be the chief executive officer of the same and shall preside over the meetings of the board of councilmen, see to the execution and enforcement of all laws and regulations of said town, approve the bonds of any officer of said town required to be taken, shall have authority to call a meeting of the council for the transaction of any business whenever he may deem the same necessary, and to compel the attendance of the members in such manner as may be prescribed by the council. And said Mayor shall have the authority upon the recommendation of a majority of the councilmen to remove any marshal or policeman of said town from office for any act of malfeasance in office, or for neglect or failure to discharge the duties of their offices. To be read. Removal of officers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding after Section 10, a new Section to be known as Section 10-A as follows: Further amendment.

blockquote.p: Section 10-A. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of same, That the officers of said town, to-wit: Mayor, Clerk of Council, Marshal, or Policemen shall be entitled to have, receive and collect for any service rendered by them as set out in the tenth section of said Act, such fees as are allowed Justices of the Peace and Constables in this State for like services, to be taxed against and collected only out of the defendants in such cases. Fees.

law.p:
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same,
That said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out Section 37, and inserting instead thereof, the following: Act of 1910, sec. 37 stricken.

blockquote.p: Section 37. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Mayor and Town Council shall have full power and authority to compel all male persons between the ages of twenty-one and fifty years, resident within the corporate limits of said town, (except such as are specially exempted under the laws of this State) to work upon the public streets, squares, parks, cemeteries, lanes or alleys in said town such time, not exceeding fifteen days in each year as the Mayor and Council may determine, or to pay in lieu of such work such sum as may be fixed by said Mayor and Council not exceeding five dollars as commutation tax, and to provide the time at which said sums shall be paid, and shall have the power and authority to levy and collect such commutation tax upon each person subject to street or road duty in said town who does not register his election to work upon the streets, etc., of said town instead of the payment of such commutation tax, on or by the first day of March each year with the Marshal of said town, or the Clerk of said council. New sec. 37. Commutation tax.

law.p: Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding a new Section to be known as Section 39-A, as follows: Further amendment.

blockquote.p: Section 39-A. Be it further enacted, That if there should occur any vacancy in the office of Mayor or Councilmen of said town occasioned by death, resignation, or removal or otherwise, that said council be and they are hereby empowered to fill such vacancy by appointment or selection from among the citizens of said town, and such appointee upon taking the oath shall have all the authority and be entitled to all the privileges and exemptions during his term of office that he would have if regularly elected thereto. Vacancies.

law.p: Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to provide a new form of government for the City of Dalton; to provide a body for the performance of legislative functions of said government, and to exercise or delegate to employees the discharge of executive powers; to prescribe the powers and duties of such body and of all other officials or employees of such city government; to repeal prior Acts incorporating said city in so far as they conflict herewith; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the governing body of the City of Dalton, known as the Mayor and Council of said city, shall consist of a Mayor and four Aldermen, instead of a Mayor and eight Aldermen or Councilmen, as at present constituted. Governing body.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all the powers, legislative, administrative, executive, and judicial, now possessed by the governing body of said city, shall devolve upon and be possesed by in as full and ample a manner as they now exist, the Mayor and Aldermen of said city as herein constituted; with the right on the part of the Mayor and Aldermen to delegate to employees
any or all of the administrative and executive duties devolving upon them, as they may from time to time deem proper. General powers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said city shall be divided into four wards, instead of eight, as at present; that said wards shall be formed by consolidating the wards defined in an Act, approved August 17th, 1908, amending the several Acts incorporating the City of Dalton, as set out on page 579, et seq., Acts 1908, in the following manner: Wards First and Second, as described in said Act, Section 2, shall be consolidated, and shall constitute First Ward; Wards Third and Fourth as so described shall be consolidated, and shall constitute Second Ward; Wards Fifth and Sixth so described in said Act, Section 2, shall be consolidated, Third Ward; Wards Seventh and Eighth shall be consolidated and shall constitute Fourth Ward. Four wards.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That each of said four wards shall be entitled to an alderman, living within its boundaries at the time of election and for three months prior thereto, but elected by a vote of the entire city. Aldermen from each ward.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That in all city elections as at present fixed by law and as herein fixed, each voter shall cast his ballot at a polling place provided in his own ward, and that all restrictions and safeguards now thrown by law around the holding of elections in said city shall continue to exist; and it is further enacted that in providing polling places in said wards, such polling places shall not be located within less than two hundred yards of each other. Polling places.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That qualifications provided by law for aldermen of said city shall continue as fixed, except as herein changed. Eligibility.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That in the selection by the qualified voters of such aldermen, each voter shall cast his vote for as many candidates as there are places to be filled, or his ballot shall be rejected by the election managers. Votes.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That at the city election in December, 1921, as now fixed by law, the aldermen each from the First and Third Wards shall be elected by the voters of said city for a term of two years beginning January 1st, 1922; and one each from the Second and Fourth Wards for a term of one year, beginning January 1st, 1922; and that annually thereafter the aldermen each from the wards whose aldermen's terms expire the first of January following shall be elected for a term of two years. The Mayor shall be elected at said election in December, 1921, for a term of two years beginning January 1st, 1922; and his successors biennially thereafter. Elections and terms.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the clerk, recorder, and marshal of said city may be removed by a three-fifths vote of the Mayor and Aldermen, the Mayor voting, after trial had and all further proceedings in accordance with the laws incorporating said city now in force, set out specifically in Acts 1915, page 584, et seq. Removal of officers.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the terms of all aldermen of said city from the various wards as at present laid out shall terminate January 1st, 1922. Present aldermen; terms.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That said Mayor and Aldermen shall be empowered to fix their own salaries, not to exceed twenty-five dollars per year for Aldermen, and fifty dollars per year for Mayor. Salaries.
Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act, approved August 2nd, 1916, amending an Act, approved August 17th, 1909, authorizing the Mayor and Council of the Town of Decatur to repair, rebuild, repave, regrade, or otherwise improve or re-improve any of the streets, squares, public alleys or lanes of said town, and for other purposes, by adding a proviso to Section 7 of said amending Act, approved August 2nd, 1916, authorizing the town authorities of said Town of Decatur to assess the entire cost of such improvements against the abutting property owners; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That the Act, approved August 2nd, 1916, amending an Act, approved August 17th, 1909, authorizing the Mayor and Council of the Town of Decatur to repair, rebuild, repave, regrade or otherwise improve or re-improve any of the streets, squares, public alleys or lanes of said Town of Decatur, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding to Section 7 of said Act, approved August 7th, 1916, the following proviso: Act of 1916 amended.

blockquote.p:
Provided, that if the persons owning real estate and having at least three-fourths of the frontage on said street, square, public alley or lane of said town which they desire to have improved as herein provided or the portion thereof which they desire to have improved, shall petition in writing said town authorities having jurisdiction in such matters to make such improvements and shall in said petition express their willingness to pay either the entire cost of such improvements or the remaining cost after assessment as provided for in this section against any street railroad company, or other
railroad company having a track or tracks running along or across said street, square, public alley or lane of said town, then said town authorities having jurisdiction in such matters upon complying with the provisions of this Act may make said improvements and may assess the entire cost of said improvements in proportion to frontage on the real estate abutting on the street, square, public alley or lane so improved or the portion thereof so improved one-half to one side and one-half to the other; or, after assessing against any street railroad company or other railroad company having track or tracks running along or across said street, square, public alley or lane the proportion of the costs as provided for in this section, may assess the remaining cost of such improvements in proportion to frontage on the real estate abutting on the streets, squares, public alley or lane so improved or the portion thereof so improved one-half to one side and one-half to the other.

law.p: This proviso thus added to said section shall not repeal the other provisions of this Act, but shall be in addition thereto.
So that said Section when so amended shall read as follows:

Section 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Council of said town shall have full power and authority to assess one-third of the cost of repairing, rebuilding, repaving, regrading, scarifying, oiling, top dressing, and otherwise improving or re-improving, any of the streets, squares, public alleys and lanes of said town, against the real estate abutting on one side of the street so improved, and one-third of the cost against the real estate abutting on the other side of the street so improved; the real estate abutting on both sides of the street shall not, together, be assessed more than two-thirds of the entire cost, in the discretion of the Mayor and Council, and any street railroad company or other railroad company,
having a track or tracks running along or across the streets of said town, shall be required to pay the cost in full of such improvements of such streets between their tracks and for two feet on each side thereof, and in such cases two-thirds of remaining cost on abutting property as aforesaid. To be read.

blockquote.p: Provided, that if the persons owning real estate and having at least three-fourths of the frontage on said street, square, public alley or lane of said town which they desire to have improved as herein provided or the portion thereof which they desire to have improved, shall petition in writing said town authorities having jurisdiction in such matters to make such improvements and shall in said petition express their willingness to pay either the entire cost of such improvements or the remaining cost after assessment as provided for in this section against any street railroad company or other railroad company having a track or tracks running along or across said street, square, public alley or lane of said town, then said town authorities having jurisdiction in such matters upon complying with the provisions of this Act may make said improvements and may assess the entire cost of said improvements in proportion to frontage on the real estate abutting on the street, square, public alley or lane so improved or the portion thereof so improved one-half to one side and one-half to the other; or, after assessing against any street railroad company or other railroad company having track or tracks running along or across said street, square, public alley or lane the proportion of the costs as provided for in this section, may assess the remaining cost of such improvements in proportion to frontage on the real estate abutting on the street, square, public alley or lane so improved or the portion thereof so improved one-half to one side and one-half to the other. This proviso thus added to said section shall not repeal the other provisions of this Act but shall be in addition thereto. Petitions.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act, approved December 20th, 1899, (pages 177 to 196 inclusive, Acts 1899) creating a new charter for the City of Douglas and all amendatory Acts thereof, so as to regulate the passage of ordinances and resolutions by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, to confer the right of veto upon said Mayor, to provide for the passage of measure over his veto, to amend Section 6 of said Act, approved December 20th, 1899, so as to provide for the increasing or diminishing of salaries of certain city officials, and for the repeal of Section 10, of said Act, approved December 20th, 1899, and to confer power upon the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, to widen, straighten, extend, open, lay out and establish any street, lane, way or square, to cause obstructions or encroachments to be removed therefrom, to confer the power of eminent domain upon said City of Douglas for the condemnation of property for the purpose of operating, extending, improving and maintaining its system of electric lights, waterworks and sewerage system within and without the limits of said city, to condemn property for the purpose of establishing, opening, widening, laying out, straightening, grading, draining or changing the grade, of any street, lane, way, alley or square thereof, to provide the method of procedure, the rights of parties at interest in such proceedings, and to provide for the making of returns of taxable property in said city, to provide for penalty upon persons not returning
same and providing for a Board of Tax Assessors and Equalizers to be elected by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, to prescribe their duties, to provide manner of assessment of property returned and unreturned for taxation, and to provide for an appeal from the decision of said Board of Assessors, and to confer power upon said Mayor and Board of Aldermen to enact ordinances to carry out the provisions of this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and the same is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, that the Act, approved December 20, 1899, creating a new Charter of the City of Douglas, and all amendatory Acts thereof, be and they are hereby amended as follows: Act of 1899 amended.
A yea and nay vote duly recorded on the minutes of said meeting.

Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act, approved December 20th, 1899, be amended, and it is hereby amended by striking from Section 6 of said Act, (page 180), the following words:

The salary or compensation of no officer of the city government shall be increased or diminished after the election of such officer and during the term for which he shall have been elected, and inserting in lieu thereof the following words:

The salary or compensation of all officers of said city elected by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may be increased or diminished at any time said Mayor and Board of Aldermen may deem proper, so that said Section when amended shall read as follows:

Section 6. Be it further enacted, That additional offices of the government of said city shall be a Clerk of Council, City Treasurer, Marshal, (who shall be Chief
of Police) and such other officers, agents and employees as may be provided in this Act, or as said Mayor and Aldermen may deem necessary; and the said Mayor and Aldermen shall prescribe the duties and fix the salaries of all such officers, agents and employees. All of said officers named shall be elected by the Mayor and Aldermen of said city each of said alderman having one vote and a majority of the whole Board shall be required to elect, the Mayor having a vote in case of a tie. The terms of all and each of said officers shall be one year, (but the Mayor and Aldermen shall have power to remove at any time any officer for inefficiency or neglect of duty,) and they shall take such an oath and give such bonds for the faithful performance of their respective duties as may be prescribed by the said Mayor and Aldermen. All such officers shall be elected by said Mayor and Aldermen at the first regular meeting in January of each year, or soon thereafter as possible. The salary or compensation of all officers of said city elected by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may be increased or diminished at any time said Mayor and Board of Aldermen may deem proper, and all of such officers shall hold their offices respectively until their successors are duly elected and qualified, unless sooner removed by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen; and in case of a vacancy in any of said offices that same shall be filled by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen. Amended section to be read. Votes. Salary increase.

That all ordinances and resolutions passed by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, shall, before the same shall become effective be signed and approved by the Mayor except in cases of veto hereinafter provided for. The Mayor shall have the right of veto and may veto any action taken by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen whether the same be a motion, an ordinance, or resolution (except appeal cases from the Mayor's Court and election of any city officer) passed by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen, and in the event the Mayor shall exercise the power of veto herein provided, he shall reduce
his objection to writing and file the same with the Clerk within five days after such passage, and said objections shall be recorded on the minutes. In the event the Mayor fails to sign or approve such measure passed, or file his objections as provided herein within five days after passage, the same shall become effective in the same manner as if the Mayor had signed and approved the same: Provided, That such measure vetoed by the Mayor may be passed over his veto at the next regular succeeding meeting after such veto, by an affirmative vote of not less than four votes in favor of the passage of such measure vetoed, at any regular or called meeting. Ordinances and resolutions.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted, That said Act, approved December 20th, 1899, creating a new charter of the City of Douglas be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking all of Section ten of said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the following, so that said Section when amended shall read as follows: Further amendment.

blockquote.p:
Section 10. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall have power and authority to widen, straighten or extend any street, alley, lane, way or square in said City of Douglas, to open, lay out and establish any new street alley, lane, way or square of whatever nature and to establish, grade therefor, same being done in accordance with resolutions or ordinances passed by said Mayor and Aldermen. They shall have power after ten days' written notice to parties at interest to cause all encroachments and obstructions of a permanent nature, or which in their judgment ought to be removed from any street, alley, lane or square and in event such encroachments upon said streets, lanes, ways or squares are made and erected thereon after such street, alley, lane, way or square is laid out and established, then no compensation shall be made for the removal of the same. In event the owner or lessor of such encroachments or the owner of the land abutting the street at such
encroachment, fails or refuses to run over same after notice herein provided for, the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may order the same removed at the expense of such owner and the Clerk of said city shall issue execution against such parties for the amount expended by the city in the removal thereof and said execution may be collected as in cases of executions issued for ad valorem taxes. The said City of Douglas shall have power and authority to purchase and hold all real estate necessary, for the erection and operation and for extending, improving and operating its system of waterworks and electric lights and sanitary sewerage systems within and without the city limits or any other public property. The said City of Douglas shall have the right of eminent domain and the power and authority is by this Act conferred upon said city to condemn property for the purpose of operating, extending, improving and maintaining its system of waterworks, electric lights and sewerage system of said city, both within and without the corporate limits of said City of Douglas, and likewise have full power and authority to condemn property for the purpose of establishing, opening, widening, laying out or straightening, grading, draining, working or changing the grade, of any street, alley, lane, way or square, or portion thereof, in said City of Douglas and the method of procedure for the condemnation of property, and the rights of all parties at interest in said proceedings for said purposes, shall be the same as now prescribed and provided by the laws of Georgia governing condemnation proceeding and amendatory Acts thereof. New sec. 10. Street improvements.

law.p: Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act, approved December 20th, 1899, and all amendatory Acts thereof, be, and the same are, hereby amended as follows: Further amendment.

Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation owning real or personal property in the City of Douglas, subject to taxation
to make returns thereof to the Clerk of Council of said city on or before the tenth day of April in each year. All property in said city, subject to taxation, shall be returned as of date of January first, and the owner of such property, or his agent or legal representative, shall on or before the date first above mentioned in each year return the same for taxation. All such property shall be returned at its fair market value, on a form prescribed by the Mayor and Aldermen or the Board of Tax Assessors of said city, under the oath of the owner, his agent or person making such return. Any person, firm or corporation failing to make returns of their property as above provided shall be subject to such penalty as may be prescribed by ordinance of said city. Tax returns.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That there shall be a Board of Tax Assessors and Equalizers in said city charged with the duty of valuing, assessing and equalizing tax returns on all property, real and personal, in said city subject to taxation. Said Board shall consist of three freeholder residents of said city, elected by the Mayor and Council of said city at the first meeting in January of each year, or so soon thereafter as may be practicable, who shall hold office for one year, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. Said Board shall meet as prescribed by ordinance, and at such other times as the Board itself may fix, for the purpose of valuing and assessing all property subject to taxation in said city, whether the same be returned for taxation or not, at its fair market value; of which return or report thereof shall be made by said Board to the City Council. In the event the valuation of property returned for taxation shall be raised or increased by said Board in making its assessment thereon, due notice thereof shall be given in writing by said Board to the owner thereof, his agent or legal representative, of the time and place when and where said Board will pass upon and finally fix such assessment, reasonable time, as may be fixed by ordinance
of said city, being given said owner, his agent or representative in order that said owner, his agent or representative may have an opportunity of being heard by said Board upon the question of said valuation and assessment; like notice and action shall be given and taken by said Board as to property not returned for taxation, but which is subject to taxation by said city. From the action of said Board of Assessors in any instance in valuing and assessing property in said city subject to taxation, whether same be returned or unreturned, an appeal shall lie to the Mayor and Council of said city, whose decision thereon shall be final. Tax assessors and equalizers.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Council of said city is hereby vested with power to prescribe by ordinance, not inconsistent herewith, rules and regulations necessary to carry into effect the intent and purpose of this Act with reference to the valuation, assessment and equalization of property subject to taxation in said city. The Mayor and Council shall provide by ordinance for due and proper notice to the taxpayers in case the valuation of their property shall be raised by said Tax Assessors, or the valuation thereof fixed by them at such figure as may seem to the owner thereof as being above its fair market value, in order that such owners, his agent or representative, may have a hearing thereon before said Board, and, should taxpayers be dissatisfied with the valuation and assessment of their property after being heard thereon by said Board of Assessors, to provide details for appeals by such taxpayers from the valuation and assessment of said Board to the Mayor and Council of said City, and for the hearing of such appeals by the Mayor and Council. Tax regulations.
Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, and it is hereby enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act, approved August 19, 1912, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, creating a new Charter for the City of East Point, in the County of Fulton, whereby Section fifty-nine of said original Act and the Acts amendatory thereof will be amended so as so to increase the ad valorem tax rate for the support and maintenance of the public schools of said City of East Point from one-half of one per cent. to three-fourths of one per cent. of the value of all the taxable property within the corporate limits of said City of East Point; and whereby Section sixty-four of said Act will be amended so as to reduce the ad valorem tax rate for ordinary current expenses of said City of East Point from seventy-five cents on the one hundred dollars to fifty cents on the one hundred dollars of the value of all the taxable property within the corporate limits of said City of East Point; and whereby Section forty-two of said original Act and the amendatory Acts thereof will be amended so as to allow owners of property abutting on any sidewalk which the Mayor and Council desire to improve by having the same paved on tiled and curbing constructed and laid thereon the option to have said work done at the expense of said property owners and by individual or private contract.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section fifty-nine of said Act, and the Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking all that portion of said Section beginning with the word provided in line ten, on page 899 of the Acts of 1912, and ending with the word cent in line twelve of said Section, and the following inserted in lieu thereof: Provided that said Mayor and Council
shall have no authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax of more than three-fourths of one per cent. of the value of all the taxable property within said city for school purposes, so that said Section, when amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1912, sec. 59 amended.

blockquote.p: Be it further enacted, That said Board of Education shall, as soon as practicable after their election, submit to the Mayor and Council an estimate of the amount of money needed by them to operate the public schools for the current scholastic year. An annual estimate shall be submitted to the City Council by said Board of Education on or before the first day of March of each year, and such assessments shall be levied and collected in the manner and at the time other taxes are levied and collected for city purposes; provided that said Mayor and Council shall have no authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax of more than three-fourths of one per cent. of the value of all the taxable property within said city for school purposes. Said Mayor and Council shall pay over to the Treasurer of said Board of Education such tax when levied and collected for the support of said schools. Said Mayor and Council shall have the authority to appropriate any special taxes collected by said city from any source whatever to the maintenance of said schools. The Board of Education shall not have the authority to contract any debt during any year in excess of the appropriation for the public schools for that particular year. To be read. School tax.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section sixty-four of said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By striking all that portion of said Section beginning with the words seventy-five in line nine, on page 902 of the Acts of 1912, and ending with the word dollars in the same line, and the following inserted in lieu thereof: Fifty cents on the one hundred dollars, so that said Section, when amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1912, sec. 64 amended.
