It shall be the duty of said Tax Assessors, within such time as may be provided by the City Manager, to meet and carefully canvass all the tax returns made to said city, placing a valuation on all real estate returned at the full fair market value of such real estate and placing additional valuations on all personalty or other property that in the judgment of said Tax Assessors has been returned at less than full, fair market value. It shall be the duty of said Assessors to carefully and diligently seek to ascertain the fair market value of all property returned, or that they shall assess, and to this end shall inspect the property when necessary and make such other investigation as may be necessary to ascertain the true value of all property subject to taxation by said city. It shall further be the duty of said Assessor to make careful investigation for the purpose of determining whether all property subject to taxation by said city has been returned, and when it is found that it has not been, said property shall be assessed at double its true value. Said Board of Assessors shall file a written report of its findings with the City Manager and shall perform all other duties required of it under the provision of this Act. Duties

Sec. 75. The said Tax Assessors may hear during the progress of their investigations such evidence as to value of the property of said city as they deem advisable
and to this end may compel the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents as now provided by the laws of Georgia. From the action of said Board in fixing an assessment an appeal, if entered within ten days in writing from the date of the notice of assessment, shall lie to the Council of the City of Eastman, whose decision thereon shall be final. Any member of said Board of Assessors is hereby empowered to administer a legal oath to any person or persons making tax returns. Property in said city owned by said Assessors, or either of them, shall be assessed by the Council. Hearings, etc.
Sec. 76. The City Manager shall cause written notice to be mailed to all persons whose property has been raised by the Tax Assessors. Notice.

Sec. 77. It shall be the duty of the City Manager to provide blanks for the return of property for taxation, in which blanks, in addition to other species of property, every species of property subject to taxation in said city now referred to in the return blanks for State and county purposes shall be referred to, upon which blank every citizen of said city and every owner of property therein shall be required to make return under oath at its full, fair market value. All property, real and personal, and all classes of property hereinbefore referred to, to the City Clerk at such times and as of such dates as may be required by the Council. It shall be the duty of the City Clerk or some other person authorized to administer oaths to administer an oath to every person making returns before the same is made that they will make a full and complete return of all such property as may be owned or controlled by such person subject to taxation in said city. Returns.

Sec. 78. It shall be the duty of the City Manager to provide a tax digest which the City Clerk shall enter the value of all property returned after the same shall have been assessed by the Tax Assessors to the same extent and as fully as is now done by counties. Digest.

Sec. 79. The Council is hereby vested with the power to prescribe by ordinances, rules and regulations necessary to carry into effect the intent and purpose of this Act; to prescribe the punishment of any person who shall be convicted of wilfully and maliciously secreting and concealing property in said city to avoid paying taxes thereon. The number of days said Board shall be in session shall be fixed by the Council. Regulations.
Sec. 80. The taxes levied by the City of Eastman shall be due and payable as now provided by law. Taxes due and payable.

Sec. 81. All taxes levied by the City of Eastman shall be collected as follows: An execution shall be issued by the Clerk of the City directed to the Chief of Police and the members of the police force of said city against the real and personal property of the defaulter and against said defaulter and the said Chief of Police or any member of the police force shall proceed to levy the same, and after advertising the same for four weeks in such newspaper of general circulation as may be designated by formal resolution adopted by the Council, shall sell their property levied on before the Court House door of said county between the legal hours of sale on a regular Sheriff's sale day. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police or a member of the police force to put up the property and offer the same for sale in parcels until he gets a bid sufficient to pay the taxes due, and shall then knock the property off to the purchaser, make him a deed and put him in possession, as in ordinary Sheriff's sale. Such a sale shall be as effective to pass the title as the deed of the person against whom such execution was issued, but the right of redemption shall exist as in sales for State and county taxes; provided, that in all cases where property has been bought in by said city for taxes, and the title hereof vested in said city. It shall be lawful for the Chairman of Council, with the consent of Council, to authorize a reconveyance of said property to the former
owners thereof upon the payment by such owners of all the taxes, premiums, penalties and costs due under the process by which same was sold. Collection. Execution and sale. Reconveyance.

Sec. 82. This Act shall not abolish any of the ordinances of the present Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman now in force except where they may be in conflict with the provisions of this Act, but all such ordinances shall remain in force in the City of Eastman in the same manner and to the same effect as the same were of force under the authority of the Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman until they are changed, modified or repealed by the authority of the City of Eastman. Ordinances not repealed.

Sec. 83. All the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia creating and amending the charter of the Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman or of the City of Eastman now in force and that are not in conflict with this Act, shall be held and construed as a part of the charter of the City of Eastman until modified, changed or repealed. Those in conflict are hereby repealed. Acts not repealed.

Sec. 84. The City of Eastman, in its discretion, is authorized to appropriate money annually to such public libraries that may be hereafter established and run in the City of Eastman, or that may be now established in said City of Eastman. Public libraries.

Sec. 85. All public utilities, franchises and all renewals, extensions and amendments thereof, shall be granted or made only by ordinance. No such proposed ordinance shall be adopted by the Council until it has been printed in full, and until a public written report containing recommendations thereon shall have been made to the Council by the City Manager, until adequate public hearings shall have been held on such ordinances and until at least two weeks after its official publication in final form; and no public utility franchise shall be for a longer period than thirty years. No public utility franchise shall be transferable except with the approval
of the Council expressed by ordinance; and copies of all transfers and mortgages or other documents affecting the title or use of public utilities shall be filed with the City Clerk within ten days after the execution thereof. Public utilities.
Sec. 86. All grants, removals, extensions or amendments of public utility franchises, whether it be so provided in the ordinances or not, shall be subject to the right of the city: Franchises.

item.p: (A) To repeal the same by ordinance at any time for misuse or non-use, or failure to begin construction within the time prescribed, or otherwise to comply with the terms prescribed. Repeal.
(B) To require proper and adequate extension of plant and service, and the maintenance of the plant and fixtures at the highest practical standard of efficiency. Extension of plant.
(C) To establish reasonable standards of service and quality of products and prevent unjust discrimination in service or rates. Service, etc.

(D) To prescribe the form of accounts and at any time to examine and audit the accounts and other records of any such utility; but if a public service commission or any other authority shall be given the power by law to prescribe the form of accounts for public utilities throughout the State, the form so prescribed shall be controlling so far as they go; but the Council may prescribe more detailed forms for the utilities within its jurisdiction. Audits.
(E) To impose such other regulations as may be conducive to the safety, welfare and accommodation of the public. Other regulations.

law.p:
Sec. 87. Permits revocable at the will of the Council for such minor or temporary public utility privileges as may be specified by general ordinance may be granted and revoked by the Council from time to time in accordance
with the terms and conditions to be prescribed thereby; and such permits shall not be deemed to be franchises as the term is used in this charter. Such general ordinance, however, shall be subject to the same procedure as an ordinance granting a franchise and shall not be passed as an emergency measure. Permits revoked.

Sec. 88. All the extensions of public utilities within the city limits shall become a part of the aggregate property of the public utility, shall be operated as such, and shall be subject to all the obligations and reserved rights contained in this charter and in any original grant hereafter made. The right to use and maintain any extension shall terminate with the original grant. In case of an extension of a public utility operated under a franchise hereafter granted, such right shall be terminable under the same conditions as the original grant. Extensions.

Sec. 89. Within six months after this charter takes effect, every public utility and every owner of a public utility franchise shall file with the city as may be prescribed by ordinance, certified copies of all the franchises owned or claimed, or under which any such utility is operated. The city shall compile and maintain a public record of all public utility franchises and of all public utility fixtures in the streets and other public places of the city. Record of franchises.

Sec. 90. Accounts shall be kept for each public utility owned or operated by the city, distinct from other city accounts, and in such manner as to show the true and complete financial results of such city ownership, or ownership and operation, including all assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. These accounts shall show the actual cost to the city of each public utility owned; the cost of all extensions, additions and improvements; all expenses of maintenance; the amounts set aside for sinking fund purposes; and, in the case of city operation, all operating expenses of every description. They shall
show as nearly as possible the value of any service furnished to or rendered by any such public utility by or to any other city or governmental department. They shall also show a proper allowance for depression, insurance, interest and the investment and estimates of the amount of taxes that would be chargeable against the property if privately owned. The Council shall annually cause to be made and printed for public distribution a report showing the financial results of such city ownership or ownership and operation, which reports shall give the information specified in this section and such information as the Council shall deem expedient. Accounts.

Sec. 91. All accounts and records of every office and department of the city shall be open to the public at all reasonable times except records and documents from which might be secured information which might defeat the lawful purpose of the officer or department withholding them from access to the public. Administrative department, records.

Sec. 92. Every officer of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of office, take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation to be filed and kept in the office of the City Clerk, that he will in all respects faithfully discharge the duties of his office. Officers' oaths.

Sec. 93. The City Manager and such other officers and employees as the Council may require so to do, shall give bond in such amount and with such surety as may be approved by the Council. Premiums on such bonds may be paid by the city. Bonds.

Sec. 94. The Council shall have authority to prescribe adequate penalties for offenses against the ordinances of the city, the same not to exceed those enumerated in Section 45 of this charter, except as provided in Section 56 of this charter, and the Recorder shall have a right to impose punishment as prescribed in said Sections 45 and 56 of this article. Any person convicted of an offense against the ordinances of the city and found to
be afflicted with an infectious or contagious disease may, in addition to the penalty for such offense, be isolated and kept in custody until danger to the public from such infection or contagion is removed. Offenses; penalties.

Sec. 95. Claims for money damages against the city on account of the injury to person or property shall be presented, and the city shall be bound therefor only as provided in Section 910 of the Code of Georgia, 1910. Claims.
Sec. 96. The power of the city to condemn property for public use conferred by this charter shall be exercised in the manner provided by law for the condemnation of land for public use. Condemnation.

Sec. 97. All persons holding administrative office at the time this charter takes effect, whether elected or appointed, shall continue in office and in the performance of their duties until provisions shall have been made, in accordance with the provisions of this charter, for the performance of such duties or the discontinuance of such offices. The power conferred and the duties imposed by law upon any officer, commission, board of department of the city abolished by this charter shall, upon the taking effect thereof, be exercised and discharged by the officer or department designated by the Council, unless otherwise provided herein. Officers to continue in office.

Sec. 98. All contracts entered into by the city for its benefit prior to the taking effect of this charter shall continue in full force and effect. All public work begun prior to the taking effect of this charter shall be continued and perfected hereunder. Contracts not repealed.

Sec. 99. That if any section or part of a section of this charter proves invalid or unconstitutional, the same shall not be held to invalidate or impair the validity, force or effect of any other section or part of a section of this charter unless it clearly appears that such other
section or part of a section is wholly or necessarily dependent for its operation upon the section or part of a section so held unconstitutional or invalid. Constitutional law.

Sec. 100. That any of the officers of said municipality who may be sued for any act or thing done in his or their official capacity may be justified under this charter, and that the provisions of this charter may be pleaded, and shall be a full defense to any action brought against the Council, the City Manager or other officers and employees of said City of Eastman, for any act or acts done by them or either of them under and in accordance with its provisions, and in accordance with the ordinance or ordinances, passed in pursuance thereof. Suits of officers.

Sec. 101. That after thirty days from the date of all elections in said City of Eastman, if no notice of contest has been given as to the result of said election, the City Clerk shall destroy the ballot, should any person or persons, except under an order of Court of competent jurisdiction, for any cause whatever, inspect either the tally sheets, list of voters or ballots of said election after they have been filed with the City Clerk, he shall be liable to fine, imprisonment or both in the discretion of the Recorder of said city. Elections not contested.

Sec. 102. The Chairman of the Council, or in his absence, the Vice-Chairman, and two Councilmen shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any and all business whether legislative or judicial, except in the selection or discharge of the City Manager, and for this purpose the entire Board of five Councilmen shall participate, but a majority shall be sufficient for the selection or discharge of said City Manager, and provided further, that when only three members of the Council are present it shall require the unanimous vote of all three members to pass any ordinance or resolution. The Chairman of
the Council, or Vice-Chairman, when presiding in deliberations have a right to vote as other members of the Council, but neither have the right of veto. Quorum of council. Chairman.

Sec. 103. All deeds, leases and conveyances to real and personal property, except as in this charter otherwise provided, to be made by the City of Eastman, shall be made and executed in the name of the City of Eastman and shall be signed by the Chairman of the City Council and the City Clerk, under the corporate seal of said City of Eastman. Provided, that no such deed, lease or conveyance shall be so made, executed and signed except after an ordinance or resolution of the Council has been adopted to that end. Execution of deeds, etc.

Sec. 104. The Council of said City of Eastman shall have power and authority to prevent horses, mules, cattle, sheep, hogs, dogs, goats and all other animals or fowls from running at large in said city, and to prevent and prohibit the keeping of hogs within the city limits, or to regulate the manner in which they must be kept if allowed kept, and shall have power and authority to take up and impound any such animal and fowl and punish all owners of such animals and fowls who refuse to obey an ordinance passed by such Council, carrying this authority into effect. Impounding.

Sec. 105. All obligations, or debts of said City of Eastman, shall be paid only upon warrants or vouchers issued as now authorized by law, except the same shall be signed by the City Clerk and countersigned by the City Manager. Obligations and debts.

Sec. 106. The account of the City of Eastman and of the officers or employees of the City of Eastman shall be audited at least annually by an auditor to be appointed by the Council, who shall fix the compensation for such work, and the report of such auditor shall be submitted to the Council as soon as the same is completed for consideration and action, if desired, by said Council, and the
same shall be published in the newspaper in said city selected by the Council for that purpose, and the expense thereof may be paid as other current expenses by the City of Eastman. Audits.

Sec. 107. The Act of the Legislature approved Dec. 15, 1894, and all amendments thereto, creating a public school system in and for the then Town of Eastman, is hereby made a part of and adopted by the charter, and the City of Eastman, as created by this charter, assumes and adopts all the obligations and relations now existing between the Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman and the said school system. Public schools.

Sec. 108. Before this Act shall become a law it shall be submitted for approval to the legally qualified electors of the City of Eastman as hereinafter provided. The present Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman shall call an election to be held on the 21st day of September, 1921, at which said election the ballots used shall submit the following proposition in the order indicated: Elections to ratify.

item.p: For the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for a City Manager form of government. Ballots.
Against the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for the City Manager form of government.
The elector striking out either of these propositions may indicate his vote for the one not stricken out.
The ballots used in said election shall be substantially as follows: City of Eastman.
For the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for a City Manager form of government.
Against the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for a City Manager form of government.

law.p: Sec. 109. If a majority of the votes cast in said election shall be in favor of the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for a City Manager form of government, then in that event this Act shall be and become of full force and effect, and this Act shall constitute the new charter for the City of Eastman. Act effective.

Sec. 110. If a majority of the votes cast in said election shall be against the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman, providing for a City Manager form of government, then in that event, the provisions of this Act shall be of no force and effect, and shall not become law. Act noneffective.

Sec. 111. If a majority of the votes cast in said election are in favor of the adoption of this Act, then in that event the present Mayor and Councilmen of the City of Eastman shall continue in office only until the first day of January, Nineteen Hundred and Twenty-two. Continuance of present mayor and council.

Sec. 112. The electors of the present Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman qualified to vote for or against the approval of a new charter for the City of Eastman providing for a City Manager form of government at the election to be held on the twenty-first day of September, Nineteen Hundred and Twenty-two, as herein provided, shall be those electors who have legally registered, under the law governing elections in said City of Eastman, now known as the Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman, up to six o'clock p. m. on the 12th day of September, 1921, and the registration of electors for said election shall close at six o'clock p. m. on the 12th day of September, 1921, and the Clerk of said municipality at this said time shall close the registration books for this said special election, and shall proceed to make up and file in his office a list of such registered voters to be
designated Registered voters for special election to be held on the 21st day of September, 1921, in alphabetical order of names, distinguishing in said list between white and colored voters. Qualified voters.

Sec. 113. It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to cause to be printed and posted in front of the City Hall or building used as such, of said Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman by two o'clock p. m. on the day preceding said special election the corrected list of the registered voters for said special election and also to furnish to each of the election managers a certified copy of such printed list on or before the opening of the polls at said special election. List of voters.

Sec. 114. A special election herein provided for shall be held at the City Hall, or the building used as such, by the present Mayor and Council of the City of Eastman and before the date of said special election the Mayor of the City of Eastman shall name three election managers to hold this special election on September 21st, 1921, under the provisions now governing elections in the City of Eastman. All other laws as now provided in the charter of the present City of Eastman for the holding of elections in said city, and not in conflict with this Act shall govern and control said special election to be held on September 21st, 1921. Election, where and when held. Managers.

Sec. 115. After the consolidation of the votes had at said special election is made by the managers, the managers shall report the result to the Mayor of the City of Eastman, and he shall declare the results of said election. Returns.

Sec. 116. Other than as herein provided, the special election to be held on September 21st, 1921, shall be held and conducted under the laws now governing general city elections in the City of Eastman. General laws.

Sec. 117. Where not otherwise provided in this charter, the right and power is hereby delegated to the City Council to prescribe by ordinance the method and mode of procedure in the trial of cases in the Recorder's Court. Recorder's court procedure.
Sec. 118. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this law be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to authorize and direct the Mayor and Council of the City of Elberton, Georgia, to divide said city into five Wards; to fix and change the boundaries of the same, and to provide that no change of boundaries shall take place within certain times; to fix the times when Councilmen shall be elected therefrom; to provide for primary nominations and elections and fix the places of holding the same; to declare who is elected; to prescribe rules and places for holding same; to provide for filling of vacancies in Council from whatever cause; and to provide further that Clerk and Treasurer of said city shall post in certain places a condensed semi-annual statement of the financial conditions of said city at certain times; and to provide further for amending city charter of Elberton, Georgia, approved July 20th, 1906, so that the Council of said city shall have authority to assess and collect one-half of the costs of grading, paving, macadamizing or other improvement for travel or drainage of any of the streets or alleys of said city or parts of the same on and out of the real estate abutting
on said street or portions of the same so improved; to authorize such improvements of the streets or alleys of said city; to authorize the Council of said city to grade, pave, macadamize or otherwise improve any portion of the width of any street, alley or lane in said city, and to assess one-half of the costs on the real estate abutting on each side of the street, alley or lane improved; to provide when the provisions of this Act shall be effective, and to repeal conflicting laws.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Mayor and Council of the City of Elberton, Georgia, shall before the next general election for Councilmen of said city, divide said city into Wards, five in number, and pass an ordinance defining and fixing the limits and boundaries of said Wards. Said Mayor and Council shall have full power and authority, by ordinance, to change the limits and boundaries of such Wards and to rearrange and fix the limits and boundaries of the same; provided, however, that no change shall be made in the limits and boundaries and arrangements of such Wards within five months next preceding the date of any general election for Councilmen of said city. The said Mayor and Council shall by ordinance designate three of said Wards, from each of which a Councilman shall be elected at the next regular election for Councilman to be held in said city after the passage of this Act, and biennially after such election, a Councilman shall be elected from each of said Wards so designated. At the second regular election for Councilmen to be held in and for said city after the passage of this Act, and biennially thereafter, a Councilman shall be elected from each of the other two Wards, so that after the second regular election for Councilmen to be held in and for said city after the passage of this Act, each of said five Wards shall be represented by a Councilman
from each Ward. The said Mayor and Council shall have full power and authority to provide by ordinance for the nomination and election of Councilmen from all Wards. Provided, however, that each Councilman shall be nominated by a vote of the qualified voters of said city residing within the Ward from which such Councilman is to be nominated and voting at a precinct within such Ward, and provided, further, that all Councilmen shall be voted for and elected by a vote of the qualified voters of said city voting in a general election held at one regular voting place in said city, and the candidates for Councilman from each of said Wards receiving the highest number of votes at said general election shall be declared elected. All special elections to fill vacancies, from any cause whatsoever, in the City Council from any of said Wards, shall be governed by the provisions herein enacted. If a Councilman shall permanently remove his residence from the Ward from which he was elected, his office shall be vacated and it shall be the duty of said Mayor and Council to call an an election to fill such vacancy. Five wards. Councilmen. Vacancies.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the Clerk and Treasurer of said City of Elberton to post at a public place in the City Hall, before the Court House door and at two other public places in said city a condensed semi-annual statement of the financial condition of the said city, as of the dates of January 1st and July 1st of each year after the passage of this Act, and such statement, as of the date of July 1st, covering the financial condition of said city for the previous six months, shall be so made. Each statement made pursuant to this section of this Act shall be verified by affidavits of the Clerk and Treasurer and three members of the Council of said city. Financial statement.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by said authority, That an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia to amend the charter of the City of Elberton, approved
July 20, 1906, appearing on Pages 745 to 748 inclusive, of the Acts of 1906, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from Section One of said Act, after the word and on the seventh line of said section and before the words said Council on the ninth line of said section, the following words, to-wit: If the streets, lanes or alleys required to be drained, graded, paved, macadamized or improved otherwise be embraced within what are known as the fire limits of said city, and also by striking from said Section One of said Act, after the word abutting on the twelfth line of said section and before the word provided on the nineteenth line of said section, the following words, to-wit On each side of the street, lane or alley improved and if the street, lane or alley required to be improved, graded, paved or macadamized be outside of what is known as the fire limits of said city, said Council shall have full power and authority to assess and collect one-fourth of the costs of such grading, paving, macadamizing or other improvement on and out of the real estate abutting on each side of the street, alley or lane improved, and by inserting in lieu of said words, so stricken, after the word abutting in the twelfth line of said section and before the word provided on the nineteenth line of said section, the following words, to-wit: On the street or the portion thereof so improved, so that said Section One of said Act, when so amended, shall read as follows: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is enacted by authority of the same, That power is hereby granted to the City Council of the City of Elberton to adopt at any time an ordinance requiring the grading, paving, macadamizing or otherwise improving for travel or drainage any of the streets or alleys of said city or parts of the same, and said Council shall have full power and authority to assess and collect one-half of the costs of such grading, paving, macadamizing or other improvement on and out of the real estate abutting on said street or the portion thereof so improved; provided, that the
costs of grading and macadamizing between the tracks of any street railroad or other railroad tracks and for one foot on each side of the track now having or that may hereafter have any tracks on the streets of said city, lanes or alleys of said city, shall be assessed against such railroad company or companies. Act of 1906, sec. 1 amended. To be read. Street improvements. Assessments.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by said authority, That Section Two of said Act of the General Assembly of Georgia approved July 20, 1906, and appearing in the Acts of 1906 on Page 745, same being an Act to amend the charter of the City of Elberton, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from said section, after the word cost in the seventh line of said section and to the end of said section the following words, to-wit: if the same be within what is known as the fire limits of said city; and to assess one-fourth of the costs of such grading, paving, macadamizing or otherwise improving on the real estate abutting on each side of the street, lane or alley improved if the same is outside of what is known as the fire limits of said city, so that said section when so amended shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, The City Council of said City of Elberton shall have full power and authority to grade, pave, macadamize or otherwise improve any portion of the width of any street, alley or lane in said city, and to assess the costs of such grading, paving, macadamizing or otherwise improving on real estate abutting on each side of the street, alley or lane improved, one-half of the cost. Act of 1906, sec. 2 amended. To be read. Improvements beyond fire limit.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by said authority, That the provisions of this Act shall be effective immediately upon its passage. Effective on approval.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to incorporate the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, and State of Georgia, approved August 19th, 1911; to authorize the Mayor and Board of Aldermen to construct, pave or otherwise improve or repair the streets, sidewalks or highways of said city, and to assess and collect one-third the cost thereof out of the abutting real estate; to authorize the Mayor and Board of Aldermen to grant the use of the streets to public service companies, corporations or enterprises, on such terms and for such periods of time as they may deem proper; to change the manner of the election, and the qualification of city officers; to provide a permanent registration, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, shall have full power and authority, in their discretion, to open up any new street, lane or avenue in said city; to construct any new sidewalk in said city; to grade, pave, macadamize, or otherwise improve or repair any street, lane or avenue in said city or any part thereof now or hereafter established, and to grade, pave, macadamize, curb or otherwise improve or repair any sidewalk of said city, or any part thereof, now in existence or hereafter constructed, and to have any or all of said improvements made or done in such manner, upon such terms, of such material, by such persons, either contractors or employees, as the Mayor and Aldermen may determine, and such construction or improvements may be done in such parts or sections as they may deem proper, each section in the discretion of the Mayor and
Aldermen to be treated as a whole or entire base upon which to proportion assessments, if any, to be made against the property owners, as hereinafter provided for. Street improvements.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall have power and authority to do or have done any or all of the work or make or have made any or all of the improvements or repairs, mentioned in preceding section, at one-third the expense or cost of the owners of the property abutting on such street, lane, avenue or sidewalk, the one-third expense or cost to be assessed against such abutting property and to be equalized and pro-rated according to the froutage of such property on such street, lane, avenue or sidewalk. Assessments.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That whenever any such work, improvements or repairs are done by the Mayor and Aldermen, by the pro rata assessment as aforesaid, as soon as the same shall have been completed, or as soon as the total cost thereof may be ascertained, they shall, either by keeping an assessment roll, or any other accurate manner determine what part of the cost shall be borne by each piece of abutting property according to its frontage, and the amount of the assessment on each piece of abutting real estate, shall be a lien on such property, inferior only to liens for State, county and municipal taxes, and dating from the passage of the ordinance or resolution providing for the doing of the work or for making of such improvements or repairs and for the making of such assessments. Assessment roll. Lien on property.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Aldermen shall have power and authority to enforce the collection of such assessments for such work or for any of the said improvements or repairs done or made either upon any street, avenue or sidewalk, by executions to be issued by the City Clerk agaisnt the real estate so assessed, and against the owner thereof at the date of the
passage of the ordinance or resolution making the assessment, said executions to be directed as provided in said charter for the direction of executions, and to be levied by any officer to whom directed, upon the property so assessed; and after advertising and the other proceedings as provided in cases of sales for city taxes, and the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder, at the time, place and manner of sales for city taxes, and such sale shall vest absolute title to said property to purchaser; provided, that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit of illegality denying that he owes the same or some part of the sum for which the said execution was issued, and in case he admits owing any part or amount, stating what amount is due, which amount so admitted shall be paid or collected before affidavit is received, and the affidavit for such balance, and all affidavits may be filed under this section shall be received, and returned to the Superior Court of Charlton County and there to be tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penalties provided in cases of illegality for delay. Executions.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Aldermen shall have power to enforce the provisions of the preceding sections from time to time upon the same street, avenue or sidewalk, as often and whenever they deem necessary. Enforcement, how often.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Aldermen of said city shall have power and authority to grant to public service companies, corporations or enterprises, franchises to use any of the streets or highways, or any part of either, of said city for any purpose and for use in such manner and to be granted for such period or periods of time and upon such terms and conditions as the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may deem proper Franchises.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That Section Three (3) of the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating
the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from said section the words one of whom shall be elected at large in the third and fourth lines of said section, the words and thirty days in each ward in the seventh line of said Section 1, and the words who is a freeholder in the eighth line of said section, so that said Section Three (3) when so amended, shall read as follows: Section 3, That the elective officers shall consist of a Mayor, who shall also act as Police Judge, a City Clerk, City Treasurer, City Assessor and a Board of five Aldermen. Any person twenty-one years of age who is a citizen of the United States and has resided one year in the State of Georgia, six months in Folkston, and who shall have paid all taxes levied against him, and has been regularly registered, shall be eligible to any elective office in the City of Folkston. Act of 1911 amended. Elective officers.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be further amended by striking Section Four (4) therefrom and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to-wit: Section 4. The next election, by ballot, shall be held at the County Court House of Charlton County, in Folkston, Georgia, on the first Tuesday in December, 1921, for the election of a Mayor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, City Assessor and a Board of five Aldermen, and the officers so elected shall be inducted into office on the first Tuesday in January, 1922; the officers so elected and inducted into office shall hold office for one year, or until their successors are elected and qualified. That after the election provided for in this section has been held, it shall be the duty of the municipality to hold elections annually thereafter, to-wit: on the first Tuesday in December of each year, and the officers so elected at subsequent elections shall be inducted into office on the first Tuesday in January of each year following
their election and at each annual election a Mayor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, City Assessor, a Board of five Aldermen of said city all shall be elected; provided, however, it shall be unlawful for more than two Aldermen to be elected from any one Ward in said City of Folkston. That all subsequent elections to the one provided for in this section shall be held at the County Court House in said City of Folkston, and all qualified voters of said city shall be qualified to vote for a Mayor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, City Assessor and a Board of five Aldermen, irrespective to the Wards provided for in said charter, approved August 19th, 1911. Further amendment. Next election. Terms. Subsequent elections.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be further amended by striking Section Five (5) therefrom and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to-wit: Section 5. It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep a well-bound registration book for the registration of qualified voters, which book shall be open at all times, except it shall be closed ten (10) days before any general or special election, and when such qualified voter or voters are once registered they shall not thereafter be required to register or further qualify as voters, and shall be and remain qualified voters so long as they, or he, has paid all taxes assessed against them by the City of Folkston and shall have complied with the State law as to qualified electors. It shall be the duty of the Mayor and Board of Aldermen to appoint three citizens of said City of Folkston each year to act as registrars whose duty it will be to call upon the City Clerk to furnish, for their inspection, his permanent registration book as hereinbefore provided, and to proceed to purge said registration list at least five days before any general or special election, and to furnish to the election managers holding any election a registration
list of all qualified voters of said city, and it shall be the duty of the election managers to use said furnished registration list and no other. Further amendment. Registration of voters.

Sec 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section Seven (7) of the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from said section the words, The salary of the Mayor shall be one dollar per annum and for officiating as Police Judge he shall receive all fees derived from defendants only on cases tried in Police Court and collected in said Court; provided, the city shall, in no case, be liable for fees, and inserting in lieu thereof the words: The salary of the Mayor shall be fixed by the Board of Aldermen in January of each year, at the first regular meeting of said Board in January of each year, and said salary shall not be less than one dollar nor more than one hundred dollars per annum, with no Police Court fees or other emoluments, so that said Section Seven (7) when so amended shall read as follows, to-wit: Section 7. The salary of the Mayor shall be fixed by the Board of Aldermen in January of each year, at the first regular meeting of said Board in January of each year, and said salary shall not be less than one dollar nor more than one hundred dollars per annum, with no Police Court fees or other emoluments. The Aldermen shall receive one dollar per annum and be exempt from street tax. The compensation of the City Clerk, City Treasurer, City Assessors and such other officers as deemed necessary and shall be provided for and named by proper ordinance adopted by the Board of Aldermen, shall have their compensation fixed by the Board of Aldermen. Further amendment. Mayor's salary.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton,
State of Georgia, be further amended by striking Section Thirteen (13) therefrom and inserting in lieu thereof the following, to-wit: Further amendment.

blockquote.p: Sec. 13. That the election managers to hold any general or special election, shall be appointed by the Mayor and Aldermen of said city and be either the Ordinary of Charlton County, a Justice of the Peace, and a freeholder, or the Ordinary and two freeholders, or a Justice of the Peace and two freeholders or three freeholders, who shall be paid the sum of two dollars per day each for their services. They shall employ such clerks as they may deem necessary, who shall receive such compensation as the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may allow. On the day following the next election provided for in this Act and all subsequent elections, the election managers shall assemble in the city and organize by the election of one of their number as secretary. They shall examine the votes cast, consolidate the same, and declare the result in the same manner as prescribed by law for the election of members of the General Assembly. All cases of contested elections shall be tried before the Mayor and Board of Aldermen. Election managers.

law.p: Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be further amended by striking therefrom Section Fourteen (14). Act of 1911, sec. 14. stricken.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be further amended by striking therefrom Section Twenty (20). Sec. 20 stricken

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That Section Twentytwo (22) of the Act approved August 19th, 1911, incorporating the City of Folkston, in the County of Charlton, State of Georgia, be, and the same is, hereby amended by
striking from said section the words and it is hereby provided that at the last meeting of the Board of Aldermen in the month of December of each year the City Clerk shall transmit to that body a statement of the financial transactions of the city during the year ending December 15th in lines six, seven, eight, nine and ten of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the following words, to-wit: And it is hereby provided that at the end of each quarter the City Clerk shall transmit to the Board of Aldermen a statement of the financial transactions of the city during said quarter, so that said Section Twenty-two (22), when so amended, shall read as follows, to-wit: Sec. 22. All claims against the City of Folkston shall be filed with the Clerk, who shall sumbit the same to the Mayor and Board of Aldermen. All payments shall be made under an appropriation by the Board of Aldermen and upon a voucher drawn upon the City Treasurer by the City Clerk and signed by the Mayor; and it is hereby provided that at the end of each quarter the City Clerk shall transmit to the Board of Aldermen a statement of the financial transactions during said quarter. This statement upon its approval by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall be published in the official city paper. This statement shall show the number of vouchers issued, to whom issued, for what and the amount, the source from which all funds have been received, cash on hand, and in whose hands, the total indebtedness of the city, and such other facts and figures as will give the public a proper knowledge concerning the true financial condition and transactions of the city of Folkston. Sec. 22 amended. Claims. Vouchers.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all Acts heretofore approved by the General Assembly relating to the City of Folkston, except such part or parts thereof as may be in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby continued in operation, confirmed and consolidated with and made a part of this Act. Charter consolidated.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act, approved August 4, 1917, being An Act to divide the City of Forsyth, Monroe County, Georgia, into six Wards, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act approved August 4, 1917, being an Act to divide the City of Forsyth, Monroe County, Georgia, into six Wards, and for other purposes, is hereby repealed. Act of 1917 repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act creating and establishing the Glenwood Public School System, being an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 19, 1919, and contained in the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia for the year 1919, Pages 598 et seq.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act that the Act entitled An Act to establish a system of public schools in the Town of Glenwood, Georgia; to provide for the carrying on, management, control and support of the same; to provide for a Board of Education, and other officers of said school system, and prescribe their powers and duties, and for other purposes; to provide for bonds and voting in thereof for the purchase or lease of property in which to carry on said school system, after submitting the same to the qualified voters of the Town of Glenwood, and the same is ratified by a two-thirds vote thereof, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and said Glenwood public school system, as created and established in said Act, is hereby abolished. Act of 1919 repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GLENWOOD, TOWN OF; QUALIFICATIONS AND REGISTRATION OF VOTERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act incorporating the Town of Glenwood, formerly in the County of Montgomery, but now in the new County of Wheeler, and entitled An Act to create a new charter for the Town of Glenwood, etc., approved August 11th, 1908, and contained in Acts, 1908, pages 711 et seq., so as to provide who shall be entitled to vote in the elections of said town, and to provide a system of registration for the voters thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the Act approved August 11th, 1908, contained in Acts, 1908, Pages 711 et seq., and entitled An Act to create a new charter for the Town of Glenwood, in Montgomery County, and to incorporate said town and to prescribe its limits; to provide for a Mayor and Councilmen for said town, and to prescribe their duties and powers; to vest in said new incorporation all property and other rights now vested in the Town of Glenwood; to supersede the present charter of same as granted by the Superior Court of Montgomery County; to authorize the establishment of a system of public schools for said town, and provide for building and equipping suitable public school buildings;to provide for a system of waterworks; to provide for all other matters of municipal cognizance, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, amended by striking from Section Three thereof the last sentence in said section, which reads as follows, to-wit: The qualification of voters at such election shall be such as are required for electors for the General Assembly, and in addition thereto residence within the corporate limits of said town for six months next preceding the election, and the payment of all legal taxes required of them by said corporation. Act of 1908 amended. Former qualifications.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding thereto a section to be numbered Section 41 and to be and to read as follows, to-wit: Further amendment.

blockquote.p:
The qualification of voters at all elections in and for said town shall be the same as that required for electors for members of the General Assembly, except the qualification now required as to sex, and in addition thereto, residence within the corporate limits of said town for six months next preceding said election, the payment, at least fifteen days before the date of election, of all legal taxes, fines, licenses, street taxes and assessment of all
kinds, required or assessed by said town that are due, and registration as hereinafter provided. That the women of said town who qualify in all other respects except as to sex, shall be entitled to vote in the elections held in and for said town. New qualifications.

law.p: Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding thereto the following section, to be known and numbered Section 42, to-wit: Further amendment.

blockquote.p:
That the Mayor and Council of said Town of Glenwood shall provide, and the Clerk of said town shall keep open at all times (except as hereinafter provided), a book to be designated as `Voters' Book,' containing on the top of each page thereof the following oath, to-wit: `I do solemnly swear or affirm that I am a citizen of the United States; that I am twenty-one years of age, or will be on the second Saturday in December of this calendar year: that I have paid all taxes, State, county and municipal, which, since the adoption of the Constitution of 1877, have been required of me, except the taxes for this year, and that I am not disfranchised from voting by reason of any offense committed against the laws of said State; and that statements opposite my name in said book as to my age and occupation are true; so help me God.' That said Clerk shall keep said book open for registration at all times during office hours and shall permit the voters of said town to register therein, at any time, on application made to him. The applicant for registration shall read the oath, or the same shall be read to such applicant by the Clerk of said town, and the applicant shall subscribe to the same by signing his or her name, or causing his or her name to be signed, in the voters' book underneath the written or printed oath above described; and a memorandum of the age of such registrant shall be made by the registrant at the time of registration, and, if not twenty-one years of age, a memorandum of the date when such registrant will arrive at
the age of twenty-one shall in like manner be made, showing the date in that year when the registrant will attain twenty-one years of age. Note shall likewise be made, where the registrant has not resided in the State, county or in said town for the required length of time, showing the date in the year when such registrant will have resided in said State, county or town for the required time. No person shall be entitled to vote in any election held in and for said town unless such voter shall have been registered on said voters' book, as above required, for thirty days next prior to such election. The qualifications for registration shall be as follows, to-wit: The person must be, in all respects except as to sex, qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of Georgia, in the County of Wheeler, and must have paid all taxes, since the adoption of the present State Constitution, to the State, county and Town of Glenwood, which have been required and which such registrant has had an opportunity to pay, agreeably to law, except for the year of the election. No person shall be registered who does not apply to the City Clerk in person upon the days and within the hours of business. Registration. Voter's oath. Qualifications.

All persons who have registered on said book, under the terms of this Act, shall be and shall remain registered until they become disqualified, for some reason, and their names removed therefrom, as hereinafter provided.

Before any regular or special election, in said town, the Clerk of the town shall make out a list from said book, of all the names appearing thereon which were subscribed thereto thirty days prior to the date of such election, of all registrants who will be twenty-one years of age and who will have resided in said town, county and State for the required period, by the date of such election, and deliver said list to the registrars named by the Mayor and Council of said town, at least fifteen days prior to such election. The Mayor and Council of said town shall appoint three freeholders therein, who
may or may not be members of Council, to receive, examine and purge said list of registered voters, and it shall be the duty of said registrar to strike and remove the names of all voters from said list who have not paid, fifteen days prior to such election, all taxes, fines, licenses, street taxes, and assessments of all kinds, that are then due, and, also, who may be, or who may have become, disqualified for any other reason to vote in such election. That said registrars shall return said list so purged to the Clerk of said town ten days prior to such election and the Clerk shall strike and mark from said voters' book the names of all registrants who may be found to be disqualified by said registrars, and such registrant so marked from said book shall not be entitled to vote in any election in said town, until such registrant has qualified and again registered under the terms of this Act. That said Clerk shall post said list so purged at the door of the Council Chamber eight days prior to the date of such election, and any person in said town whose name may not appear thereon, and who claims to be qualified to vote, or any person who may question the right of any voter to vote in such election whose name appears on said list, may give notice thereof to said Clerk in writing and said Clerk shall then and there appoint a time, then giving notice to those concerned, and call said registrars together, at least five days before the date of such election, to hear such complaint, and the action of the registrars on said complaint shall be final. List of voters. Registrars.

No person shall be allowed to vote at any election in said town who has not been duly registered according to the provisions herein set forth, and whose name does not appear on said list as finally purged and approved by the registrars.

law.p:
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the above rules and regulations for registering and voting, in the elections of said town, shall apply to any primary held therein by any party to nominate candidates for municipal office,
as well as to all other elections of said town, and no one shall be permitted to vote in any such primary who is not then qualified to vote in the general election for which such candidate is to be nominated. Primaries.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a system of public schools for the Town of Grantville, Coweta County, Georgia, to provide for the maintenance and support of the same; to provide for a Board of Education and other officers of said school system, and to prescribe their powers and duties; to provide for the submission of the same to the qualified voters of the said town; to provide for the issuance of bonds for said purpose, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there may be established in the Town of Grantville, in this State, a system of public schools to be established, conducted, maintained, supported and controlled in the manner provided by this Act. Establishment.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the Board of Education of the Town of Grantville, Coweta County, Georgia, shall consist of five members elected at same time and in the same manner as the Mayor and Councilmen of said town are elected. At the first election after the passage of this Act, one member shall be elected for one
year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years and one for five years, so that after the first election under this Act one member shall be elected annually at the same time the elections for Councilmen are held, for a full term of five years, or until their successors are elected and qualified. All vacancies occurring in said Board by death, resignation or otherwise than by expiration of terms of office, shall be filled by the remaining members electing some qualified citizen of said town to fill said vacancy, or vacancies, and such persons so elected shall hold office for the balance of the unexpired term to which they were elected. No member of the Board of Education shall serve as Mayor or Councilman or Tax Assessor of the Town of Grantville. Any one qualified to vote for Mayor and Councilmen under the charter of the Town of Grantville shall be qualified to vote for members of the Board of Education. Immediately after this Act is ratified, as hereinafter provided, the Mayor and Councilmen of said Town of Grantville shall elect five citizens of said town who shall serve as a Board of Education until the first regular election of a Board as provided in this Act, and who shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified. The Board of Education of the Town of Grantville created by the provisions of this Act, shall be a body corporate with the right in them and their successors to take and hold in trust for said Town of Grantville any grant or devise of land or donation or bequest of money or other property made to it for educational purposes, with the right to sue and be sued; with the right to purchase suitable lot or lots for school buildings and to erect thereon a school building or buildings, or to purchase lots with a building or buildings thereon; to purchase equipment and furnishings and grounds for school purposes. The said Board of Education is authorized and empowered to establish and maintain a thorough system of public and high schools on said premises so purchased; to-conduct
dormitories, to put buildings thereon by donations from others, to make contracts and to do any and every other thing that may be necessary or proper for the conduct and carrying on of said public and high school system in the Town of Grantville. The qualifications for members of the Board of Education shall be the same as prescribed in the charter of said town for Mayor and Councilmen. Board of education. Election and terms. Vacancies. Interim board. General powers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That before entering upon the discharge of the duties of said office, each member of said Board shall take and subscribe to the following oath before some officer authorized under the laws of this State to administer oaths: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge the duties devolving upon me as a member of the Board of Education of the Town of Grantville, to the best of my skill and ability, and in accordance with what shall to me appear for the best interest of the community and the cause of education, and without fear, favor, affection, reward or the hope thereof, so help me God. A majority of said Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Oath of office. Quorum.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That at the first meeting of said Board after their election, as provided in this Act, and annually thereafter, at their first meeting after the election of a new member of the Board as provided in this Act, they shall organize by electing a Chairman for the ensuing year, and also a Chairman pro tempore to act in the absence or disqualification of the Chairman, and also by electing some competent person as Secretary and Treasurer of the Board. Said officers shall be elected by ballot or by acclamation as said Board may see proper. The Chairman and Chairman pro tempore shall be members of said Board, but the Secretary and Treasurer need not be a member of the Board, but may be a citizen of said town who is in the opinion of the Board qualified to perform the duties of the office. The Clerk of the Town of Grantville may, in the discretion of the Board,
be elected Secretary and Treasurer thereof. The members of said Board of Education shall receive no compensation for their services as such. Organization and officers.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the Secretary and Treasurer to keep a record of all the official acts and doings of the Board of Education, which records shall at all times be kept open to inspection of any tax payer of said Town of Grantville. He shall also give bond in sufficient amount with good security to be adjudged by the Board, payable to the Board of Education of the Town of Grantville for the faithful discharge of his duties, and the safe keeping and proper disbursement of all money which may come into his care by reason of his trust. He shall receive all public school money from the proper authorities, receive and receipt for all incidental fees and all other moneys he may be entitled to receive and keep a record of all moneys so received and paid out by him and take proper vouchers for all disbursements, but shall pay out no funds except by order of the Board entered upon the minutes. He shall receive such compensation for his services as may be fixed by said Board, not to exceed two per cent. of the amount of money received by him, which amount said Board is hereby authorized to contract for and pay out of the public school funds. Secretary and treasurer.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That said Board of Education shall elect a superintendent and teachers and other officers for the public schools of Grantville, fix their salaries, contract with them as such, and pay the same out of the money coming into their hands; and shall have the right and authority to suspend or remove said Superintendent or teachers whenever in their discretion they deem it best to do so, and shall suspend or expel any pupil from attendance upon said school when, in the opinion of the majority of the Board, it shall be for the interest of the school, and their action in so doing shall be
final and complete. Said Board shall also be empowered, and it shall be their duty, to borrow money for the support and maintenance of said schools, when necessary, and repay the same with legal interest from the funds coming into their hands, and they shall at all times supervise, regulate and make efficient said school system, fixing the length of the terms and time of opening and closing the same, prescribe the curriculum, the text books and books of reference to be used therein, and shall do any and all such acts, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, as may promote the system of education. Superintendent; teachers. Funds borrowed. Regulation of system.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That said Board of Education shall annually make to the Mayor and Council of said town a written report of all moneys received and disbursed by them which shall be spread upon the minutes of the said town Council. Financial reports.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the Board of Education to establish such grammar schools and high schools as may be necessary for the education of the children attending said schools, and tuition in same shall be free to all children within the school age residing within the Town of Grantville, up to and including the seventh grade, but the Board shall have a right, when in their judgment and discretion it is necessary to do so, to charge a tuition fee for all grades in said schools above the seventh, not to exceed $5.00 per month. They shall also have the right to charge a matriculation fee not to exceed $3.00, for the entire school year, to be paid by each pupil attending said school. Said matriculation fee may, in the discretion of the Board, be paid in such instalments as the Board may direct. Children of non-residents may be admitted to such schools established under the authority of this Act upon such terms and conditions and upon the payment of such tuition as may be prescribed by the Board of Education of the Town of Grantville. Schools. Fees.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the County School Superintendent of Coweta County or other counties of the State, to make contract with the said Board of Education of said town to teach pupils of school age residing in their respective counties and outside the corporate limits of the Town of Grantville, and to pay said Board out of that portion of the school fund of the State belonging to their respective counties, in like manner and under the same provisions as teachers in schools of their respective counties are paid; provided, however, that in case the rate of tuition for non-resident pupils, as fixed by said Board, is higher than the public school rate authorized to be paid by the County School Superintendent, then said Board of Education shall have the right to contract for, charge and collect said difference from the parent or guardian of said non-resident pupils. Contracts with county system.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the Board of Education of the Town of Grantville shall prepare and take a census annually, after the passage and ratification of this Act, of all the children residing in said Town of Grantville who are, under the law, entitled to participate in the State public school fund, and furnish a report of the result of said census to the State Superintendent of Education on or before the first day of September each year, unless said Board shall prefer and shall contract for the share of the public school fund to which they may be entitled through the County Board of Education of Coweta County. Census.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That the State school fund may be supplemented by an ad valorem tax levied by the town Council of the Town of Grantville, as follows: The Board of Education shall, by the first day of September of each each year make an estimate of the amount necessary to be raised that year for the additional support of public schools in said town and place
this estimate before the town Council of said town and when the same is approved by said town Council it shall be the duty of said Council, when making the annual tax levy for the current expenses of said town, to levy a school tax along with the other town taxes upon all property within the corporate limits of the Town of Grantville, and the said town Council is hereby authorized and required to levy said school tax and collect or have the same collected by the officers of said town along with the ad valorem taxes of said town in the same manner as other taxes are levied and collected; provided, however, that said Mayor and Council of the Town of Grantville shall have no authority to levy and collect a tax for said purpose of more than one-half of one per cent. of the value of all the taxable property within said town for school purposes. School tax.
Sec. 12. There shall be separate schools provided for white and colored pupils. White and colored schools.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That before this Act shall become operative, it shall be submitted to a vote of the qualified voters of the Town of Grantville, and in order to carry out provisions of this section the Mayor and Council of said Town of Grantville shall order an election, of which election thirty days' notice shall be given by publishing a notice of the time and place of holding same in some newspaper published in said county, or by posting a notice of said proposed election at three or more public places in said Town of Grantville. Said election shall be held under the same rules and regulations as elections for Mayor and Council of said town, except as herein otherwise provided, and the qualifications for voters shall be the same. Those voting in said election in favor of the establishment of said public school system shall have written or printed on their ballots, For public schools, and those opposed shall have
written or printed on their ballots, Against public schools. The managers of said election shall make returns to the Mayor and Council of said town who shall open said returns and declare the result of the said election at the first regular meeting of said Council held thereafter, and if two-thirds of those voting in said election shall vote for public schools, then this Act shall take effect immediately, but otherwise not. Should this Act fail of adoption, however, at said first or any other subsequent election held for this purpose, the Mayor and Council may, in their discretion, submit the same to another election under the same rules and regulations as are herein provided for said first election after the lapse of six months from said first or any other election, at which the same shall have been previously defeated, and if, at any subsequent election, the same should be adopted by a two-thirds vote, it shall then become effective. The Mayor and Council of the Town of Grantville shall call the election herein provided for whenever they deem best. Election to ratify. Ballots. Result.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Town of Grantville shall have power and authority to issue bonds of said town, from time to time, not to exceed in the aggregate the sum of $50,000.00, or so much thereof as may be necessary for the purpose or purchasing a suitable lot or lots for school buildings and to erect thereon a school building or buildings, or to purchase lots with a building or buildings thereon to be used for school purposes; or to purchase equipment and furnishings and grounds for school purposes. The bonds herein provided for to be in addition to any bonds heretofore issued by said Town of Grantville for school purposes, and are to be issued upon complying with the general laws of the State of Georgia governing bond elections for municipal corporations. Bond issue, for what purposes.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to revise and consolidate the several Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, granting and amending the charter of the City of Griffin, in Spalding County, Georgia; to amend the charter of said city; to declare the rights and powers of said municipality, and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same.

Section 1. Corporate Name. The inhabitants of the territory hereinafter designated in Spalding County, Georgia, are hereby continued corporated by the name and style of the City of Griffin, a body politic and corporate, with all the powers hereinafter specified, and such other powers as are granted by the General laws of the State of Georgia to municipal corporations. Corporate name.

Sec. 2. Corporate Limits. The corporate limits of said city shall extend one mile in every direction from the center of the former county court house, which is now used as the county jail, and shall form a circle two miles in diameter, provided, however, that the Act of the General Assembly, approved August 14, 1909, is continued of full force, to-wit: The State hereby cedes to the City of Griffin the perpetual right to the possession of Camp Northern, and the right perpetually to use and enjoy the same for park or other purposes, except that in the event
of war, the State may, and it reserves the right to use and occupy the property hereby ceded for military purposes, but in no other event will it interfere with the possession and use of said property by the City of Griffin. And further, that the police authority and jurisdiction of the City of Griffin is hereby extended over the territory hereby ceded, and jurisdiction of violations of the municipal ordinances of the City of Griffin is hereby vested in the criminal court of the City of Griffin. Territorial limits.

Sec. 3. Corporate and Governing Authority. The municipal government of said city shall consist of a commission of three citizens, who shall be known as the Board of Commissioners for the City of Griffin. Said Commissioners shall be the legislative and governing authority of said city. Governing body.

Sec. 4. Corporate Powers. As a body corporate said city may sue and be sued, have and use a common seal; it may own, purchase, have, hold, receive, and enjoy any estate, whether real, personal or of any other kind, located within or without the limits of said city, and may by authority of the Board of Commissioners thereof, sell or dispose of the same for the benefit of said city, as said Commissioners at any regular meeting may adjudge proper and right. General powers.

Sec. 5. Qualification and Election of Commissioners. The said Commissioners shall be elected by the qualified voters of said city, and shall be citizens of said city. Any person eligible to vote for members of the General Assembly and for Commissioners for the City of Griffin shall be eligible to hold the office of Commissioner for said city; provided, that no person shall be eligible to said office or to any other office in said city who is the holder unaccounted for of any public fund under either the Federal, State, County or City Government, and that such Commissioners shall be freeholders at the time of election to office. Election commissioners. Eligibility.

Sec. 6. Commissioners' Term of Office. The said Commissioners shall be elected for a term of two years, or until their successors are elected and qualified, unless removed in accordance with the provisions of this charter.
