calling an election to fill the office of Mayor and Aldermen of said town, and a Town Marshal, whenever there shall be a vacancy from death or failure to hold an election on the day fixed by the charter, or for any cause whatsoever, and to provide for the time and manner of holding said election and declaring the result thereof, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the corporate limits of the Town of Omaha in Stewart County, Ga., is defined as follows: Commencing at a point near the northwest corner of the original survey of said town, at the intersection of the north side of the right-of-way of Seaboard Air Line Railway and lands of D. B. Fitzgerald, thence running west six hundred feet, thence south twenty-five hundred feet, thence east six hundred feet to southwest corner of original survey of said town, thence south to public road leading to Florence, Ga., thence along the north side of said road in an easterly direction to a point where the extended north and south line of original survey of said town on east side intersects said road; thence north along said original north and south line to the south bank of Hannahatchee Creek, thence along the south bank of said Hannahatchee Creek, to a point directly opposite the west boundary of said corporate limits so that all the territory lying between the eastern and western boundaries of said corporate limits, and north of the right-of-way of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, and south of Hannahatchee Creek, as herein defined to be the corporate limits of said Town of Omaha. Territorial limits.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the Board of Aldermen of the Town of Omaha shall have no power and authority to assess, levy or collect any annual ad valorem taxes upon any farming land which are used solely for farming purposes, but this Act shall not be
construed to apply to any real property except such land as is used for agricultural purposes only, and this exemption shall not apply to those small tracts used in connection with residence lots or small patches or gardens that may be cultivated within the corporate limits of said town. Agricultural land tax.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That on the first Wednesday in September, 1921, there shall be held an election for a Mayor and five Aldermen in and for said town, three of said Aldermen to be elected for a term of one year, and said Mayor and two of said Aldermen to be elected for a term of two years. Annually thereafter on the first Wednesday in September, there shall be held an election for three Aldermen or for a Mayor and two Aldermen, as the case may be, with the exception that the Mayor and two Aldermen elected in September, 1921, shall hold office for a term of two years and until their successors are elected and duly qualified. That all elections for Mayor and Aldermen or for Aldermen of said town shall be held at the Justice Court House in said town, and the polls shall be kept open between the hours of ten a. m. and three p. m., whenever held. Said election shall be held by a Justice of Peace and two freeholders, residents of said town, or by three freeholders, residents therein, said Superintendents in either case to be appointed by the Mayor of said town, and if the office of Mayor is vacant then by any Justice of the Peace of said District, and said election in all respects shall be governed by the requirements and provisions of Section No. 5 of the Act to create a new charter for the Town of Omaha, in Stewart County, approved August 14th, 1906. Mayor and aldermen; elections, terms.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That in event that the office of Mayor or one or more of the members of the Board of Aldermen shall become vacant by death, resignation,
removal or for any cause whatsoever, that the Mayor of said town or one or more members of the Board of Aldermen or the citizens of said town shall have the authority to call an election to fill any vacancy in the office of Mayor or Board of Aldermen by posting a written notice that an election will be held after the expiration of ten days from the day said election notice is posted at the Court House door in the Town of Omaha. Vacancies.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That whenever any election is held either on the first Wednesday in September, 1921, or at any time thereafter for the purpose of electing a Mayor and Aldermen of said Town of Omaha, or to fill any vacancy in the office of Mayor or Board of Aldermen of said town, the persons or person so elected shall within thirty days from the date said election was held, shall qualify by taking an oath before an officer of this State to well and truly perform the duties of the office to which they have been elected, and upon failure to qualify by any person thus elected within the time herein prescribed, another election shall be held to fill said vacancy caused by the failure of the person elected to qualify. Oath of office.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all the provisions of the several Acts incorporating the town of Omaha which are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act, and not repugnant thereto, are confirmed by this Act, and that all other laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PELHAM CHIEF OF POLICE, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act amending the charter of the Town of Pelham so as to provide for the election of the Chief of Police by the people, and for other purposes, approved July 19, 1920, and to provide for the election of the Chief of Police of the Town of Pelham by the Mayor and Council of said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act that the Act approved July 19, 1920, entitled An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Pelham so as to provide for the election of the Chief of Police by the people and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Act of 1920 repealed.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Council of the Town of Pelham shall have power and authority to elect a Chief of Police for said town and such additional policemen as they may deem necessary; that said Mayor and Council of the Town of Pelham shall have power and authority to fix the salary or fees of said Chief of Police and additional policemen and shall have power to prescribe their duties and require such bond of them for the faithful performance of their duties as they may deem necessary and proper. Policemen, appointment by mayor and council.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the Town of Pelham to authorize the Mayor and Town Council of the Town of Pelham to sell and convey the municipal light plant and water plant and all equipment and appliances connected therewith, and also the distribution system and transmission line used in connection with said electric light plant, including all appliances used therewith.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia. and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same. That the Town of Pelham shall be vested with the right and authority by and through its Mayor and Town Council to sell and convey the municipal light and water plant and all equipment and appliances connected therewith. and also the distribution system and transmission line used in connection with said electric light plant, including all appliances used therewith. Power to sell plants.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act, approved August 17, 1912, entitled An Act to amend an Act to incorporate the Town of Pine Park in Grady County, approved August 15, 1910, by striking out the figures 1913 in the last line of Section 27 of said Act and inserting
in lieu thereof the figures 1912, and for other purposes; by striking the words and the official organ of Grady County, out of line sixteen (16) and the words majority of the qualified voters out of line seventeen (17), of Section one of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the words two-thirds majority of the qualified voters, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, that the words and the official organ of Grady County in line sixteen (16) Section 1 be stricken, and that the words majority of the qualified voters in line seventeen (17) Section 1 be stricken and the words two-thirds majority of the qualified voters inserted in lieu thereof, so that said Section 1, when so amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1910 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the Town of Pine Park in the County of Grady, approved August 15, 1910, be amended by striking out the figures 1913 in the last line of Section 27 of said Act and inserting in lieu thereof the figures 1912, so that the Section as amended will read as follows: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Council upon petition of the majority of the qualified voters of said town may order an election and submit to the qualified voters of said town the question of establishing a system of public schools for the Town of Pine Park and if upon the holding of said election after twenty days advertisement at three places in said town should two-thirds majority of the qualified voters in said town vote for the establishment of a public school system, then the said Mayor and Council may declare a system of public schools established for said town and said Mayor and Council shall have the power to devise, design and adopt a system of
public instruction in said town under said election and shall have exclusive jurisdiction of all schools established under said system and shall be authorized to modify the same from time to time as circumstances may require, to appoint, remove or support teachers in said schools in their discretion, to fix salaries for such teachers; to prescribe a curriculum in said schools, to make such by-laws, rules and regulations for the government and control of such schools as they may think proper; and they are hereby empowered upon adoption of said school system; to levy such taxes for the support of such schools upon the property in said town returned for taxation as said Mayor and Council may deem proper not to exceed one-half of one per cent; provided, however, that no election under this charter can be ordered by said Mayor and Council upon the petition of the citizens as herein set forth prior to the first day of October, 1912. To be read. Election to establish.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal Act No. 330 of the Acts of 1905, creating the independent local school system of Pineview, and all amendments thereto, in order that the Pineview Public Schools may be a part of the Wilcox County System, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Act No. 330, approved August 16, 1905, beginning on page 507 and extending through page 513, creating and establishing the independent local
school system in Pineview, and all amendments thereto, are hereby repealed and the Pineview Schools are constituted a part of the County System as they were previous to the passage of Bill No. 363. Act of 1905 repealed. Schools in county system.
Sec. 2. Be it enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Charter of the City of Quitman; to abolish the officers of Mayor and Aldermen and certain other offices of said city, created by legislative enactment; to provide for a Commissioner-Manager form of government for said city; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act, approved August 23rd, 1905, entitled An Act to amend, consolidate and supersede the several Acts incorporating the City of Quitman, in the County of Brooks, State of Georgia; to create a new charter and municipal government for said corporation; declare the rights and powers of same, and for other purposes; with the Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended in the following particulars. Act of 1905 amended.

Section 1. That in lieu of the Mayor and Councilmen of the said City of Quitman there is hereby created and established a Commission of three citizens, who shall be known as the Board of Commissioners for the City of Quitman. Said Commissioners are hereby given all rights, powers and authority heretofore vested in the
Mayor and Councilmen of the City of Quitman, except as otherwise provided herein, and the Commission is further given the full power and authority to ratify the election and employment of all police and other officers, and agents and employees of said City of Quitman, together with the right to fix the term of office and employment, to prescribe the duties, to name the compensation, to ratify the discharge from service without cause or notice of any officer, employee, or agent of said City of Quitman, or to discharge such officer, employee, or agent, as provided in Section 8 sub-section (j) of this Act, and to designate the office and employment by such name as the Commission deems expedient; except as in this Act otherwise provided. Commission to supersede mayor and council.

Sec. 2. The said Commissioners shall be elected by the qualified voters of said city and shall be citizens of said city who, under the said Act of 1905, are eligible to be Mayor and Councilmen of said city. Election and eligibility.

Sec. 3. The said Commissioners shall be elected for a term of three years, beginning January 1st of each year, and until their successors are elected and qualified; provided, that of the first three Commissioners elected under the provisions of this Act one shall hold office for a term of one year, one for a term of two years, and one for a term of three years, and the said first three Commissioners so elected shall, within thirty days from their election, cast lots for the term to be held by each, and the successors of each shall be elected for a full term of three years. Said election shall be held on the 6th day of December, 1921, and shall be held under the supervision and control of the Ordinary of said county, subject to the laws now of force for holding elections for Mayor and Councilmen of said city, and the returns from said election shall be made to said Ordinary, who shall declare the result thereof. In case there is a tie vote between candidates a new election shall be ordered by said Ordinary in not less than ten days or more than 15
days from the election, which election so ordered shall be only between the candidates receiving the same number of votes, and elections shall be called as often as may be necessary by the Ordinary until a candidate or candidates may be elected. Terms. First election.

Sec. 4. That on or before the first day of January of each year the Commissioner or Commissioners elected shall be notified of their election and shall appear before a Judge or Clerk of some Court of Record or before some Justice of the Peace and take and subscribe the following oath: I swear that I will faithfully and impartially demean myself as a member of the Board of Commissioners for the City of Quitman during my continuance in office and in all things pertaining to my office. I will be governed by what in my judgment is for the public good and the best interest of the City of Quitman, so help me, God. Oath of office.

Sec. 5. The Board of Commissioners shall, at their first meeting in each year, elect one of their members as Chairman of the Commission, or, if unable to agree, the Ordinary of said County shall appoint one of said Commissioners as Chairman of the Commission, and said Chairman of the Commission shall exercise all of the powers and shall have imposed upon him all of the duties now exercised by and imposed upon the Mayor of said city so far as the trial of violators of the laws and ordinances are concerned, until otherwise provided by the Commissioners of said city by the establishment of a Recorder's Court or otherwise. Each of said Commissioners shall receive a salary of $20.00 per month, except the Chairman, who shall receive a salary of $30.00 per month. Chairman. Salaries.

Sec. 6. In said Commission shall be vested all the powers heretofore vested in the Mayor or the Mayor and Council of the City of Quitman, except as otherwise provided in this Act. It shall have full authority to pass ordinances, levy taxes, make appropriations, fix licenses,
and shall have all the rights and powers heretofore given the Mayor or the Mayor and Council, except as otherwise provided in this Act. General powers.
Sec. 7. The Chairman of said Board shall have the powers and authority heretofore vested in the Mayor of said city, except as otherwise provided in this Act. Powers of chairman.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners shall select and appoint a City Manager within thirty days after their election and qualification, who shall be the administrative head of the municipal government, and who shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments. City manager.

He shall be appointed without regard to his residence, political beliefs or affiliation. During the absence or disability of the City Manager the Commissioners may designate some properly qualified person to execute the functions of the office. The powers and duties of the City Manager shall be: Appointment. Powers and duties.

item.p: (a) To see that all laws and ordinances are enforced.
(b) To exercise control over all departments and divisions created therein, or which may be hereafter created by the Commissioners.
(c) To attend all meetings of the Commissioners, with the right to take part in all discussions, but having no vote.
(d) To recommend to the Commissioners for adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary and expedient.
(e) To prepare and submit to the Commissioners an annual budget.
(f) To keep the Commissioners fully advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city.
(g) To supervise and direct the official conduct of all appointive city officers, except as herein otherwise provided.

(h) To supervise the performance of all contracts made by any person for work done for the city, and to make all purchases of materials and supplies for the city under rules and regulations of the Commissioners.
(i) To perform such other duties as may be prescribed herein as may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the Commissioners; and

(j) To appoint and discharge all subordinate officers and employees in all departments; all appointments to be made upon merit and fitness alone; said right of appointment and discharge being subject to the ratification and approval of the Commission at its next regular meeting after such appointment or discharge; provided, however, that if the Commission shall desire the discharge of any officer or employee of the city and the Manager shall, upon demand of the Commission, refuse to discharge such officer or employee, said Commission may, by proper order, passed at a regular meeting, discharge such officer or employee.

law.p:
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the City Manager may be removed from his office or employment at any time by a majority vote of said Commissioners without cause or notice, and said Commissioners shall fix his compensation or salary; provided that the present City Clerk and Treasurer, City Attorney, and other officers of the city (except the Mayor and Councilmen) shall hold their respective offices and receive the compensation as at present provided therefor until the expiration of the term for which they were elected or appointed, unless sooner removed in the manner at present existing. Upon the election and qualification
of said Commissioners, on or after January 1st, 1922, the term of the Mayor and all of the Councilmen shall terminate. Removal. Terms of present officers.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners shall each year cause to be printed a detailed, itemized statement of receipts and disbursements of the city and a summary of its preceding year. Financial statement.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners may require the said City Manager to come before them at any time and answer questions either orally or in writing and may require from said City Manager, at any time they see fit, written reports upon any matter involving the city that they deem proper, and the City Manager shall report weekly to said Commission his general actions and doings, and shall regularly at stated intervals, at least quarterly, file full and complete reports of the various departments of the city. Manager's reports.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said City Manager shall devote his entire time to the office and the members of the Commission shall devote as much of their time as may be necessary. The said Commission shall meet at least once each month at stated periods, and shall hold their meetings in public except when they deem executive session necessary; shall keep minutes of their proceedings, and shall record all their actions. All votes shall be taken by aye and no and shall appear on the minutes. They shall be required to meet at such times and as often in extra meetings as any two of them or the Chairman may designate or call. The Chairman shall appoint one of the Commissioners Chairman pro tem, who may exercise the routine duties of the Chairman in case of the Chairman's absence or inability to act for any reason. In the case of a vacancy in the office of any Commissioner the remaining Commissioners shall call an election to fill such
vacancy under such provisions as are now in force relative to filling vacancies on the Council of said city or that may be hereafter adopted by said Commission. Time devoted to office. Meetings. Vacancies.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no Commissioner shall, before going into effice, solicit votes for himself or others, or promise any person to appoint him to office, or promise to vote for such person or any other person to any office or agency or employment under the city. For the violation of this provision the said Commissioner shall be liable to be punished upon conviction as for a misdemeanor, the punishment to be defined by the Criminal Code of Georgia of 1910, Section 1065. Soliciting of votes; etc. Penalty.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate name and organization of the City of Quitman is hereby in all respects preserved, as in the original Act of 1905, and the Acts amendatory thereof; and all Acts not inconsistent with this Act are hereby declared of force. Acts not repealed.

Sec. 15. That after the first election for Commissioners herein provided for elections shall be held annually on the first Tuesday in December, under the rules and regulations now provided for holding elections for Mayor and Councilmen, and such other rules and regulations as may be hereafter adopted by said Commission for the election of a Commissioner to succeed the Commissioner whose term of office expires January 1st following and the Managers of the election shall give the persons elected a certificate of election, which certificate will entitle the holder to be installed into the office. Elections.

Sec. 16. Be it further enacted, That a special election in the City of Quitman, to be held under the same rules and regulations as to registration and qualifications of voters and other conditions of city elections, on the fourth day of October, 1921, next between 7 A. M. and 6 P. M. The tickets for said election shall have written
or printed thereon the words: For Commission Government, or Against Commission Government, and if a majority of those voting in said election shall vote for For Commission Government this Act shall be in full force and effect. Election to ratify.
Sec. 17. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act, incorporate the Town of Robertstown, in the County of White, to grant certain powers and privileges to said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act to incorporate the Town of Robertstown, approved August 16, 1913, be, and the same is hereby repealed. Act of 1913 repealed.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend the charter of the City of Rossville, Walker County, Georgia, approved August 24, 1905, and all Acts amendatory thereof, so as to abolish
the public school system of said City of Rossville; to provide for the extension of the corporate limits of said City of Rossville; to establish and maintain a system of waterworks for said city; to authorize and empower said City of Rossville, by and through its Mayor and Council, to issue and sell the bonds of said city, not to exceed the sum of thirty thousand dollars, for the purpose of establishing and maintaining said system of waterworks, after the same is approved by a two-thirds vote of the qualified voters of said city, as prescribed by law; to provide for the sale of said bonds, and for the payment of the principal and interest thereon; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by said authority, That from the passage of this Act that the Act approved August the 24, 1905, entitled An Act to incorporate the City of Rossville, in the County of Walker; to appoint a Mayor and Council therefor; to prescribe their powers and duties, and the manner of their election; to grant powers and privileges to the same; to provide for working roads and streets in said city; to provide a system of public schools for the same, and for other purposes, that so much of said Act that provides for a system of public schools for the City of Rossville, with all provisions relating thereto, as embraced in the Act incorporating the City of Rossville, and all Acts amendatory to the system of public schools for the City of Rossville, are hereby repealed. Act of 1905 amended.

Sec. 2. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That Section 2 of the Act incorporating the City of Rossville, Georgia, approved August 24, 1905, and Section 10, amendatory to said Act, approved August 22, 1907, and all amendatory Acts thereto are hereby amended by defining the corporate limits of said
city as follows: That the corporate limits of said city shall begin on the State line between Georgia and Tennessee at Mrs. A. E. Morrison's northeast corner, said corner being about one thousand feet west of the point where Rossville avenue crosses said State line; thence south to Mrs. A. E. Morrison's southeast corner; thence southwest in a straight line running one hundred yards west of the Peerless Woolen Mill to Maple street; thence west along the north side of Maple street to Flegal avenue; thence west from corner of Flegal avenue on south side of Maple street fifteen hundred and fifty-feet to corner on Maple street and the land of John F. Bryan; thence running south along the line of John F. Bryan's land fourteen hundred feet to corner with land of J. W. Carlock; thence east along the line of J. W. Carlocks's land nine hundred feet to corner on Henderson street; thence south along the west side of Henderson street through J. W. Carlock's land seven hundred and thirty-two feet to corner with the lands of Jo Long and S. A. Hanley; thence west along the land line of S. A. Hanley, two hundred and ten feet to corner with the land of Crawford Brown; thence south along the land line of S. A. Hanley and Crawford Brown, and straight across Dry Valley public road four hundred and sixty-five feet to corner with the land of J. R. McFarland, on south side of Dry Valley public road; thence eastwardly along the land line of J. R. McFarland, on south side of Dry Valley public road one hundred and eighty-eight feet to corner; thence south in a straight line through the land of J. R. McFarland six hundred and fifty feet to corner of the land of A. W. Wotring and J. R. McFarland; thence south along the west land line of A. W. Wotring, E. G. Carroll and in a straight line through A. L. Ellis' land seven hundred and eighteen feet to corner of A. L. Ellis' land with open street; thence eastwardly along the land line of A. L. Ellis, and open street four hundred feet to Government road; thence eastwardly from corner of
Government road and along the south line of O. L. Miller eleven hundred and fifty feet to corner on the east side of the right-of-way of the Central of Georgia Railway; thence in a northerly direction and along the east side of the right-of-way of the Central of Georgia Railway, thirty-three hundred feet to corner on the right-of-way of the Central of Georgia Railway with original line of the City of Rossville, at a point on the east side of Central of Georgia Railway eastward from Jackson street; thence eastwardly through the tract known as the Chickamauga Cement Company's tract and along the original line of the corporate line of the City of Rossville one thousand feet to corner; thence northward along the original city line of Rossville and through the tract known as the Chickamauga Cement Company's tract of land to Mrs. A. E. Morrison's southwest corner, south of field known as Long's field; thence northwest along land line to the Mrs. M. M. Thomas estate and along original city line to said corner; thence west and northeast along land line between tract known as the Chickamauga Cement Company's tract of land and the lands of the Mrs. M. M. Thomas estate to the tract of land formerly known as the J. M. McFarland tract of land, and along original city line of Rossville to southwest corner; thence southeast along land line and original city line of Rossville, to point ten feet west of Leinbach road; thence northeast along original city line of Rossville and ten feet west of center of Leinbach road to the south right-of-way of the road formerly known as the old Rapid Transit Electric Railroad and original city line of Rossville about eleven hundred feet to stock gap; thence east along original city line of Rossville to west right-of-way of Chickamauga avenue, or Government road; thence in a straight line across Chickamauga avenue or Government road eastwardly two hundred and fifty-five feet to corner on the Morrison land on the east side of the right-of-way of the Chattanooga Railway Light Company's Fort
Oglethorpe street car line; thence along the east right-of-way of the Chattanooga Railway Light Company's Fort Oglethorpe street car line in a northerly direction eleven hundred and seventy feet to the Georgia-Tennessee State line; thence west with Georgia-Tennessee State line to point of beginning. Territorial limits.

Sec. 3. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act of the Legislature incorporating the City of Rossville, Georgia, and approved August 24, 1905, and all Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended, so as to authorize the Mayor and Councilmen to call an election to provide for the issue of bonds for the purpose of constructing, contract for, establish and maintain a system of waterworks for said Town of Rossville, Georgia, for all purposes usual and incident to waterworks systems for municipal corporations, and to furnish water to private parties, manufacturing industries, and charge and collect for same, and generally to manage and conduct said waterworks system as the City Council of said City of Rossville, Georgia, may in its discretion deem best and proper. Waterworks bonds.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That provided that the proportion of votes required by the Constitution of the State of Georgia be cast at an election to be called by the City Council at such time as, in its discretion, it may deem proper, shall be For bonds for water, the City Council of said City of Rossville, Georgia, be, and it is, hereby authorized to issue and sell from time to time in its discretion, said City Council may deem best. The issue of said bonds not to exceed thirty thousand ($30,000.00) dollars in the aggregate; each bond to mature not later than fifteen years after date of its issue, and to bear interest at a rate not exceeding seven (7) per cent. per annum, payable semi-annually. The principal
and interest of said bonds to be payable in gold coin of the United States of the present standard of weight and fineness. The sale of said bonds shall be for the purpose of securing funds wherewith to enable the City Council of said City of Rossville, Georgia, to purchase, build, contract for, establish and maintain a system of waterworks for said city. In the event of the issue of any of said bonds, the City Council shall by ordinance, provide for the levy and collection of an annual special tax upon all property, both real and personal, in said city, for the purpose of raising moneys sufficient to pay the semi-annual interest on said bonds, and to provide a sinking fund herewith to pay the principal of said bonds at their maturity. Election. Maturity and interest rate. Sale.
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to create a Board of Harbor Commissioners for the City and Port of Savannah; to provide for the appointment and term of office of said Commissioners; to define the powers and jurisdiction of said Board; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, there is created and established in the City of Savannah a Board of Harbor Commissioners for the Harbor and Port of Savannah, which shall be known as the Board of Harbor Commissioners for the City and
Port of Savannah. The said Board shall consist of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the Governor of Georgia upon the nomination of the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah. One Commissioner shall be appointed for one year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years, and one for five years. Upon the resignation, death or removal from office of any of said Commissioners, a successor shall be appointed by the Board for the unexpired term. Upon the expiration of the term of office of said Commissioners, their successors shall be appointed for the term of five (5) years each. The principal office of said Board shall be at the City Hall in the City of Savannah. Said Commissioners shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for all necessary expenses. A majority of said Commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and the Commissioners shall employ a secretary and such other clerks as may be necessary to keep fair minutes and entries of all orders, regulations and transactions of said Commissioners in a book or books to be kept for that purpose, which said minutes and entries shall be submitted to the inspection of any person or persons who shall desire to see and peruse the same. Said Board shall elect out of its own number a President, Vice-President and a Secretary, whose duties shall be those usual to such offices. Said Board shall meet at regular sessions, not less than once a month, and at such other times as the President of the Board shall convene them, or on written request of three members. Establishment. Five members. Appointment. Terms. Successors. No compensation. Quorum. Clerks. Minutes. Officers. Meetings.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall have the power to regulate the commerce and traffic of the Harbor and Port of Savannah in such manner as may in their judgment be best for its maintenance and development. It shall have and enjoy all of the rights, powers and immunities incident to corporations. It
shall be empowered and it shall be its duty to take charge of and administer the public wharves of the City of Savannah; the construction of new wharves where necessary, and to erect warehouses or sheds thereon; to place and keep the wharves, warehouses, sheds and approaches in good condition; to maintain sufficient depth of water at said wharves; said Board shall have jurisdiction also over the lighterage and tow boat companies operating in the Port of Savannah, and shall make rules and regulations governing the services of such companies in said port. Powers. Corporate body.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Commissioners shall make rules for regulating, stationing and anchoring ships, vessels and boats in the Savannah River and its navigable tributaries, or at the wharves, piers or bulkheads, or in the docks, slips or basins, extending into or on the said river and its navigable tributaries, for removing from time to time ships, vessels and boats in order to accommodate and make room for others, or for admitting river crafts to pass in and out of the docks, slips and basins, and for compelling the Masters and Captains of ships, vessels and boats to accommodate each other, so that ships, vessels and boats shall, for a reasonable time, be entitled to berths next to the wharves, piers and bulkheads until they have landed or loaded their cargoes. Legislation.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall have power to make surveys and soundings, ascertain the capacities of the aforesaid river and its navigable tributaries for commercial purposes, and to prepare plans therefrom, and to keep records thereof. They shall also have power to regulate, fix and establish State, county or city owned property bulkhead and pierhead lines and a distance between piers, subject to the regulations of the United States Government; to adopt and
promulgate rules and regulations for the constructions, extensions, alteration, improvement and repair of wharves, piers, bulkheads, docks, slips and basins. Surveys and soundings.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners is hereby authorized and empowered to charge vessels and ships entering the Port of Savannah the customary harbor fees. Said Board shall also have the right to provide rates and wharf charges for vessels and ships occupying the public wharves and terminals under the jurisdiction of said Commissioners in such amounts as said Board of Harbor Commissioners may deem proper. Said Board is further empowered to fix a maximum dock charge for vessels at privately owned terminals. Harbor fees, etc.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners is hereby authorized and empowered, with the concurrence of the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, to acquire by purchase or condemnation in the exercise of the right of eminent domain, or both, all lands, property, property rights, leases or easements deemed necessary by said Board for the establishment of additional wharves and terminals in the Port of Savannah, either within or without the corporate limits of said city. All proceedings with regard to the exercise of the rights of eminent domain by said Board in the acquiring or damaging of land, property, property rights, leases or easements, shall be in the manner provided by the laws of the State of Georgia in the exercise of said right by other public corporations. Eminent domain.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall have the right to expend such monies as may be appropriated to it by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah or by the State of Georgia, or derived by it from fees and charges on ships and for the use of the
wharves and terminals in the Port of Savannah or from any other sources for the purpose of acquiring additional wharves and terminals in the Port of Savannah and for the improvement of and the addition to such public wharves and terminals as may be in existence at the time of the passage of this Act. Disbursements.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the purpose of acquiring lands, easements and rights for the establishment of new wharves and terminals and erecting and building warehouses and piers and digging slips and deepening the water adjacent thereto, the said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall have the right to issue bonds in an amount not greater than sixty (60%) per centum of the appraised value of the properties owned at the time by said Board; such bonds, however, to be issued only after the same have been authorized by an election of the qualiefid voters of the City of Savannah. Such election to be called by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, and to be held under the provisions of existing laws relative to elections for the issuance of bonds by counties and municipalities provided in Article 1. Chapter 6 of the 6th Title of the Code of Georgia of 1910; said bonds shall be validated as provided in Article 2 of said Chapter and said Title. The said bonds shall in no event be an obligation of the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, but shall be paid solely out of the monies and revenues of said Board of Harbor Commissioners, and from the property owned by said Board. Said Board shall establish a sinking fund for the retirement of said bonds. Bonds.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid. That the Harbor Master, Port Warden and Captain of the Port of Savannah, or such of said officers as may be in existence, shall be under the jurisdiction and control of said Board of Harbor Commissioners. Said officers
shall be nominated and elected by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah. The salaries of said Harbor Masters and Captain of the Port shall be paid by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah until such time as said Board of Harbor Commissioners may be able to pay such salaries, in such event it shall be the duty of the said Board of Harbor Commissioners to pay said salaries, either in whole or in part, as they may be in position to do. Port officers.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall have the right to make such rules and regulations for the Harbor and Port of Savannah as they may deem proper. They shall also have the right to establish harbor lines in the Savannah River between such points in Chatham County as they may deem proper, and to enact rules and regulations for persons building or erecting structures of any character in said river on either side thereof within the city limits. Regulations.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever any person or persons shall desire to construct, extend, or alter any wharf or pier, or to erect, extend, alter, or improve any other harbor structure into or on the aforesaid river and its navigable tributaries within the city limits, such person or persons shall make application to the President of the Board of Harbor Commissioners, stating in writing the nature and extent of such intended wharf, pier, or other harbor structures or buildings in the nature of a wharf, or harbor structures, aforesaid; and file in the office of the President of the Board of Harbor Commissioners the plans and specifications showing fully the proposed erection, construction, extension, alteration or improvement and produce their deeds, or other evidence of title, to the property to be so occupied, altered or improved; whereupon the President of Board of Harbor Commissioners
shall give notice of the time and place of hearing such application, to all parties interested by advertising twice a week for two successive weeks, in two newspapers of general circulation published within the county in which such work is to be done, and by posting such notice upon the premises referred to in such application; it shall give its consent and issue a license for the erection, construction, extension, alteration or improvement for which application shall have been made, and cause the same to be recorded in the office of the President of the Board of Harbor Commissioners, in a book to be kept by the said President of the Board of Harbor Commissioners for that purpose; and such license shall not be unreasonably withheld. Alteration of harbor structures. License.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any person or persons aggrieved by any decision of the said Board of Harbor Commissioners granting or refusing in whole or in part, any application for a license to erect, construct, extend, alter, or improve any wharf, pier or bulkhead or other harbor structure, or as to any other thing under this Act, may within thirty days after the date of said decision present a petition to the Superior Court of Chatham County, Georgia, setting forth the facts in the case and the ground of petitioner's complaint, and thereupon said Court, having first caused reasonable notice of the presentation of the said petition, and of the time fixed for the hearing thereof, to be given to all persons who may be legally interested therein, shall proceed to hear and determine the subject matter of the said petition; and said Court shall make such order in the premises as it may deem legal and proper, and the said order shall be final and conclusive. It shall be lawful for the said Court to appoint a Commissioner to take evidence to be used at the said hearing and to make such order for the payment of the costs, by one or more of the parties to the proceeding, as it may see fit and as justice may require. Appeals.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all rules and regulations adopted by said Board of Harbor Commissioners shall before becoming effective be approved by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, and after being so approved, the said Mayor and Aldermen may provide that said rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of ordinance of the City of Savannah; and said Mayor and Aldermen shall have the power and authority to provide a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and of a penalty of not more than thirty days' imprisonment, either or both, or any part of either or both, for the violation of any such rules and regulations of said Board of Harbor Commissioners. Regulations approved by mayor and aldermen.

Sec. 14. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall annually appropriate such sum or sums of money as it may see fit or deem necessary for the maintenance or support of said Board of Harbor Commissioners. The said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have the right to convey and transfer to said Board of Harbor Commissioners the title to any and all public wharves, terminals and lands acquired for wharf, dockage, warehouse and factory site purposes on the Savannah River owned by said Mayor and Aldermen at the time of the passage of this Act, or which may be afterwards acquired by it, and said Board of Harbor Commissioners for the City and Port of Savannah is hereby authorized and empowered to receive the title to such property and to own the same for the purpose as stated in this Act. Appropriations for maintenance.

Sec. 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it is understood public wharves as used herein shall refer to any wharf or terminal owned by the
State, county or city or to a private wharf, or terminal which the owner thereof gives the public the right to use at all times without charge. Wharves under jurisdiction.
Sec. 16. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all Acts or parts of Acts in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to alter, revise and amend the several Acts relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of City of Savannah; and for other purposes.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That in all cases where the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall deem it necessary to repave, redrain and remacadamize or otherwise improve any street, alley, avenue, lane or other public place which has been paved or improved prior to the passage of the Act of the General Assembly of August 18, 1919, found in Georgia Laws of 1919, page 1294, or which shall have been heretofore macadamized or drained under the provisions of said last named Act, such repavement, redraining or remacadamizing or other improvement is hereby authorized to be done and in pursuance of the provisions of said Act of August 18, 1919, and Acts amendatory thereof, and in such cases, all provisions of said Act providing for making such improvements and levying assessments therefor and the issuance of bonds shall apply, provided that in the judgment of said Mayor and Aldermen of said city the pavement or improvement is worn out and no longer serviceable. Street improvements.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all cases where the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall deem it necessary to resurface any existing pavements on any street, alley, avenue, lane or other public place, which pavement was laid prior to the passage of the Act of the General Assembly of August 18, 1919, found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294 and following, or which shall have been laid under the provisions of said last named Act, and which pavement may not be worn out or no longer serviceable as a pavement as defined in the preceding section, the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah is hereby authorized to resurface the existing pavement on any such street, alley, avenue, lane, or other public place in pursuance of and under and by virtue of the provisions of said Act of August 18, 1919, and Acts amendatory thereof, and in such cases all provisions of said Act providing for paving and improving and levying of assessments therefor and the issuance of bonds shall apply, as well as all other provisions of said Act, provided that in the judgment of said Mayor and Aldermen the said paving which is to be resurfaced is rough, or uneven, or unsuited for traffic, or renders traffic difficult. Resurfacing.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all cases where the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall begin proceedings to resurface any existing pavement on any street, alley, avenue, lane, or other public place in the City of Savannah under and by virtue of Section 2 of this Act and of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia of August 18, 1919, aforesaid, and Acts amendatory thereof, but shall be unable to proceed with the said resurfacing of such existing pavement by reason of a protest in writing being filed by the owner of more than one-half in area of the land liable to assessment to pay for such improvement and resurfacing as provided for in Section 12 of the said Act of August 18, 1919, then and in such event, and thereafter, the Mayor and Aldermen
of the City of Savannah shall have the authority to resurface any existing pavement on any street, alley, avenue, lane or other public place and which pavement may not be worn out and no longer serviceable as a pavement, as defined in Section 1 of this Act, under and by virtue of and in pursuance of the provisions of the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia found in Georgia Laws 1884-85, page 263 and following, in Georgia Laws 1887, page 537, and in Georgia Laws 1910, page 1142, and in all such cases the provisions of said last named Acts providing for paving and improving and levying assessments therefor, as well as other provisions of said Acts, shall apply, provided that in the judgment of said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah the said paving which is to be resurfaced is rough or uneven, or unsuited for traffic, or renders traffic difficult. Acts of 1919, 1884-5, 1887, 1910 made applicable.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 23 of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294 and following, entitled An Act to alter and amend the several Acts relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from the fourth line of said Section the word exclusive and inserting in lieu thereof the word inclusive, so that said Section 23 when amended will read as follows: Act of 1919, sec. 23 amended.

blockquote.p: Section 23. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the publication of all notices in a daily newspaper called for in this Act shall be the number of days therein specified inclusive of Sundays and legal holidays. Notices.

law.p:
Sec. 5. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any regular employee of the City of Savannah, of the age of sixty years or upward, who has served well and faithfully for a period of twenty-five years or
more, (of which five years' service must have been continuous and immediately before his retirement) shall, upon application to the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, be retired from active service and shall during the remainder of his life receive a pension of one-half of the salary paid him at the time of his retirement, the pension however, in no event to exceed $100.00 per month, but he shall be subject to call for active duty for at least fifteen days of each month. Pensions.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 15 of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294 and following, entitled An Act to alter and amend the several Acts relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, be and the same is, hereby amended by striking the words stating the material to be used, in the 11th and 12th lines of said Section and inserting in lieu thereof the following words stating the several character of paving materials in the alternative proposed to be used, from which one is later to be selected on the opening of bids hereinafter provided, so that when said Section is so amended it will read as follows: Act of 1919, sec. 15 amended.

blockquote.p:
Section 15. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That after the expiration of the time for objection or protest on the part of the property owners, if no sufficient protest be filed or on receipt of a petition for such improvement signed by the owner of more than one-half in area of the land to be assessed, if such petition shall be found to be in the proper form and properly executed, the said Mayor and Aldermen shall adopt a resolution reciting that no such protest has been filed, or the filing of such petition as the case may be, and expressing the determination of said Mayor and Aldermen to proceed with the said improvement, stating the several character of paving materials in the alternative proposed
to be used, from which one is later to be accepted on the opening of the bids hereinafter provided, and the manner of construction, and defining the extent, character and width of the improvement, and other such matter as may be necessary to instruct the Chief Engineer of said city in the performance of his duties in preparing for such improvement the necessary plans, plots, profiles, specifications and estimates. Said resolution shall set forth any such reasonable terms and conditions as said Mayor and Aldermen shall deem proper to improve with reference to the letting of the contract and the provisions thereof, and the said Mayor and Aldermen shall by said resolution provide that the contractor shall execute to the city a good and sufficient bond in an amount to be stated in such resolution, conditioned for the full and faithful performance of the work and the performance of the contract, and for the protection of the city and all property owners interested, against any loss or damage by reason of the negligent or improper execution of the work, and may require a bond in an amount to be stated in such resolution for the maintenance in good condition of such improvements for a period of not less than five years from the time of its completion, or both in the discretion of said Mayor and Aldermen. Said resolution shall also direct the Chief Engineer of said city to advertise for sealed proposals for furnishing the materials and performing the work necessary in making such improvements. The notice of such proposal shall state the street, streets, or other public places to be improved, the kind of improvements proposed, what if any bonds will be required to be executed by the contractor aforesaid, and shall state the time when and the place where such sealed proposals shall be filed and when and where the same will be considered by said Mayor and Aldermen. Said notice shall be published in ten consecutive issues of a daily newspaper of general circulation in the City of Savannah. At the time and place specified in such notice the Mayor and Aldermen shall examine all
bids received, and without unnecessary delay award the contract to the lowest and best bidder who will perform the work and furnish the materials which may be selected and perform all the conditions imposed by the said Mayor and Aldermen as prescribed in said resolution and notice for proposals, which contract shall in no case exceed the estimate of cost submitted by the Chief Engineer with the plans and specifications, and the said Mayor and Aldermen shall have the right to reject any and all bids and re-advertise for other bids when any such bids are not in its judgment satisfactory. Paving materials.

law.p: Sec. 7. Be it further enacted by the authority, That wherever in the said Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved August 18th, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294, and following, as well as the Acts amendatory thereof and in this Act, certain duties are prescribed to be performed by the Chief Engineer and the Assistant Chief Engineer of said city, such duties can be performed and carried out by the Director of Public Works of said city in place of the Chief Engineer and by the City Engineer in place of the Assistant Chief Engineer, and when so performed by said Director of Public Works and said City Engineer, shall be legal and valid and binding. Director of public works; engineers.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That wherever and whenever said Mayor and Aldermen shall have undertaken to pave, or repave, or resurface, or otherwise improve any street, lane, alley or other public place in the City of Savannah, under and by virtue of the provisions of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18th, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294, and following, and the Acts amendatory thereof and under the provisions of this Act, and the proceedings for such paving, repaving, resurfacing and improvement, and the assessments thereof, shall be held to be invalid for any reason, either before or after the paving, or repaving, or resurfacing,
or otherwise improving the street, alley, lane or other public place has been done, then and in such event the assessments for such paving, repaving, or resurfacing, or improvement against the property and property owners shall be made and levied and collected under and by virtue and in pursuance of the provisions of the Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, found in Georgia Laws 1884-1885, page 263, and following, also in Georgia Laws 1187, page 537, and in Georgia Laws 1910, page 1142, and such assessments so made under the provisions of the last named Acts shall be legal and binding upon the property benefitted and upon the property owners. All proceedings heretofore had by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah under and by virtue of the Act of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, approved August 18th, 1919, and found in Georgia Laws 1919, page 1294, and following for the paving or repaving of any street, lane or alley or other public place in the City of Savannah are hereby declared to be valid, it being the intention of the General Assembly of Georgia in the said Act of August 18th, 1919, to include and import in the use of the word pave as used in Sections 10 and 12 of said Act the right to repave any such street, alley, lane or other public place whenever the same was in the judgment of said Mayor and Aldermen worn out and no longer serviceable. Invalid paving proceedings. Assessments.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have power and authority to assess and levy the street or commutation tax now authorized to be assessed and levied upon persons residing within the corporate limits of the City of Savannah between the ages of twenty-one and sixty years, also upon persons between said ages who work or labor daily within said corporate limits of said city or who have a fixed occupation therein but who reside without the corporate limits of the City of Savannah; provided, however, that persons who reside within other taxing
jurisdictions which require its residents to perform street or road duty or pay a commutation tax in lieu thereof, and who have actually performed such street or road duty or paid a commutation tax equal to that assessed by the City of Savannah, then such persons shall be exempt from the provisions of this Section. Commutation tax.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act there is established a police district for and adjacent to the City of Savannah which shall embrace the land and territory outside the corporate lines of the City of Savannah which lies within the State of Georgia and within three miles in a straight line from any point of the present or future corporate limits of said City of Savannah. Police district.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have and exercise police powers and police jurisdiction over and in said police district. Police powers.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and ordinances in force in the City of Savannah, or that may hereafter be enacted by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah in reference to offenses against the public health, against the public place and tranquility, and against public morals, as well as all ordinances for the preservation of peace and good order and the safety of property shall be in force within the territory comprising the said police district in the same manner and to the same extent as they are in force within the corporate limits of said city, and for all purposes to prevent the commission of any and all of said offenses and suppressing the same in order to apprehend violators of said laws, police jurisdiction is hereby expressly given to the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah over the said entire territory embraced in said police district. To this end, the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have the power
to enforce said laws and ordinances by the police department of the City of Savannah just as they may deem proper and necessary for the full protection of the city. Provided, nevertheless, that no obligation shall rest upon the municipal authorities to establish any police system within said district, the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah being hereby given power and right to do so, which right the said Mayor and Aldermen may exercise in full, partial, or not at all, as in its judgment the best interest of the City of Savannah may require. Laws effective in police district.

Sec. 13. Be it further enacted, That that certain Act adopted and approved August 11, 1906, entitled: An Act to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Police Court of the City of Savannah, Georgia, and of the Recorder thereof; to provide for a Clerk of said court, defining his duties; declaring the police force of said city to be officers of said court, making provisions for the taking of bail, forfeiture of recognizances, and punishment for contempt, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding another Section to said Act to be numbered Section 15 as follows: Act of 1906 amended. New sec. 15

blockquote.p: Section 15. Be it further enacted, That wherever any woman may be convicted in said Police Court of a violation of any ordinance of the City of Savannah, the Recorder of said Court shall have the authority to provide that any term of imprisonment imposed upon any such woman shall be served by confinement of such woman at the Woman's Department of the State Farm at Milledgeville. Women, how punished.

law.p: Sec. 14. Be it further enacted, That the Mayor of the City of Savannah in case of absence or disability of the Clerk of Police Court is hereby authorized to designate some city employee to act as a Deputy Clerk for said Police Court, who shall have all the power and authority of the Clerk of said court while acting in said court as such Deputy Clerk. Deputy court clerk.
Sec. 15. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to revise, alter and amend the several Acts relating to and incorporating the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah, by providing for the establishment of a police district in the land and territory outside the corporate limits of the City of Savannah which lies within the State of Georgia and within (3) three miles from any point in the corporate limits; by providing that the municipal government of the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall exercise power and authority over said district for police purposes, and all laws and ordinances in force within the corporate limits of the City of Savannah with reference to offenses against public safety, public health and the peace, good order and welfare of persons and the safety of property shall be in force within the territory comprising the said police district; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authhority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there is established a police district for and adjacent to the City of Savannah, which shall embrace the land and territory outside the corporate lines of the City of Savannah which lies within the State of Georgia,
and within three miles in a straight line from any point of the present or future corporate limits of said City of Savannah. Territorial limits.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have and exercise police powers and police jurisdiction over and in said police district. Police powers.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and ordinances in force in the City of Savannah or that may hereafter be enacted by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah in reference to offenses against the public health, against the public peace and tranquility and against public morals, as well as all ordinances for the preservation of peace and good order and the safety of property, shall be in force within the territory comprising the said police district in the same manner and to the same extent as they are in force within the corporate limits of said city, and for all purposes to prevent the commission of any and all of said offenses and suppressing the same in order to apprehend violators of said laws. Police jurisdiction is hereby expressly given to the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah over the said entire territory embraced in said police district. To this end, the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah shall have the power to enforce said laws and ordinances by the police department of the City of Savannah just as they may deem proper and necessary for the full protection of the city. Provided, nevertheless, that no obligation shall rest upon the municipal authorities to establish any police system within said district, the said Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Savannah being hereby given power and right to do so, which right the said Mayor and Aldermen may exercise in full, partial or not at all, as in its judgment the best interest of the City of Savannah may require. Laws effective. Enforcement.
Sec. 4. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all Acts and parts of Acts in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved August 17th, 1912, creating a new charter for the City of Statesboro, so as to authorize the Mayor and Council of City of Statesboro to levy and collect an ad valorem tax on all property, real and personal, within the corporate limits of said city, not to exceed one and two-tenths of one per cent. for the purpose of raising revenues to defray the ordinary expenses of the City of Statesboro, and for paying the principal and interest on the bonded indebtedness of said city; and to amend said Act as amended by an Act approved August 1st, 1918. so as to authorize the Mayor and City Council of City of Statesboro to levy and collect an annual tax for school purposes, not to exceed seven-tenths of one per cent. on the real and personal property in said city, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That an Act approved August 17th, 1912 (Acts of 1912, Pages 1353-1354), entitled an Act to create a new charter for the City of Staaesboro, be amended by inserting between the words one in the seventh line and the words per cent. in the seventh and eighth lines of Section 38 of said Act, the words one and two-tenths of one, and by adding at the end of said Section 38 the following words: Provided, that a portion of the funds raised by the increased rate may
be used by said Mayor and City Council of Statesboro for the purpose of paying the principal and interest of the bonded indebtedness of said City of Statesboro, so that said Section 38 of said Act, when so amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1912 amended.

blockquote.p: Sec. 38. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the purpose of raising revenues to defray the ordinary current expenses incident to the support and maintenance of the city government, the said City Council shall have the full power and authority to levy and collect an ad valorem tax upon all property both real and personal, in the corporate limits of said city not to exceed one and two-tenths of one per cent., but when the amount is deemed insufficient, said City Council shall have the authority to levy an additional tax in the mode and manner provided by the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia; provided, that a portion of the funds raised by the increased rate may be used by said Mayor and City Council of Statesboro for the purpose of paying the principal and interest on the bonded indebtedness of said City of Statesboro. To be read. Tax rate. Sinking fund.

law.p: Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said Act approved August 17, 1912 (Acts of 1912, Page 1368), as amended by an Act approved August 1st, 1918 (Acts of 1918, Page 896), providing for the levy and collection of an annual tax for school purposes by the Mayor and City Council of Statesboro, be amended by striking from lines seven and eight and line twelve of Section One of said Act, approved August 1st, 1918, the words five-tenths of one per cent., and inserting in lieu thereof the words seven-tenths of one per cent., so that said Section One of said Act, when so amended, shall read as follows: Act of 1918 amended.

Sec. 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act approved August 17th, 1912, entitled
`An Act to create a new charter for City of Statesboro,' and as amended by an Act approved August 1st, 1918, be amended by striking from the fourth line of Section 60 of said Act the words `not to exceed five-tenths of one per cent.' and inserting therein the words `not to exceed seven-tenths of one per cent., so that Section 60 as amended shall read as follows: To be read.

blockquote.p: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Mayor and Council of the City of Statesboro are hereby authorized to levy a tax annually in addition to that now authorized by law, not to exceed seven-tenths of one per cent. on the real and personal property in the City of Statesboro for the purpose of establishing and maintaining a system of public schools in said city; provided, that the money so raised shall be used for school purposes as hereinafter set forth. School tax.

law.p: Sec. 3. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.fulltitle:
An Act to repeal the following Acts of the Georgia Legislature, to-wit: An Act to establish a system of public schools in the Town of Sylvester, Worth County, Georgia, approved December 18th, 1900; Section 22 of an Act to continue the school system of the Town of Sylvester in the name of the City of Sylvester, approved August 13, 1904, entitled an Act to incorporate and create the City of Sylvester, in the County of Worth, and prescribe the limits, etc., except that part of said section which provides that
all property and other things acquired by said town thereunder, shall become, and are hereby made, the right and property of the City of Sylvester and all other debts and liabilities of said town contracted and made under and by virtue of the said Acts, are assumed and are hereby made the debts, liabilities and obligations of the City of Sylvester, it being expressly understood that this part of said section is not repealed; an Act to amend an Act to establish a system of public schools in the Town of Sylvester, Worth County, Georgia, and also to continue the school of the Town of Sylvester, and establish the same as the school system of the City of Sylvester, approved August 13, 1904, to provide reports from the Sylvester schools to the County School Superintendent and the Board of Education of Worth County; to provide for the payment of the Sylvester schools by the Worth County Board of Education out of the State fund on the same basis as is provided for other schools of Worth County, etc., approved August 19, 1919; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the above recited Acts and parts of Acts be repealed, as follows, to-wit: An Act to establish a system of public schools in the Town of Sylvester, Worth County, Georgia; to empower the Mayor and Council of the town to levy and collect a tax for the support and maintenance thereof; to provide for the issuance of bonds of said town for the purpose of purchasing school property, building school houses, etc.; to create a Board of School Commissioners for the said town; to authorize and require the County School Commissioner of Worth County to pay or turn over to the said School Commissioners of the said town such part
of the State and county school fund as may be the just pro rata share of the said town, and for other purposes, approved December 18, 1900 Act of 1900 repealed.

Section 22 of an Act to continue the school system of the Town of Sylvester in the name of the City of Sylvester, approved August 13, 1904, it being entitled An Act to incorporate and create the City of Sylvester in the County of Worth, and prescribe the limits thereof; to provide for the Mayor and Councilmen and other officers of said city and provide to continue the present school system of the Town of Sylvester and establish the same as the school system of said city, and provide for the maintenance of the same, and for other purposes, except that part of said section which provides that all property and other things acquired by said town thereunder, shall become, and are hereby made, the right and property of the City of Sylvester, and all other debts and liabilities of said town contracted and made under and by virtue of the said Act are assumed and are hereby made the debts, liabilities and obligations of the City of Sylvester, it being expressly understood that that part of said section is not repealed. Act of 1904 amended. Property and indebtedness.

An Act to amend an Act to establish a system of public schools in the Town of Sylvester, Worth County, Georgia, approved December 18, 1900, and also to continue the school system of the Town of Sylvester and establish the same as the school system of the City of Sylvester, approved August 13, 1904; to provide reports from Sylvester schools to the County School Superintendent and the board of Education of Worth County; to provide for the payment to the Sylvester schools by the Worth County Board of Education out of the State funds on the same basis as is provided for other schools of Worth County; to provide for a biennial census of the children of school age within the limits of the City of Sylvester; to provide that the annual report of the
County School Superintendent include the report from the schools of the City of Sylvester, to provide for the qualifications of members of the Board of Commissioners of the City of Sylvester for the examination of teachers in the schools in the City of Sylvester, and for other purposes, approved August 19, 1919, are hereby repealed. Act of 1919 repealed.
