law.shorttitle: ACADEMY FOR THE BLIND; REPORT OF COMMITTEE.
law.p: Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, that the Standing Committee on Academy for the Blind of both the Senate and House be and they are hereby authorized during vacation to visit the Academy for the Blind and make their report to the next Session of the General Assembly. Report.

Resolved further, that the members of said committees, visiting said institution shall be paid their regular per diem and all actual traveling expenses, said payment to be made upon the itemized sworn statement of the committeemen filed with the chairman of the respective committees and said statements collectively filed by the chairman of each of the committees with the Governor of the State, who shall draw his warrant therefor upon the Treasury of the State. Compensation.

Be it resolved by the Senate of Georgia, the House of Representatives concurring, That a Committee of five members of the General Assembly, two from the Senate to be named by the President, and three from the House to be named by the Speaker, be appointed: Appointment.

item.p: First: To investigate and ascertain whether the District Agricultural Schools of this State are being operated in accordance with the requirements of the Acts of the General Assembly which created such schools, and all amendatory Acts thereto. Operation of schools.

Second: If any of said schools are not being operated in accordance with said requirements of law, to ascertain which schools are not being so operated, and wherein said schools fail to comply with said requirements. Failure to meet requirements.
Third: To examine into the courses of study taught in said schools, and ascertain wherein said courses of study differ from the courses of instruction available in High Schools. Courses of study.

Fourth: To compile a statement showing the number of students enrolled in each of said schools during each of the past ten years (from 1910 to 1920 inclusive), the average time attended, the number of graduates from each of said schools for each year during said ten year period, and as far as practical, what percent of said graduates of each school followed agriculture after graduation. Number of students.

Fifth: To compile a statement showing the cost to the State for each student in each of said schools, per year, for the past ten years, and to show on said statement for each year the cost of uniforms, and other fixed charges, and the cost of board, for the school year, which was paid by the parent or guardian for each child in each of said schools. Cost to state.

Sixth: The officials of said schools are hereby required to furnish all information called for in this Resolution, which may appear on the records of said schools, to the Committee named hereunder. Information furnished.

Seventh: The Committee to be named hereunder shall pursue said investigation, without cost to the State, after the close of the present session of the General Assembly, and before the convening of the General Assembly in regular session in June, 1922, at which time said Committee shall make its report of facts, with such recommendations as it may see proper to make thereon, to the General Assembly of 1922. Investigation and report.

law.p: Whereas, it is necessary to enact a new tax law for the State of Georgia, or to amend the existing tax laws of the State, and in order to properly accomplish this, it is necessary to employ the services of a competent stenographer: Preamble.

Therefore, be it resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, that the sum of Seventy-Five ($75.00) Dollars, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be, and the same is hereby appropriated to the Appropriation and Ways and Means Committee for the purpose of employing a stenographer to do said work. $75 for work on tax law.

Whereas, it is made to appear from the report of the Commissioner of Pensions, that it will require an additional sum of Eight Hundred Fifty-two Thousand ($852,000.00) Dollars to be added to the sum heretofore appropriated to complete the payment of the pension rolls, with the increases provided by law for 1921, to pay pensioners that are entitled to same under Acts 1919, therefore be it Preamble.

Resolved, by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, that the sum of Eight Hundred Fifty-two Thousand ($852,000.00) Dollars be and the same is hereby appropriated (or so much thereof as may be necessary, when added to the appropriation heretofore made) to complete the payment of the pension rolls of all classes, with the increases made in the amount of the pensions due for 1921, to pay pensioners that are entitled to same under Acts 1919, and be it further $852,000 to complete payment.

Resolved, that the Governor of Georgia be, and he is hereby authorized to draw his warrant, or warrants, on the State Treasury for the proper disbursement of the money herein appropriated, out of any funds in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated. Warrants for disbursement.

Whereas, the ravages and destruction by the boll weevil in the cotton producing states of the United States has gone beyond accurate computation in dollars and cents and today is practically unchecked, and Preamble.

Whereas, it would be in the interest of science, economy and humanity that abundant inducement be offered to bring about some form of discovery on a scientific basis which would rid our country of this pestilence and check its inroad upon one of the greatest necessities of the human family, and

Whereas, all research in that direction has thus far been left largely to the individual agricultural departments of the states and the nation, without any special inducement to the scientific brain of the world to devote itself to an effective discovery, therefore

Be it Resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, both branches concurring, That the Congress of the United States be and is memorialized to set aside a gratuity in the sum of not more than Five Million Dollars to be awarded as a prize to the scientist or person who will discover to the satisfaction of such examination as the Congress of the United States may deem necessary to provide an effective method of eliminating the boll weevil; the award of the prize or gratuity to be made in such manner that the right to the discovery shall become the property of the United States Government for the use of the people of the United States. Prize award.

Be it further Resolved, That a copy of this resolution be forwarded to each member of the National House of Representatives and the United States Senate properly
signed by the officials of this General Assembly, and the Clerk of the House of Representatives of Georgia is hereby instructed to carry out this provision of this resolution. Congress memorialized.

To authorize the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the County of Candler to receive from the King Lumber Company a building erected by it for a court house under a contract with said County of Candler for the erection of said court house, and to come to a full and complete settlement with the King Lumber Company for work done and money expended by it upon said court house, and to settle in full with said King Lumber Company for the purchase price of said court house, and to relieve the Board of County Commissioners of said County of Candler who entered into a contract with the said King Lumber Company for the erection of said court house and which contract was subsequently declared illegal, from all liability for money paid to King Lumber Company in the execution of said contract before the same was declared illegal, and for other purposes.

Whereas, on the 8th day of January, 1920, the Board of Commissioners of the County of Candler entered into a contract with the King Lumber Company for the purpose of the erection of a court house on land owned
by the County of Candler, in the Town of Metter, County Seat of Candler County, and known as the Tropnell Tract, and Preamble.

Whereas, at the time said contract was entered into the said County of Candler was without a court house or other public building within said Town of Metter for the purpose of holding the Court and furnishing offices for the county officers, and
Whereas, it was absolutely necessary to erect said building for the use of said County of Candler, the said county never having had a court house or other public building, and

Whereas, the said King Lumber Company under said contract, proceeded promptly to erect said court house and had expended about the sum of One Thousand Dollars in the actual execution of said contract, and in addition had expended, or contracted for about Twenty Thousand Dollars to be used in said building and

Whereas, after said sum had been expended, and said contract for material had been entered into by said King Lumber Company, certain citizens and taxpayers of said County of Candler, filed before the Judge of the Superior Courts of the Middle Circuit, a petition to enjoin the further execution and performance of said contract upon the ground that said contract had been illegally entered into by the said Board of County Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said County of Candler, the grounds being that the Board of County Commissioners had not legally advertised for bids before said contract was let, and
Whereas, upon a full hearing upon said application for injunction by the Court, the same was refused and the Court by judgment declared said contract valid and binding, and

Whereas, the plaintiffs in said case being dissatisfied with the judgment of the Court, excepted to said judgment by bill of exceptions and filed aid bill of exceptions in the Supreme Court of Georgia, and
Whereas, upon signing said bill of exceptions, the presiding judge refused upon the application of the plaintiffs to supersede his judgment, and
Whereas, the said case on said bill of exceptions was pending in the Supreme Court approximately nine months, and

Whereas, the conditions were such then existing in the County of Candler made it absolutely necessary for the proper conduct of public buildings, and for the proper protection of the county records, that the said court house should be completed at the earliest possible date, and

Whereas, the said King Lumber Company at the urgent request and insistence of the said Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues proceeded with the erection of said building while said case was pending in the Supreme Court, and during this period expended in the erection of said court house the sum of approximately Eighty-three Thousand Dollars on the original contract price of One Hundred Twenty-five Thousand Dollars and had completed about three-fourths of the work on said court house, the Supreme Court by its judgment declared said contract illegal, and the same was enjoined, and

Whereas, by reason of said judgment of the Supreme Court all work has been suspended upon said court house and it is now in an incomplete condition and it is impossible to complete same under said contract, and
Whereas, the sum of $49,407.24 has been paid by the county to said King Lumber Company and expended by the said King Lumber Company in the execution of said contracts, and

Whereas, the County has issued to the King Lumber Company Thirty-four Thousand Three Hundred and Nineteen Dollars in payment of work done upon said courthouse and material furnished by the said King Lumber Company for the erection of the same, and
Whereas, said amount of money was by the County Commissioners paid to the King Lumber Company and said warrants issued to them before said contract was declared to be illegal,
Therefore, be it Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring,

item.p:
1. That the present Board of Roads and Revenues of said County of Candler consisting of M. S. Dekle, W. J. Morgan, and Geo. O. Franklin, are authorized and empowered to contract with the said King Lumber Company to receive said court house for said County from said King Lumber Company whenever the same shall have been completed and delivered to said County in a complete condition, and the said Board of Roads and Revenues of said County of Candler is hereby authorized and empowered to come to a complete and perfect settlement with said King Lumber Company for all work done on said building and all money expended in the same, which was necessary for the completion of said building and its deliverance to the County by the said King Lumber Company as herein provided for; provided, however, that in making said adjustment the said County authorities shall pay only the sum actually expended for work and material in the erection of said building, the said amount not to exceed the sum of Ninety-six Thousand Dollars, and when said settlement is reached and
the said sum paid, the said King Lumber Company are relieved from any liability to said County of Candler on account of any money received by it and on account of its contract for the erection of said building before the same was enjoined by the judgment of the Court, and the warrants now held by the King Lumber Company issued to them by the County Commissioners in payment of the work done and the material furnished are hereby declared to be legal and part of the said sum to be paid by the County Commissioners herein provided for the completion of same. Contract and settlement. Payment to King Lumber Co.

2. Be it further Resolved, That W. L. Jones, H. L. Franklin and W. J. Smith, who composed the Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of said County of Candler at the time said contract with the King Lumber Company was entered into, and who as such Commissioners contracted with the King Lumber Company for the erection of said court house, be, and the same are hereby relieved from any liability to the said County of Candler for any money paid by them to the said King Lumber Company in the execution of said contract or for any county warrants issued by them to the said King Lumber Company. Commissioners relieved from liability.

law.shorttitle: CARROLL COUNTY; NUMBER OF COMMISSIONERS TO BE INCREASED.
law.p: Whereas, the County of Carroll has a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues of one member, and
Whereas, many people of said County are desirous of changing the present system to a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues consisting of five members; therefore, Preamble.

Be it Resolved, That an election be held in said County between January 1st and April 1st, 1922, for the purpose of acting on the question as to whether said County shall have One or Five Commissioners of Roads and Revenues, and, Election.

Be it further Resolved, That the Ordinary of said County shall call said election, fix the date thereof, and make all necessary arrangements therefor, giving notice thereof for a period of thirty days prior to said election in the legal organ of said County, and,

Be it further Resolved, That the returns of said election shall be made to the Ordinary of said County, who shall consolidate the votes and declare the result thereof; that the expense of said election be paid by said County as in regular elections. Returns and expenses.

Be it further resolved that those voting for five Commissioners of Roads and Revenues shall have written or printed on their Ballots For Five Commissioners and those voting against Five Commissioners shall have written or printed on their Ballots Against Five Commissioners, and if a majority of the votes cast are in favor of Five Commissioners the Representatives of said County are instructed to pass a Bill carrying into effect the wish of the people. Ballots.

law.shorttitle: CONFEDERATE SOLDIERS' HOME; BURIAL OF DEAD.
law.p: Whereas, the portion of ground allotted for the burial of the Confederate Soldiers, in Atlanta, is occupied, and Preamble.
Whereas, There is at the present time abundant room in the Cemetery at Marietta, Georgia, in which only Confederate Soldiers can be buried,

Therefore, be it Resolved, That a portion of the unoccupied ground of the Confederate Cemetery at Marietta, Ga., be set aside for burial of the dead from the Soldiers' Home in Atlanta, Georgia. Portion of cemetery set aside.

law.shorttitle: CONGRESSIONAL REAPPORTIONMENT COMMITTEE; MEETING DURING RECESS.
law.p:
Whereas, it is manifestly impossible for this Committee to take action and redistrict the State until after Congress passing some legislation authorizing the same which in all probability will be done within the next five or six weeks and after the adjournment of the present session of the Legislature, and whereas it is a matter of grave importance to the people of this State that a careful and equitable adjustment be made of the Congressional District of Georgia and in order that this may be done with the proper care of all concerned it is apparent
that the Committee on Congressional Reapportionment should meet during the recess of the General Assembly to prepare a bill redistricting the State. Preamble.

Therefore, be it Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, That the Committees on Reapportionment of the House and Senate meet during said recess upon call of the Chairman of each Committee for the purpose of preparing the necessary proposed legislation. Meeting.

Resolved, further, That the members of said Committees shall be paid their regular per diem and all actual expenses, payment to be made upon the itemized sworn statement of the Committees filed with the Chairman of the Committees and approved by him. Compensation.

law.shorttitle: DAUGHTERS OF CONFEDERACY, PRESENTATION OF PORTRAIT TO.
law.p: Whereas, there are now two oil paintings of General John B. Gordon owned by the State, and at present in the Capitol of the State and not in use, and Preamble.

Whereas, the Atlanta Chapter of the United Daughters of Confederacy are collecting portraits of all Southern Generals to place on the walls of their Chapter House located in the City of Atlanta, which Chapter House is accessible to all the Daughters of the Confederacy throughout the State, and
Whereas, said portraits of General John B. Gordon since not in use are subject to deterioration unless immediate and proper care is taken of them,

Be it, Therefore Resolved, That the Keeper of Public Buildings and Grounds is hereby directed to immediately deliver one of same to their representative on behalf of the State of Georgia. Delivery authorized.

law.shorttitle: DICKS, VINSON, FITZGERALD, AND McCALL; RELIEF AS SURETIES.
law.p: Whereas, J. T. Dicks, G. E. Vinson, David Fitzgerald and C. S. McCall, did on September 26th, 1918, become sureties on the bond of M. W. Huchinson, Tax Collector of Wilcox County, Georgia, for the faithful performance of his duties as such Tax Collector, for and during the term of office ending Dec. 31st, 1920, and Preamble.

Whereas, the said M. W. Huchinson, Tax Collector, having failed and neglected to account for a sum approximating $12,000.00 to the County of Wilcox, and judgment having been obtained against the said Huchinson and his bondsmen aforesaid, for said sum, and
Whereas, the said M. W. Huchinson, as Tax Collector aforesaid, and his said bondsmen, having settled in full with the State of Georgia for all monies due said State, and

Whereas, owing to the advanced age of the bondsmen in question, and of their straightened financial circumstances, and the certainty that they, and each of them will, if their property should be seized to satisfy the demands of said Wilcox County, be reduced to a state of bankruptcy and destitution, want and despair, and
Whereas, it appears to be more equitable that the loss, if any, should be sustained by the entire County, rather than by the aged, infirm, and embarrassed bondsmen in question,

Therefore, be it Resolved, by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That said bondsmen be, and they are hereby relieved from any and all liability on said bond of M. W. Huchinson, as Tax Collector of Wilcox County, Georgia. Relief from forfeiture.

law.shorttitle: ENTOMOLOGY BOARD; PURCHASE OF CALCIUM ARSENATE.
law.p: Whereas, the cotton boll weevil has become a menace to the citizens and more especially to the cotton producers of Georgia, be it Resolved, That the State Board of Entomology of Georgia be instructed and is hereby authorized to purchase in large quantities, calcium arsenate and supply same at actual cost to the cotton growers of the State of Georgia, in quantities of ten pounds and up in sizes required by the Department of Agriculture in supplying tags for the same; and we recommend that the State Board of Entomology have the authority to use from their annual appropriation as a revolving fund of $10,000 (Ten Thousand Dollars), for carrying out the provisions of this Resolution. Preamble. Purchase authorized.

law.shorttitle: FEDERAL TRANSPORTATION ACT; MEMORIAL TO AMEND.
law.p: Whereas, in recent decisions of the Interstate Commerce Commission interpretations have been given the Transportation Act of 1920, such as gives to the Interstate Commerce Commission complete authority over the entire subject of transportation and including the right to prescribe intra-state rates; Preamble.
And Whereas, it means, in effect, the abrogation of all authority of State regulation to make and prescribe rates for intra-state movement of freight;

And Whereas, the freight rates are in some instances so burdensome and excessive at this time as to prohibit the movement of various commodities, and the passenger rates are so excessive as to deter travel to the end that the railroads are receiving less in passenger revenues than they would receive if a lesser rate were in effect;

Therefore, be it Resolved by the House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, the Senate of Georgia concurring, That we call upon the Congress of the United States to so amend the Transportation Act of 1920, and in such plain language, that the authority of the States over intra-state traffic in their respective States, will be fixed and certain in language plainly declaring the right of States to prescribe intra-state rates. Congress memoralized.
Be it further Resolved, That a copy of this resolution be sent to each United States Senator and Congressman from the State of Georgia.

law.shorttitle: FISHING LAWS OF GEORGIA AND FLORIDA; UNIFORMITY ESTABLISHED.
law.p: Whereas, there now exists numerous conflicts between the laws of the States of Georgia and Florida pertaining to the taking and catching of fish from the salt waters of the two States, and Preamble.

Whereas, the waters of Georgia and Florida on the boundary between the two States commingle, and conflicts between the laws of the two States, create a great deal of trouble and friction between persons engaged in fishing in such waters, and render the enforcement of the Fish Laws of the two States difficult, and
Whereas, it is desirable for the proper protection of the fish industry in the boundary waters of this State, that there be co-operation with the State of Florida, and

Whereas, there has been a lack of friendly understanding between the two States with reference to the uniformity of the Fish Laws, thus creating bad feeling and rendering less effective the laws of the two States for the protection of fishing.

Therefore, be it Resolved by the House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, the Senate concurring, That a committee of two from the House and one from the Senate, to be named by the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate, respectively, be appointed for the purpose of conferring with the proper authorities of the State of Florida, with the view of bringing about a uniformity of laws between the two States regulating fishing in the boundary salt waters, and for proper enforcement thereof, and that said Committee report to the next session of the General Assembly of this State,
the result of its labors and make such recommendations as the members thereof shall deem advisable with reference to the subject matter of their investigations. Committee appointed.

law.shorttitle: GENERAL ASSEMBLY; NOTIFICATION OF COMPLETION OF BUSINESS.
law.p: Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, That a Committee of Five be appointed, three to be appointed by the Speaker of the House and two to be appointed by the President of the Senate, to notify the Governor that the General Assembly has completed the business before it and now stands ready to adjourn sine die. Committee appointed.

Whereas, a Bill has been passed by both branches of the General Assembly providing authority for the lease of the property at the corner of Peachtree and Cain Streets in Atlanta known as the Governor's Mansion, and Preamble.
Whereas, That property is not in fit state to be used as a place of residence by the Governor; and the present Governor is not using it for residence purposes, nor can he safely do so, and
Whereas, under existing conditions the Governor and his family are put to the necessity of living in a hotel, therefore

Be it Resolved, That the Governor is hereby authorized by the General Assembly, the House and Senate concurring, to employ a sum not to exceed $5,000 from the contingent fund of the executive department during the year 1922 and a like sum during the year 1923; and that he is further authorized to employ a sum of $2,500 for the year 1921, for the purpose of leasing or otherwise providing a temporary place of residence to be used by the Chief Executive and his family. Be it further Contingent fund, use authorized.

Resolved, That the Finance Committee of the Senate, now engaged upon the general appropriations bill, be requested to make provisions in that bill so as to cover the intent and purpose of this resolution by adding these sums to the item making appropriation for the contingent fund of the Executive Department. Sums added to appropriations act.

law.shorttitle: W. J. GREEN; EXPRESSION OF SYMPATHY.
law.p: Whereas, the Hon. W. J. Green, a member of the lower House from Jones County, has asked leave to attend the burial of his son, who died as a brave soldier in the cause of his country on the fields of France, Preamble.

Be it Resolved, by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the deep sympathy of the General Assembly of Georgia be extended to our Honorable Colleague and the
members of his family, and that the brave example and sacrifice of his deceased son who died as a soldier in the cause of his country be honorably commended. Sympathy extended.

Be it further Resolved, That upon concurrence of the Senate, that a copy of this resolution be transmitted to the Hon. W. J. Green, member of the lower House from Jones County, as a lasting evidence of sympathy of the General Assembly of Georgia in this his hour of bereavement. Transmission of copy.

law.shorttitle: HALL OF HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES; INVESTIGATION OF ACOUSTICS.
law.p: Whereas, the acoustic property of the Hall of the House of Representatives is such that it is almost impossible for members to hear speeches. Be it resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, That the Governor be requested to have an architect investigate this defect to see if it can be obviated. Preamble. Investigation.

Whereas, the State Highway Commission in order to co-operate with the counties, to secure the Federal Aid funds available and to build the system of State roads
stipulated by the law creating said Highway Department having adopted a large and extensive road and bridge building program and whereas the Legislature believing that the report of said Highway Commission was inadequate to fully acquaint the Legislature and the people of this State with the affairs, acts and accomplishments of the said Highway Department during the past twelve months, therefore be it resolved that a joint committee of nineteen members be appointed by the Speaker of the House and President of the Senate, twelve members to be selected from the House and seven from the Senate, respectively, whose duty it shall be to conduct a complete and detailed investigation of the Highway Department of this State, to inquire fully into all the affairs of the department, including its expenditures, acts and accomplishments; it shall also be the duty of this committee to report its findings to the Legislature within ten days from its creation; it is especially provided that expenses of said committee shall amount to not more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars; the committee is clothed with full authority to conduct a full and complete investigation of said Highway Department. Preamble. Committee appointed. Duties.

law.shorttitle: HOUSE BILL NO. 439 REQUESTED RETURNED FOR CORRECTION.
law.p: Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, That the Governor, who now is in possession of House Bill 439, return the same to the House for correction of dates in said Bill. Governor requested to return bill.

law.shorttitle: JOINT COMMITTEE ON NEW TAXING SYSTEM.
law.p: Whereas, the General Assembly of the State of Georgia has under consideration an Amendment to the Constitution of Georgia which proposes that the question be submitted to the people of Georgia whether the present ad valorem system of taxation shall be abandoned in favor of a new system of taxation upon incomes, inheritances, gross earnings, etc. Preamble.

Whereas, this departure from a system with which the people are familiar should first receive at the hands of the General Assembly of Georgia a through, comprehensive study and analysis in the light of the experience of other States before being submitted to the people for ratification or rejection;

Whereas, by a study and discussion of this subject the members of the General Assembly of Georgia would be the better qualified to propose this question to the people of Georgia in a manner calculated to produce the desired results without disturbing business conditions, and without probable disastrous results to the varied interests of the State, manufacturing, banking, agricultural and industrial and to all other interests;

Whereas, after such examination of the many questions of law and fact involved in this proposal and a free discussion thereof in the General Assembly of Georgia and in the press of the State the electorate of Georgia would be much more familiar with all sides of the question and there better qualified to pass upon this legislation;
Whereas, all admit that the revenues of the State must be greater to maintain the institutions of Georgia in a manner in keeping with the wealth and progress of the State;

Whereas, it is the desire and wish of the people of Georgia that such system or systems be devised or perfected as will bring about this result, but without an un-due and unnecessary disturbance of business of every kind in the State;
Whereas, under all conditions and circumstances appropriations of every kind should be within the income of the State from all sources so that outgo should not hereafter exceed income;

Whereas, action on the proposed measure generally known as the income tax bill can not be of any final benefit or value at this session of the General Assembly, inasmuch as the whole matter must be submitted to the people of Georgia at a general election to be held after the regular session of the General Assembly of 1922;
Whereas, no time will be lost in submitting the proposal to the people by deferring action until the session of 1922;

Whereas, there are only ten more working days of the session of 1921 in which to consider the General Tax Act and the Appropriation Bill and the numerous Senate and House Bills and Resolutions, including the proposal to permit the Governor to pledge the rentals of the Western and Atlantic Railroad for funds with which to cover the present deficit in the State Treasury;

Whereas, it is manifestly impossible in that length of time to give full, fair and intelligent consideration to the business before the General Assembly nor to act with
wisdom, justice and moderation on such a proposal as involves a complete change in the system of taxation in Georgia;

Therefore, be it resolved by the General Assembly of Georgia that action on the income tax measures before the General Assembly be postponed until the session of 1922, and that for the purpose of evolving a system of taxation which will meet the needs of the State and distribute the burdens of taxation upon all classes equitably a Joint Committee shall be, and the same hereby is, appointed as follows: Five (5) from the Senate to be appointed by the President of the Senate; Ten (10) from the House of Representatives to be appointed by the Speaker of House of Representatives of Georgia, and to this Joint Committee of the Senate and House shall be referred all measures in the House or Senate relative to the said proposed change of tax systems, and this Joint Committee is hereby authorized to consider all such measures in vacation and to make a report of such bill for the consideration of the General Assembly as may be deemed proper on the first day of the session of 1922, and the said Joint Committee shall receive the regular per diem for the days it is actually in session in the work provided for in this resolution. Action postponed. Committee appointed.
Whereas, it has been reported all over the Northern and Eastern financial circles that Georgia is in the midst of a famine and her people stricken with an epidemic of pellagra, and, Preamble.
Whereas, this report is doing untold damage to the State and every branch of its industries.

Therefore, be it resolved by the House and Senate of the State of Georgia, now assembled, that such reports are absolutely without foundation and truth, and the press of the State co-operate with this body in correcting any such report or impression by giving as much publicity to this resolution as possible. Correction made public.

law.shorttitle: PRICE, J. J.; RELIEF AS SURETY.
law.p: Whereas, J. J. Price did become bail for the appearance of Martin Harris, colored, at the October term, 1919, of the Superior Court of Lincoln County, Georgia, in a case pending in said Court against the said Martin Harris, charging him with the offense of felony, which said bond was for the principal sum of one hundred and fifty dollars, and Preamble.

Whereas, by reason of the non-appearance of the said Martin Harris, said bond was forfeited and a rule absolute was entered at the said October term, 1919, and an execution was issued for the principal sum of one hundred and fifty dollars and costs, which was then and there paid by the said J. J. Price, surety aforesaid, and

Whereas, at the April term, 1921, of the said Superior Court of Lincoln County, the said Martin Harris did enter a plea of guilty to the said charge in said Court, after having been produced before said Court by said J. J. Price, his surety aforesaid, and was then and
there sentenced to serve a term of three years on the chaingang of said county, which term the said Martin Harris is now serving on said chainging.

It is, therefore, resolved by the Senate of Georgia, the House of Representative concurring, that inasmuch as the purpose for which said bond was made has been fully accomplished, the authorities of said Superior Court of Lincoln County, collecting and paying out the fines and forfeitures in said Superior Court, are hereby authorized and directed from said fines and forfeitures in said Superior Court, to pay the said J. J. Price the said sum of one hundred and fifty dollars and all costs paid by him on said foreclosure and rule to reimburse him the sum paid by him as aforesaid on account of the forfeiture of said bond, and said J. J. Price shall stand on the same priority in collecting and receiving said one hundred and fifty dollars from said fund of fines and forfeitures in said Superior Court as the other officers of said Court, to-wit: Solicitor-General, Clerk and Sheriff. Relief from forfeiture.

Be it resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That former Governors Hoke Smith, Joseph M. Brown and Hugh M. Dorsey be, and they are, hereby requested to hang upon the walls of the Executive Offices, their portraits. Portraits for executive offices.

law.shorttitle: QUITMAN COUNTY, SUPPLY OF BOOKS TO.
law.p: Whereas, the Court House of Quitman County was destroyed by fire on February 1, 1921, and all books, including Codes of Georgia, Supreme Court Reports, Court of Appeals Reports, Form Books, and Acts of the Legislature were thus consumed by fire. Preamble.

Be it therefore resolved by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the State Librarian be, and she is, hereby directed to furnish, at an early date as possible, to the Clerk of Superior Court of Quitman County, out of the stock on hand, complete sets of the Supreme Court Reports, from the first volume to the last volume issued inclusive, and of the Court of Appeals Reports from Number One to the last volume issued, and three Form Books, and two sets of Park's Codes, and Acts of the General Assembly up to and including the year 1920. Books from state library.

law.shorttitle: HON. F. P. RICE; PORTRAIT REQUESTED.
law.p: Whereas, the Honorable Frank P. Rice, ex-Senator from the 35th Senatorial District, Atlanta, Ga., was the author of the bill providing for the construction of the present Capitol building, which movement was in a Bill To be entitled an Act to construct a new Capitol building in the City of Atlanta for the State of Georgia, and which Bill passed the Legislature November 3, 1882. Preamble.

Therefore, be it resolved, That in order to preserve this important chapter of Georgia History, the Hon. Frank P. Rice is hereby requested to furnish to the Governor of Georgia, an oil painting of himself, and the Governor is requested to have same appropriately placed and hung in the Capitol building. Portrait to be placed in Capitol.

law.shorttitle: RUSSELL, REECE AND CAIN; RELIEF AS SURETIES.
law.p: Whereas, E. L. Russell, S. E. Reece, J. C. Cain and J. A. Palmer did on the 25th day of June, 1919, become bail for the appearance of one I. D. Cain at the October term, 1919, of the Superior Court of White County, Georgia, in a case pending against I. D. Cain, charging him with the offense of embezzlement, which said bond was forfeited by reason of the non-appearance of the said I. D. Cain, at the October term, 1920, of said Court, and Preamble.
Whereas, a rule absolute was entered and an execution issued upon the said rule absolute on the forfeiture of said bond for the principal sum of $2,000.00 and cost; and

Whereas, the said I. D. Cain was afterwards recaptured by the said E. L. Russell, S. E. Reese, J. C. Cain and J. A. Palmer, who paid the expenses of said recapture and the return of him back from Ohio, at which place he was recaptured, and
Whereas, the said I. D. Cain was delivered over to the Sheriff of said White County, and incarcerated in the jail of said county.

Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, and the Senate concurring, That inasmuch as the purpose for which said bond was made, is fully accomplished, that said E. L. Russell, S. E. Reese, J. A. Palmer and J. C. Cain be released from all liability on said execution issued on said forfeiture; provided, however, the said E. L. Russell, S. E. Reece, J. A. Palmer and J. C. Cain, the sureties on said bond, shall have first paid all cost in forfeiting said bond. Relief from forfeiture.

law.shorttitle: SHIRLEY, MRS. ELIZABETH, RE-ESTABLISHED AS PENSIONER.
law.p: Whereas, Mrs. Elizabeth Shirley, a pensioner of Hall County, in the State of Georgia, failed to receive the pension due her for the year 1919; and Preamble.
Whereas, the said pensioner is legally on the pension list, and said pension for said year is due and unpaid.

Be it therefore resolved, That the sum of one hundred ($100.00) dollars be, and the same is, hereby appropriated to pay the pension of Mrs. Elizabeth Shirley, of the County of Hall, for the year 1919, and the Governor, upon requisition being made therefor by the Commissioner of Pensions, is hereby authorized to draw his warrant therefor, to be paid by the Treasurer of Georgia to the Ordinary of Hall County, out of any funds in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated. $100 for 1919 pension.

law.shorttitle: SPRING STREET VIADUCT; CONSENT OF STATE.
law.p: Be it resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That consent on the part of the State be, and the same is, hereby granted to the City of Atlanta, through its duly authorized authorities, to erect a bridge from a point at or near the present terminus of what is known as Spring street in the City of Atlanta upon along and over the State's property, known as the Western and Atlantic Railroad property, to a point at or near the present Terminal station in the City of Atlanta. Consent given.
This consent is granted with the provision that consent of the present lessees of the W. A. Railroad shall be first given to said City of Atlanta. Consent of W. A. railroad lessees.

Be it resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That there shall be appointed a committee of five composed of three from the House and two from the Senate to make investigation of the affairs of the Georgia State Sanitarium at Milledgeville. Said committee is hereby clothed with authority to summon witnesses, compel the production of books, papers and records and to do such other acts as are necessary to develop all facts in connection
with the operation of said institution and they are hereby directed to report their findings to the next General Assembly. Committee appointed.

law.shorttitle: TENNESSEE COPPER CO. ET AL.; CONTRACT AS TO LITIGATION, ETC.
law.p: To be entitled a Joint Resolution to authorize and direct the Governor of the State to contract in respect to the subject matter of the litigation pending in the Supreme Court of the United States between the State of Georgia and the Tennessee Copper Company and the Ducktown Sulphur, Copper and Iron Company, Ltd.; to provide for the settlement of damages done to the citizens of Georgia; to provide for the modification of existing contracts between the State of Georgia and the Tennessee Copper Company and the Ducktown Sulphur, Copper and Iron Company, Ltd., and for other purposes.

Whereas, the State of Georgia has pending against the Tennessee Copper Company and the Ducktown Sulphur, Copper and Iron Company, Ltd., in the Supreme Court of the United States an action for injunction and other relief, which has been pending for a number of years; but the State has found it more expedient, and in the interest of its citizens to give to these companies an opportunity to remedy the evils complained of and to adjust such damages as may be done to citizens of this State through a system of arbitration; and in pursuance of this policy the Governor, at the direction of the General
Assembly, from time to time, has entered into contracts with these companies designed to the end just stated; and Preamble.

Whereas, during the operation of these contracts the companies have relieved the conditions formerly existing, and such damages as now occur are casual and easily to be compensated by the award of damages in individual cases; and

Whereas, these improvements and diminution of the damage have progressed to such an extent that the annual damage is now much less than the expenses of the arbitration board, so that it is no longer necessary to expend the large sums of money hitherto spent in the maintenance of the arbitration system as formerly maintained, but the same can now be operated effectively at much less expense.

Therefore, be it resolved by the General Assembly of Georgia (the Senate and the House of Representatives concurring), That the Governor is authorized and directed to enter into a new contract or contracts with said companies, said contracts to be substantially of the same nature as the contracts now in force and to extend for a period of five years from the expiration of the present contracts, but the same provisions as to the termination thereof as are contained in the provisions of Sections 10 and 12 of the contract between the State of Georgia and the Tennessee Copper Company as set forth in the joint resolution of the General Assembly of Georgia on that subject, approved August 6, 1913, relating to notice of termination and the means by which such contracts may be terminated for failure of the company bona fide to live up to the contract, shall be a part of the new contracts. New contracts authorized.

Furthermore, the new contracts shall contain the same limitations as to the amount of sulphur dioxide gases
which may be emitted from said plants as are contained in the present contracts, to-wit: The daily escapage of Tennessee Copper Company shall be not exceeding eighty-eight (88) tons and that of Ducktown Sulphur, Copper and Iron Company, Ltd., not exceeding forty (40) tons, during the growing season provided for in said contracts, being from April 10th to October 1st of each year. Gas escapage limited.
However, in the interests of economy, it is directed that the Governor is authorized to agree with the said companies on the following changes in the system of arbitration:

The Governor shall appoint a disinterested and capable State's Arbitrator; and the State's Arbitrator shall, in addition to his powers as arbitrator, act as the State's sole standing inspector, with all the powers of any inspector appointed by the Governor under existing contracts; and the offices of existing inspectors under the present contracts are abolished; provided, nevertheless, the Governor may, in his discretion, on complaint of any citizen or at any other time when he thinks the circumstances so require, send a special inspector, at the expense of the companies, to visit said plants or the territory adjacent thereto, and make a special report to the Governor on any matter as to which the Governor may desire special information. The State's Arbitrator shall receive a salary not exceeding $100.00 per month, for the period from April 10th to November 1st of each year and his necessary expenses (to be audited and allowed by the Governor) while he is actually engaged in the work, the same to cover his services as arbitrator and inspector. The Governor shall see to it that at all times at least one of the arbitrators shall be a citizen of one of the Counties of Fannin, Gilmer or Union. Arbitrator to be inspector. Compensation.

The office of standing umpire is abolished; but the new contracts shall provide that in the event the Arbitrator appointed by the companies and the State's Arbitrator are unable to agree, and only in the event of such disagreement, the Governor shall designate some person to act as umpire in the matter, as to which the two Arbitrators have so disagreed, said umpire to receive as compensation for his services not exceeding $10.00 a day and his actual expenses, to be fixed, audited and allowed by the Governor, while engaged in determining the matter as to which he is called in by the disagreement of the two Arbitrators. Standing umpire abolished. Special umpire.

Nothing herein shall in any wise relieve the said companies from paying the expenses of the arbitration system, as provided in the original Court costs, except as herein modified. The ratio of liability as between the two companies shall remain as in the contracts now in force. Expenses of arbitration.

Upon such new contracts being satisfactorily executed between the Governor, on behalf of the State of Georgia, and the said companies, through their respective representatives, the Attorney-General of the State is directed to join with the attorneys representing said companies respectively in taking such steps in the Supreme Court of the United States as will carry the agreement into effect, so as to provide for a suspension of the proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States during the period in which said contracts shall remain in force. Suspension of Supreme court proceedings.

law.shorttitle: TUTTLE-NEWTON HOME, TRANSFER OF PROPERTY TO.
law.p: To authorize the Governor of Georgia to transfer to the Tuttle-Newton Home the property of 100 acres of land described in the following resolution, and for other purposes.

Whereas, the State of Georgia entered into a contract with the Tuttle-Newton Home, an eleemosynary corporation, established under the laws of Georgia, and located in Richmond County, Georgia, to purchase certain property within said State in the County of Richmond belonging to said Home, containing 325 acres, with improvements thereon, for the purpose of locating and establishing the Georgia Training School for Mental Defectives, and Preamble.
Whereas, it was ascertained by careful survey of the tract from which said 325 acres was to be taken contained 425 acres, and

Whereas, on the 1st day of October, 1920, said Tuttle-Newton Home executed to the State of Georgia a conveyance in fee simple to said land in compliance with the contract aforesaid, and through error described in said conveyance the entire tract of 425 acres and

Whereas, the State thereby received 100 acres of land for which it has paid aboslutely nothing and which it was intended and contracted should not be conveyed to it, which said 100 acres contains no improvements and is no part of the land originally intended to be conveyed,

Therefore, be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, In order to correct said mistake the Governor be, and he is hereby authorized and
requested to reconvey, as early as practicable after the approval of this Resolution to the Tuttle-Newton Home the within described tract of land. Property transferred.

All that lot or parcel of land with improvements thereon, lying and being in the State of Georgia, County of Richmond, near Gracewood, Georgia, beginning at a point where the northeastern boundary of Hale tract No. 1 intersects the southwestern boundary of the Roberson tract, at or near the high water mark of Spirit Creek, which point is specifically numbered 10 on a plat recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Richmond County in a deed from the Tuttle-Newton Home to the State of Georgia, recorded in Book 9 J's, pages 388 and 392, thence south 65 degrees 30 minutes west five hundred thirty-four feet (534) to a point marked nine (9) on said plat; thence south 48 degrees 30 minutes west five hundred sixty-six (566) feet to a point marked eight (8) on said plat; thence south 40 degrees 30 minutes west one hundred seventy-five (175) feet to a point marked seven (7) on said plat; thence south 54 degrees 30 minutes west two hundred eighty-one (281) feet to a point marked six (6) on said plat; thence south 170 degrees 30 minutes east forty-two (42) feet to a point marked five (5) on said plat and which point is marked by a stake; thence south 43 degrees 0 minutes west nineteen hundred forty-nine (1949) feet to a point marked four (4) on said plat, which point is marked by a pine stump; thence south 58 degrees 30 minutes east seventeen hundred three 8-10 (1703.8) feet, which point is in the line between points number four (4) and three (3) on said plat, but is not marked on said plat; thence south 33 degrees 30 minutes west twenty-seven hundred seventy-six (2776) feet to point on the line between the Hall tract No. 1 and the Robinson tract, as shown on said plat, which point is five hundred fifty-three 4-10 (553.4) feet from the intersection of Hall tract No. 1, Hall tract No. 2 and Robinson
tract on said plat; thence south 23 degrees 50 minutes east one thousand seven 6-10 (1007.6) feet to the point of beginning, which tract comprises approximately one hundred acres (100) and which tract is bounded on the north by land of Deas; west by land now belonging to the State of Georgia, which land consists of twenty-eight (28) acres originally part of Robinson tract, south by Hall tract No. 1 on said plat and Brandon's Mill Road; east of Brandon's Mill Road and land of Brandon and which tract is one hundred (100) acres of the Robinson tract. Description taken from plat made by Geo. W. Summers, April 9, 1920. Description.

law.shorttitle: UNFINISHED BUSINESS OF ASSEMBLY; AUTHORIZED HELD OVER.
law.p: Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, that all bills, resolutions, etc., on the Calendar and undisposed of at the adjournment of the present session of the General Assembly go over to the next regular session to convene in 1922, as unfinished business of the present session, shall retain the same position on the Calendar which they occupy at the time of adjournment of this session. Position on calendar.

law.shorttitle: UNFINISHED BUSINESS OF ASSEMBLY; PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO REMAIN AFTER ADJOURNMENT.
law.p: Resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate, the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate, be, and are, hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol five days after the adjournment of the General Assembly for the purpose of affixing their official signatures to all bids and resolutions passed previous to said adjournment, and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Officers to remain at Capitol.

Resolved, That the Chairmen, respectively, of the Enrollment and Auditing Committees of the House and Senate, together with the members of the Senate Enrollment Committee, and eight members of the House Enrollment Committee, to be designated by the Chairman thereof, and two members of the House Auditing Committee, and two members of the Senate Auditing Committee, to be designated by the Chairman thereof, and the Chairman of the House Engrossing Committee and four members of the House Engrossing Committee, to be designated by the Chairman thereof, and the Chairman and two members of the Senate Engrossing Committee, to be designated by the Chairman thereof, be, and they are, hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol five days after the adjourned General Assembly, for the purpose of bringing up the unfinished business of the session, and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Committee members authorized to remain.

Resolved further, That the Postmistress of the House be, and she is, hereby authorized to remain at the
Capitol five days after the adjournment of the General Assembly, for the purpose of distributing and forwarding members' mail, and that she be allowed her per diem for said time. Postmistress.

Resolved further, That three porters of the House and two porters of the Senate be, and they are, hereby authorized to remain at the Capitol five days after the adjournment of the General Assembly, and that they be allowed their per diem for said time. Porters.

law.shorttitle: UNFINISHED BUSINESS OF ASSEMBLY, STATEMENT AS TO.
law.p: Resolved by the House, the Senate concurring, That E. B. Moore, Clerk of the House, and Devereaux F. McClatchey, Secretary of the Senate, be instructed to prepare, publish and mail to each member of the General Assembly, a statement showing the status of all unfinished business of this session at the time of its adjournment. Statement to each member.

law.shorttitle: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA; COMMITTEE ON BILLS TO ESTABLISH REGENTS.
law.p:
To appoint a Joint Committee from the Senate and House to investigate and report on the Bills to establish a Board or Boards of Regents for the University
of Georgia, and its branches, and for the public schools and eleemosynary institutions of said State.

Whereas, there is now pending in both the Senate and House of Representatives, Bills to establish a Board or Boards of Regents for the University of Georgia and its branches and departments, for the public and high schools and for the eleemosynary institutions of this State, and to prescribe the duties and determine the jurisdiction of said Board or Boards; and Preamble.

Whereas, it is apparent that, for the remainder of the present session, the time and energies of the members of the General Assembly will be devoted almost exclusively to the fiscal affairs of the State; and

Whereas, it will be difficult, if not impossible, for the General Assembly at this session to make that careful and exhaustive study of the subject which its difficulties and supreme importance to the State demand.

Therefore, be it resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That a Joint Committee composed of three from the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate, and five from the House, appointed by the Speaker of the House, be named at the present session, and that their duties be, and they are, hereby prescribed as follows: Committee appointed.

item.p: 1. To make a thorough examination into and study of the present system of education in this State, with the view of recommending corrective measures as needed. Examination of educational systems.
2. To examine into the educational systems of other States where measures, similar to those proposed for this State, have been and are now in operation.

3. To prepare and submit to the General Assembly of Georgia at its next session such report and a draft of such measure or measures as will indicate the results of such investigation and study, and as will embody in concrete form the proposed changes in our educational system. Said investigation should cost the State only actual expenses of its members. Report. Costs.

law.shorttitle: WESTERN AND ATLANTIC RAILROAD; NEW DEPOTS IN CERTAIN CITIES.
law.p: Whereas, the Western and Atlantic Railroad is a standard, single track, main line road, connecting Atlanta, Georgia, with Chattanooga, Tennessee; and Preamble.
Whereas, said W. and A. Railroad runs in a north-westerly direction through Fulton, Cobb, Bartow, Gordon, Whitfield and Catoosa Counties in Georgia; and
Whereas, the Counties of Fulton, Cobb, Bartow, Gordon, Whitfield and Catoosa receive no taxes whatsoever from either the W. and A. Railroad or the lessee; and
Whereas, the W. and A. Railroad is a most excellent railroad and is maintained up to a high standard; and
Whereas, the passenger depots at Marietta, Cartersville, Calhoun and Dalton are in a dilapidated condition and are absolutely incapable of and inadequate to meet the demands of traffic.

Therefore, be it resolved by the Senate, the House of Representatives concurring, That the Railroad Commission
of Georgia is hereby requested to authorize and direct the lessees of the W. and A. Railroad to erect passenger depots at Marietta, Cartersville, Calhoun and Dalton sufficiently capable of meeting the demands of traffic; also to erect rain sheds at other points. Depots at Marietta, Cartersville, Calhoun, and Dalton.
